That we strenuously object to the proposal to deny Western Districts Health Fund Medicare agency rights in the Blue Mountains and to deny Springwood the availability of a Medicare agency altogether.
The agency has provided an important service to a community characterised by its large number of young families and aged persons and by its public transport difficulties.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the termination of the Medicare agency rights for Western Districts Health Fund and the withdrawal of Medicare services in Springwood in particular.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain residents of the Illawarra region draws to the attention of the House any proposed fundamental changes to Federal contributions to children's services.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
Continue a strong Federal commitment to a high quality of care in all children's services.
Maintain regulations governing the quality of care delivered through children's services.
Continue both Operational Assistance Grants and Fee Relief Subsidies ensuring that all child care services and individual families receive direct assistance.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology I present the Committee's report entitled Investment in Australian Manufacturing, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee's first inquiry was an inquiry into the factors determining the level of investment in Australian manufacturing and policies which might improve investment performance. The decline in the 1950s and 1960s of the relative contribution of the manufacturing sector to Australia's gross domestic product is well known. At the same time, manufactured goods, along with services, have become high growth areas in world trade. Australia has not maintained its share of the world trade in these products. Partly as a result of that, our external debt has grown to a size which is a threat to our future standard of living. The overall level of investment in Australian manufacturing, at least until recently, has been insufficient to restructure and revitalise the industry. The Committee was not convinced that the increase in manufacturing investment since 1985-86 provides grounds for complacency. A considerable period of recovery is needed to overcome the effect of the decline of the manufacturing sector in previous years to achieve the structural changes necessary in a less protected, more competitive environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject matter of the Committee's inquiry was very broad in scope and very complex in detail. Complexities arise in the very definition of investment and its measurement. Many witnesses and submissions emphasised the importance of examining investment in research and development and in the training of our work force, as well as the more conventional forms of investment in plant and equipment. The current shortage in skilled labour in many industries is persuasive evidence of deficiencies in training investment. The Committee supports the establishment by the Government of a task force to investigate education and skills training reform. The task force needs to determine the reasons for the low level of contribution to training by industry in Australia by comparison, particularly, with the more dynamic Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries and to find means of substantially increasing such investment.

The process of negotiation between industry and unions obviously is an approach to be preferred, but results need to be achieved quickly. The Committee recommends that the task force examine alternative forms of establishing industry training funds so that, if necessary, the Government may be in a position to take action without further delay. The Committee also recommends that the task force examine the apprenticeship system. Evidence presented to the Committee indicates that the apprenticeship system is often inflexible, too narrow in its focus on particular trades and does not provide adequately for adult training or retraining.

As with training investment, the contribution of the business sector in Australia to research and development has been low by comparison with other OECD countries. Our contribution has grown in recent years, obviously encouraged by the introduction of the 150 per cent tax incentive scheme. There is evidence that many industry leaders do not appreciate the importance and value of research and development expenditure, quite apart from the tax benefit. Hopefully, having been encouraged to invest in research and development, those problems of attitude may be overcome. The Government announced in the May economic statement that the 150 per cent tax deduction would remain until 1 July 1991, at which time it would become a 100 per cent deduction scheme. The Committee recommends that the scheme not be further altered after July 1991 for another five years. This would ensure that business could undertake research and development investment with greater confidence, as well as allowing more time to promote the desirable change in management attitudes towards such investment.

Returning to investment in the more conventional sense of expenditure on plant and equipment, the Committee found that a wide range of factors can influence investment decisions. The level of expected demand obviously is one of the main factors and the response time of new investment to increases in expected demand clearly is affected by the amount of existing surplus production capacity. As we have seen in recent years, shifts in the exchange rate of the Australian dollar can make our products more or less competitive on world markets and can make imports more or less a threat to local industries. Much of the growth in manufacturing investment since 1985-86 was stimulated by the substantial depreciation of the Australian dollar that occurred in that year. We have seen how volatile exchange rates can be and the uncertainties that confront those people making investment decisions.

Obviously, another major factor influencing investment decisions is the expected rate of return. That in turn depends on expectations about all the factors which can influence costs-the availability and cost of labour and capital, which includes both wages and interest rates; the costs imposed by government regulation and taxation; the inflation rate; the amount of industrial disputation, and so on. All these factors have an impact on business confidence or uncertainty, that important background atmosphere in which decisions are made.

Government policies clearly affect many of the above determinants of investment behaviour. At the broad macroeconomic level the Government must be seen to have a consistent, predictable policy direction. It is important that business has a stable framework in which to operate. I believe the importance of that has been recognised by the Government. There is wide agreement in the community and across political parties concerning the need for the inflation rate to be lowered to at least match that of our major competitors and trading partners. Similarly, there is agreement that we cannot afford a blow-out in real wages-although there will always be scope for disagreement concerning the size of acceptable increases in nominal wages and the means by which wages should be regulated. There is agreement also that the Government should remove as far as possible impediments to investment, either created by government policies or existing as distortions in the economic system.

A major irritant, particularly to smaller businesses, is the complexity of government regulation. Partly this results from the existence of three tiers of government; but much could be done to simplify and coordinate the requirements imposed by government on the establishment and operation of businesses. The `one stop shop' approach has a great deal to recommend it. Concerted efforts need to be made by all levels of government to weed out unnecessary or outdated regulations which serve only to increase the costs and time delays imposed on business activity.

Government taxes are another area identified by industry as an impediment to investment. It is important that the taxation burden in this country should not render our exporters internationally uncompetitive; nor should the taxation system create major biases between different kinds of investment, unless this is consciously done as a strictly temporary assistance scheme. Prior to the reforms announced in the May Statement, there did appear to be substantial differences between the effective tax burdens imposed on different kinds of investment and depending on whether the investments were financed by debt or equity. The reduction in corporate tax rates and the replacement of the accelerated depreciation scheme should decrease those distortions. For some who benefited particularly from the accelerated depreciation allowance the reduction in tax rate may not provide a complete compensation. It is to be hoped that the overall effect will be to encourage at least a more economically efficient pattern of investment. Changes in the inflation rate can significantly alter effective tax rates and create biases between those relying on debt financing or equity financing.

Reform of the tax system to take account of the impact of inflation has been regarded as a very complex and difficult area. The Committee recommends, however, that such reform to remove or minimise the distorting effect of inflation be fully investigated. In addition to removing impediments to investment, it is often suggested that the Government provide investment incentives-either for industry in general or, more usually, for particular fledgling industries or industries targeted for their longer term potential. The Committee does not support the reintroduction of a general investment allowance, nor did we identify particular industries which might be targeted for investment allowances.

The Committee did consider, however, that the venture capital market requires special consideration. The introduction of the capital gains tax was intended to remove an anomaly in the taxation system. It decreased, however, the attraction of investment in venture capital funds. In 1983 the Government considered that special measures were needed to aid in the establishment of a venture capital market and introduced the management and investment companies program. The creation of a capital gains tax, as part of a more general tax reform measure, may not have taken full account of the impact on the venture capital market. The Committee recommends that a strictly temporary exemption from capital gains tax be granted for venture capital investment to allow this market a better chance of becoming fully established. The Committee also recommends that the venture capital market be reviewed again before July 1991, at which date the Government has proposed to terminate the management and investment companies program.

The Committee was concerned, as well, about the more general matter of the availability of finance for new or small businesses. Evidence was given of the difficulties experienced by such businesses. An economy which requires restructuring and development must have a financial system which services those needs. It would seem timely to examine whether the Australian Financial system and its institutions are adequate to the task. The Committee recommends such an examination, including the impact of financial deregulation and subsequent new entry into the banking and financial system.

The threat of takeover activity was suggested as one cause of increases in divided payouts, the reduction in the availability of internal sources of investment finance and consequent pressures on the cost and availability of external finance. There is concern in the community about purely speculative takeover activity and speculative investment generally in the share and property markets, such activity diverts funds away from more productive forms of investment. There is community concern as well that such speculation using borrowed money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in supporting the tabling of this report by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology I would like very quickly to allude to a few matters that have been partly covered by the Chairman, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), and also emphasise some of those points and raise some others. There was universal agreement that there should be increased industry training. I think all honourable members would agree that one of the major problems facing Australia today concerns the training of the work force and the increasing of skills. One of our difficulties is the method by which we can improve the situation, although we all support the broad principle. That in itself shows the level of bipartisanship that this Committee has engendered.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to talk a little more about financing and tax and so on, matters to which the Chairman alluded. The Committee did find that the tax system creates some considerable problems when it comes to financing new manufacturing and the replacement of plant. As the report says in its introduction, the most important thing to do to remove some of the distortions that the tax system causes is to bring down inflation. There is no doubt that that should be the overriding aim of any government. It is also interesting to note the distorting effects of the tax system on debt financing versus equity financing. Despite some of the changes made in the May mini-Budget, there is still a problem because taxpayers do to some extent subsidise debt financing.

I was very interested in some of the findings-they are mentioned in the report-of the National Priorities Project 1988. They are mentioned also in a book called Spending and Taxing II: Taking Stock from the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University. It makes fascinating reading because it points out some of the problems of the different forms of financing and the ways they effect different forms of capital structures in ownership. I would like to quote from a paper submitted to the Committee from the Centre of Policy Studies which unfortunately arrived too late to be considered for the report. It highlights some of the difficulties the Chairman alluded to concerning the effects of inflation and the effects of tax on methods of finding capital for companies and businesses to expand their manufacturing. This group found that there is a paradox-I guess that is not exclusive to Australia; it is found in other countries-that shows that a drop in the statutory company tax rate does not imply that effective tax rates will drop. The paper states:
In fact, in some cases they-
that is, the effective tax rates-

have risen even with a drop in the personal tax rate. A lower corporate tax rate decreases the value of tax deductions on two counts. Firstly it decreases the value of nominal debt interest deductibility and imputation credits. Secondly it decreases the amount that can be deducted from tax through depreciation allowances.

This decrease is over and above that lost through a lower rate of depreciation. In the case of debt and new share finance investment, these two effects are sufficient to cancel out any advantage gained through a lower statutory rate.

So this in itself shows that it is a very much more complex area than some people probably believe at first sight. Reducing the company tax rate does not automatically mean that effective tax rates on companies and on new investment will also drop. That is a point that ought to be borne in mind when looking at the conclusions of this report.

I also support the concerns expressed by the Chairman and in the report in regard to the need to maintain a venture capital market. There is no doubt that this has led to the spawning of a lot of new businesses. I do not think they have had a full opportunity yet to reach fruition, and the idea of a venture capital market should be continued. Obviously the effects of the capital gains tax in this area are serious and, while I want to maintain some bipartisanship, the fact is that the Opposition has a different view on capital gains taxation.

The only other point I would like to touch on relates to section 9. While there is mention of the concern about speculative investment and whether there ought to be tax deductibility in relation to share purchases, I feel that in practical terms it would be very difficult to distinguish between what is speculative investment and what is not. What may appear to be speculative investment today could in a very short time turn out to be investment for working funds for a business. I think it would be dangerous to try to distinguish between the two because in the long run it is unlikely that we will find a practical solution that will lead to a better method of funding new investment.

In the short time available I would also like to thank the members of the secretariat for their support. Obviously, these committees depend very heavily on the skills of the members of the secretariat. They have certainly done a marvellous job in helping to prepare this report. I know that other members of the Committee want to grab some time, so I conclude by commending the report to the House. I hope that it leads to a more informed debate on some of the problems that are facing the manufacturing industry, particularly how to raise the level of investment and also, most importantly, how to raise the level of skill development for the manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Investment in Australian manufacturing is certainly an appropriate topic, given the centrality and importance of increasing manufacturing investment if Australia's economic restructuring task is to be successfully accomplished. Honourable members obviously would be aware of the fact that in recent times we have experienced a long term decline in the terms of trade. This decline has improved in the last year or so, but most people expect that to be a relatively temporary phenomenon.

SPEECH.PARA: We will have to restructure our economy significantly if the current account balance is to be corrected in the long term. The key element of that is to revive and rebuild our manufacturing sector but to do it in a way rather different from that in which it was originally formed in the post-war period, with a much greater emphasis on being internationally competitive and export-oriented than was the case before. These are the goals that need to be achieved if we are to correct our structural economic imbalances. That point is generally accepted. However, there will obviously be considerable debate about the best way of going about that task.

It is also common ground between all participants in the Australian economic debate that we need, firstly, an increase in aggregate investment levels and, secondly, a switching of investment into the internationally traded goods sector. Those two objectives will have to be achieved in order to reach our economic goals. Given the importance and centrality of that objective, it is appropriate that the Committee take a look at that issue as its first reference and see what sort of recommendations it can come up with.

One of the criticisms that one may have had of the House of Representatives committee system in the previous Parliament is that in some cases-not all cases-it tended to drift off into relatively peripheral areas of policy and debate. This issue is right at the core of the current economic debate. I was very pleased when the Committee decided to adopt it as its first reference.

There is a lot of debate and there are all sorts of conceptual problems about what constitutes an adequate level of investment. Do we just look at some kind of historical norm? If we look at an historical norm, what account do we take of the early 1980s when we had the resources boom which, it was said, produced an artificially inflated investment level for a short period? What is our benchmark for an adequate investment performance? There is a whole series of issues which, given the five-minute time constraint, I obviously cannot address here; but these are matters that are explored at some length in the Committee report. I urge honourable members who are interested in the subject to look at it.

In relation to current performance, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget pre- sentation and in the Budget Papers set out a rather optimistic outlook for total investment next year-12 per cent real growth. If that is achieved, obviously that will be an excellent start in the direction of reviving the investment performance of Australia's economy.

There is a separate issue of how much of that is going into manufacturing and how much is going into the traded goods sector generally. Since the depreciation of early 1985 we have seen a significant pick-up in manufacturing investment. However, it must be borne in mind, firstly, that that pick-up was from a fairly small base and, secondly, that for an economy undergoing major structural change-such as we hope ours is-one would expect an unusually high capital to output ratio and unusually high levels of investment. So it is not necessarily valid to be satisfied or content about the performance to date. Certainly, things are moving in the right direction but that has to be sustained and we have to recognise that we are undergoing big structural changes, so unusually high investment levels are appropriate and necessary.

I have some concerns about our investment performance. There is not time to go into them in detail now. In part, they relate to the impact of the deregulated foreign exchange and financial sector. As honourable members would be aware, we are currently seeing what is regarded as a temporary improvement in the terms of trade and, coupled with that, a substantial strengthening of the Australian dollar. Obviously, they will have a significant adverse impact on the export potential of some of our manufacturers. If that trend is sustained over a longer period there could be significant problems. There is a policy dilemma inherent in operating a floating exchange rate that once the depreciation starts to do its work and to turn around the trade volumes, automatically the currency starts to appreciate and we begin to lose the initial competitive advantage.

Coupled with a temporary strengthening in commodity prices, we have a bit of a problem. Whether the operation of that whole system will produce the type of sustained growth in investment that we need remains an open question. I suspect that some form of non-market intervention will still be required, particularly through the operations of the financial system, if the necessary investment performance in manu- facturing and in the traded goods sector generally is to be achieved. I conclude by joining the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in thanking the Committee secretariat for the excellent work that it put into this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a new member of parliament the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is the first parliamentary committee report with which I have had anything to do. Working on the Committee was certainly an illuminating experience. The Committee went to some lengths to try to produce a bipartisan report, which it has done. There were times when members from this side of the House felt rather outnumbered. I acknowledge that members from the other side of the House were prepared to accommodate our concerns and at no stage did we ever have to record a vote in trying to come to a final report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address two issues in the Committee report under intangible investment-skills formation and research and development. On skills formation, I would like to talk briefly on the apprenticeship system and also about business contribution to skills formation. The Committee heard quite a lot of concern about the apprenticeship scheme as it exists at the moment. Specific concerns were that people coming out of the apprenticeship system were not broadly enough trained and that there was not enough flexibility for getting into the apprenticeship system in the first place, particularly for older people who may wish to go back to retrain in an apprenticeship. Business frequently expressed the concern that there was a shortage of skilled labour and it would seem all around that there is enormous dissatisfaction with the way the system is working at the moment. I hope that the review of the apprenticeship system that is under way now will address those concerns and come up with realistic alternatives.

Business contribution to skills formation was discussed at length in the Committee. It would appear on the face of it that business and private expenditure on research and training in Australia is very poor. A table in the report shows that business and private investment as a percentage of gross domestic product in Australia is 1.2 per cent, which compares unfavourably with the United States of America at 1.7 per cent, Japan at 2 per cent and West Germany at 2.1 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That This House supports the principle of one vote one value for elections to State and Federal Parliaments of the Commonwealth of Australia.

`Justice' is the first word of the first speech that I am privileged to make in the new and permanent Parliament House. I use the word `justice' at the beginning of my speech because I believe that as members of parliament we come to this place to implement principles of justice and to work and fight for the interests of the people. So, to that end, there could be no better way to start private members' business in this House than to debate the motion appearing before us today. That motion is: That this House supports the principle of one vote one value for elections to State and Federal Parliaments of the Commonwealth of Australia. This, of course, is one of the subjects of the referendum proposal which is going to be put to the people on 3 September. My motion will be seconded by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who is the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

The purpose of the motion is unambiguous. It is to give members of the Opposition an opportunity to stand up and be counted on one of the most basic principles of parliamentary democracy-a principle that we in the Australian Labor Party hold dear. It is for that reason that we are putting the proposal to the people to vote on at a referendum. This proposal forms an essential part of the social justice strategy of the Australian Labor Party. One element of that strategy is to provide opportunities for people to participate in decisions that affect their lives, to do more than just vote once every three years at an election.

The proposal for democratic reform of the Constitution grew out of a prolonged period of consultation by the Constitutional Commission and I will refer to that in the course of my speech. But it is not a new principle; it is not a new idea. Many people from all walks of life and all political persuasions have supported this principle before. As long ago as 1959 the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review was established by Sir Robert Menzies. That Committee was made up of members of all political parties. In its report in 1959 the Committee recommended that a clause be inserted into the Constitution in similar form to that which we are proposing that the people of Australia have an opportunity to put into our Constitution in 1988.

I am glad that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has entered the chamber, because his father was a member of that joint committee. His father, a man of principle, stood up for what I always thought were Liberal Party values-principles of fairness. I put the honourable member for Mayo to the test today. Does he stand by that unanimous report of 1959?

During the lead-up to the election of the Whitlam Government, time and time again the then Opposition put the Liberal-Country Party Government, as it then was, to the test. The then Opposition sought to move amendments to the electoral legislation in 1961, 1965 and 1968. Time and time again-in 1964, 1968 and 1971-private member's Bills were introduced into the Parliament. On each occasion the Opposition opposed the principle of one vote one value. It was not until 1974 in that historic Joint Sitting of the Australian Parliament that the principle of one vote one value became part of the law of the Commonwealth but, of course, not a part of the Commonwealth Constitution.

I urge honourable members to look at what other members said in the course of that debate because there were some fine and principled speeches. But indeed, there were also some speeches which brought no credit to the members who opposed that principle. One of the best speeches of principle was made not by a Labor member but by the then Senator Steele Hall, who is now a member of this House. He said-and he was quite right then as he is quite right now-that one of the tragedies of the non-Labor side of politics in Australia was that it almost invariably stood against the extension of the franchise to the fullest. He said.
It is incredible to me that the Liberal Party, at least, can stand against the full implementation of this Bill.

He made some other important points which the House should be reminded of today. He challenged the grubby assertion that somehow country people were inferior and that somehow we had to make some special condescending allocation of greater electoral voting power to country people. Senator Steele Hall said that that view had `drawn the countryside down to a position where it had been ridiculed by democrats'. I say to all those people in the towns and on the farms around Australia, `You are equal Australians and you should have the same equality of voting as all other Australians have.'

I mentioned that the Government, under the leadership of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), had established the Constitutional Commission to promote constitutional reform. The Attorney-General did that because he was committed to the view that the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia is not the plaything of politicians; it is a document for the people. The Constitutional Commission was made up of eminent Australians from all walks of life; people who were not stooges of the Government, but people whose commitment to the principles of constitutional reform transcended party politics. They included Sir Maurice Byers, the former Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, Professor Enid Campbell, Sir Rupert Hamer, the former Liberal Premier of Victoria, Sir Leslie Zines and, before his appointment to the High Court, the then Mr Justice Toohey. There was a special advisory committee on individual and democratic rights which included such diverse people as Thomas Keneally and Peter Garrett. All those people from all walks of life said that the principle of one vote one value was so fundamental to our democracy that no State government, Liberal or Labor, should ever again be allowed to trifle with that principle. Therefore there should be a special section inserted in the Constitution to assert that principle.

The track record of electoral reform in the States is nothing less than shameful. I admit that we in the Australian Labor Party have an enormous cross to bear for our role in some of those shabby initiatives in years gone by. But all that has changed because in New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria and of course at the Federal level there have been reforms to ensure that one vote one value is inserted into the laws of those States. But in Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia and the Northern Territory the electoral systems are just so unfair. Nowhere is the principle of one vote one value guaranteed and I had hoped in the course of my remarks to explain the enormous disparities in the size of electorates, but time does not permit. I think we all understand from our knowledge just how corrupt the system is in those States.

It is not just the people of Australia who are making judgments about the integrity of the Opposition on this question, it is also the major editorial writers of this country. The Sydney Morning Herald has already accused Mr Howard of blatantly appealing to the fears and sensitivities of the smaller States and condemned him for his stand. The Australian newspaper has done likewise and described the shadow Attorney-General's contribution as setting the tone for the Opposition's approach to the question, saying that its campaign is based on superficiality and misinformation. The former Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, described it as snakelike in its approach to these important questions.

My time has ended. I could talk for much longer on such a fundamental principle, but let me return to the essential theme of my contribution to this debate: the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia is the people's Constitution. It is not the plaything of a politician. It is time that the people of Australia took away powers from the politicians and ensured for all time the principle of one vote one value as a basic principle of Australian democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly acknowledge the sincerity of the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I noted that he referred very cautiously to my father's involvement with the 1959 Constitutional Review Committee, which included no less a light than Gough Whitlam. The honourable member said that my father had a sense of fairness, as apparently did other members of that Committee, and I am sure they did. Of course, this is the nub of the whole debate. It is not that people on this side of the House, or people like my father or whoever they may have been, do not support the principle of fairness. Of course we support the principle of fair and democratic elections. It is a question of how one defines fair and democratic elections.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am going to explore this morning in this debate is that the proposal in referendum question No. 2 that is being put by the Australian Labor Party does not constitute fair and democratic elections. That is, frankly, the rich irony of this debate. The honourable member for Hughes is a sincere man, but he has been trapped by the rhetoric of his own Party to support something that does not actually create a fair and democratic electoral system, as he would apparently like.

When we look at this whole issue, I suppose we have to start by trying to define what is fair. Is it fair for the Commonwealth or for the Commonwealth Constitution to tell the States how to run their electoral systems? Is it fair that some constituents can just walk down the road and see their member of parliament and some have to travel 500 or 600 kilometres? Is it fair that some minorities have special places allocated for them in parliaments, as do the Maoris in New Zealand for example? Is it fair that some special provision is made for, say, rural people in some parliaments or metropolitan people of certain kinds in some parliaments? These are open questions. I am not giving honourable members an answer to those questions, but I am saying that there is a substantial body of debate about what the meaning of fairness really is.

Let me tell the House something initially about what is not fair. It is not fair to put a question to the Australian public claiming that if referendum question No. 2 is approved we will then have fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. According to the Government's own Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Act, that is not what the question is about. If honourable members actually read the Act they will see that there is no mention of the phrase `to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia'. So that is the first point.

If the Government believes in fairness, why not ask a fair question that actually reflects what the referendum is about? It provides for 13 new clauses to be added to the Constitution and deletes five clauses. It ignores the so-called principle of one vote one value-with a 20 per cent tolerance, by the way, which does somewhat undermine, I would have thought, the purity of the principle-by omitting the Senate. It omits some provisions in the Federal Constitution in relation to the House of Representatives. In effect, it applies only to the States. So it is not what it appears to be. As I have said, it is fundamentally not a fair question.

The question is aimed at the State of Queensland, where the Government says the electoral boundaries are not fair. I happen to think that that is basically right, but let me say that the Queensland electoral boundaries under this constitutional provision would not have to be changed for 12 months and, even if this question is carried, it will not affect those boundaries at the next Queensland election. So the raison d'etre of the legislation certainly, at least in the short term, loses its basic meaning.

I will come back to the basic theme of my speech, which is the question of what is fair. Let us look at those States that the honourable member opposite referred to which have written into their Constitutions one vote one value to see whether their elections, by some definitions, are fair. They are fair if the only definition of an electoral outcome is that every electorate is of approximately the same size. Perhaps if we were to take the argument to its logical conclusion, every electorate would have to be of exactly the same size, and that is not the provision in their constitutions. But are they fair in other ways?

In my State of South Australia, to win the next election the Liberal Party will need to get 52.2 per cent of the two-party preferred vote and the Labor Party 47.8 per cent. Is that fair? In Victoria the Liberal Party will need to get 51.3 per cent and the Labor Party 48.7 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Is that fair? In New South Wales at the last State election, with boundaries organised under a State Labor government, the Liberals had to get 52.5 per cent and Labor 47.5 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Is that fair? Yet the Government has the principle of one vote one value. Fairness is perhaps in the eyes of the beholder, but I do not think those electoral systems in terms of electoral outcomes are, as it happens, fair.

Federally we have the principle, if you like, of one vote one value, but with a tolerance. Is that fair? Is it fair that the Liberal and National parties got more votes in the last election than did the Labor Party? More people wanted the Liberal and National parties to form a government than wanted the Labor Party, but we actually lost four seats. Is that fair? Let me tell honourable members what happened in South Australia: Labor got 41.39 per cent of the primary vote and the Liberal and National parties got 41.78 per cent-slightly more, but let us say the same. At the time of the last election-we have won one seat since in a by-election-we held five seats and Labor won eight seats. Is that fair? Is that reasonable? Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, I know in your heart you agree with me that that is not fair. The Labor Party, in any case, does not really support--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the honourable member would not impute motives to the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you nodded; that is your decision, not mine. The Labor Party does not support its own case. First of all, I have made the point that the Government, in its referendum question, proposes a 20 per cent tolerance. Why? If it thinks the fundamental principle is that every vote should be of identical value, surely it would not provide for a 20 per cent tolerance? So the Government logically does not quite support its own argument anyway. Secondly, apparently the Government supports the continuation of each State returning 12 senators to the Senate. The reason the Government supports that is that it thinks it is fair, presumably, that the smaller States have disproportionate representation in the Senate so that minorities are not ignored and so that South Australians, Western Australians, Tasmanians and Queenslanders do not have their whole lives ruled by people who come from Sydney and Melbourne. A lot of people think that the rights of minorities-I know honourable members opposite talk a lot about this matter with great sincerity-are important. They are important and that is why that provision exists in the Constitution: to protect the rights of minorities. As a matter of fact, I think that to protect the rights of minorities is fair.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the Deputy Speaker agrees with me. Tasmania has five seats because of the constitutional provision that every State must have a minimum of five House of Representatives seats. The Government apparently supports that. There is no attempt to change that in the Constitution. Somehow the Government does not really support what it talks about. In the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) the Government at one stage introduced a Bill to set up an electoral system called the d'Hondt electoral system which was not consistent with its Act-with its so- called one vote one value referendum proposal. The Government announced yesterday that it would set up the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission whose commissioners will be elected. But guess what? The votes of some electors in some of the regions will be worth twice the value of others. That is the Labor Party's proposal. It is simply not consistent. The Government is singling out only the States with this referendum proposal and it ignores the Commonwealth, it ignores ACT elections and, as it happens, it ignores the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Honourable members opposite are saying, `We, the Federal Parliament, are going to tell the States how to run their own parliaments'. Is it fair that we, in this House which is dominated by Sydney and Melbourne, should tell South Australians how to run the election for their Parliament? If they are not able to make that sort of decision it makes a mockery of their Parliament. Is it fair? That indeed is the basic question. The one vote one value constitutional proposal that the Government has put forward is not fair.

My time has run out but the final point I make is that throughout the democratic world there is a whole range of different electoral arrangements, particularly in respect of upper Houses, to protect minorities. They do not implement the principle of one vote one value. We do that in our Senate. The New Zealanders, in their lower House, do this for the Maori indigenous population. It happens in a whole range of other countries as well. It depends on how one defines fairness. I think it is fair to protect the rights of minorities as well as to ensure that we have proper democratic elections. In conclusion, if the Government supports the principles of fairness in this referendum proposal, why does it not ask a fair question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out two fundamental flaws in the arguments put forward to the House by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer).
—Only two?

—I will pick out two and leave the others for another day. First, on several occasions he said that the constitutional referendum will enshrine in the Constitution a tolerance of plus or minus 20 per cent. He simply has not bothered to read the background to the referendum. The referendum will not put in a tolerance of plus or minus 20 per cent; it will put in a tolerance of plus or minus 10 per cent-the current tolerance provided for in the Commonwealth Electoral Act.
—Twenty per cent.

—The honourable member for Mayo interjects and says that is a total of 20 per cent if one adds 10 and 10. But throughout his speech he kept referring to a tolerance of plus or minus 20 per cent, which is the tolerance that this Parliament abolished in 1974. He is at least 14 years behind the times. The second fundamental flaw in his argument is his suggestion that this referendum is aimed solely at the States, and that it is unfair of this Parliament to be attacking the States by enshrining a one vote one value system for the States only. He is wrong again. At the moment we simply have an Act of this Parliament which establishes our tolerance of plus or minus 10 per cent. As I said previously, before 1974 the tolerance was greater than that. It was a disgrace that there were electorates, particularly that of Grayndler, which were discriminated against for many years. There was great divergence between the numbers of electors to the House of Representatives before 1974 yet if, at some stage in the future, some government has control of both Houses, it could pass legislation which could increase the tolerance from the current level of plus or minus 10 per cent simply by getting a Bill through both Houses of this Parliament. In this referendum which will be put to the people on Saturday week we need to enshrine in our Federal Constitution a maximum tolerance of plus or minus 10 per cent so that if, by some chance of fate, the Liberal and National parties obtain a majority in both Houses in the future, it will not be possible for them to return to the dark days when they had massive rural weightings to give special advantage to the National Party rump.

SPEECH.PARA: As for his suggestion that this referendum is aimed only at Queensland, I invite the honourable member for Mayo to look at the electoral system in Western Australia-an electoral system which remains rorted because the Liberal Party in Western Australia blocks sensible proposals in the Western Australian upper House. Today there are members elected to the Western Australian Legislative Assembly whose electorates have more than 100,000 electors; other members of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly with an equal vote have electorates with less than 10,000 electors-a difference of more than 10 to one. This means that when some people voted for the Western Australian Legislative Assembly at the last election their voting power was 10 times larger than that of city voters. I would have thought that Liberals and Democrats would see this as abhorrent. Yet when one looks at what has happened in the Western Australian Parliament, one sees that the National Party and the Liberal Party, at every turn, have sought to block the Western Australian Labor Government's attempts to bring in a one vote one value system. What alternative do we have but to allow the national Government, the national Parliament, through the referendum which was provided for in our Constitution, to establish a national standard of one vote one value throughout all Federal and State parliaments.

I point out that the establishment of one vote one value is the continuation of a trend which has continued in Western parliaments for many years. If one looks back to the great reform Acts in the 1800s in the British Parliament, one sees that people have been campaigning for many years to extend the right to vote to every citizen and also to ensure that redistributions are carried out regularly so that people are fairly elected and fairly represented. The test is that if a majority of the people vote for a particular party, then that party should be elected to form the government. That is not the case in some States in Australia today. It is certainly not the case in Queensland. Because there is not a one vote one value system in Western Australia it is not the case there either. I believe that Australia has had a proud history of electoral reform throughout the years, particularly in the 1800s. We introduced the secret ballot, universal suffrage and, in many ways, Australia led--

TALK.START.PARA: —Votes for women.

—We were first with votes for women, as the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business suggests. We have led the way in many of these areas. Because there are very few genuine and healthy democracies functioning in the world today, we have to make sure that at no stage in the future can some government with questionable principles seek to water down our commitment to democratic government. In 1974 this Parliament, at a joint sitting, carried an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which sets the current permissible tolerance of plus or minus 10 per cent. Currently the parliaments of South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria also provide for one vote one value. Tasmania also has one vote one value because the State electorates are based on the five Federal electorates. Yet in Western Australia while there has been some improvement after recent reforms there is still a difference of two to one in the Western Australian Legislative Assembly. Rural voters have twice the voting power of those in the city. That simply does not allow the majority of the people to elect a government.
