SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the first referendum question regarding 4-year parliamentary terms does not guarantee 4 years between elections and will weaken the independence of the Senate.
This question, which will be put to the Australian people on 3 September, at first reading seems rather innocuous. It asks voters whether they approve of a law:
To alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

However, the consequences of passing this will be far-reaching indeed because it will make the Senate little more than a mirror image of the lower House. I say to the Australian people that if we do this we might as well abolish the Senate altogether. In fact, the whole referendum is misleading and deceptive in itself. I wonder whether the Australian people realise that if they vote Yes for four questions come 3 September, which is only a little more than a week away now, they will be changing 33 sections of our Constitution. They will be repealing nine sections, including 20 new ones, and modifying four others. Thirty-three sections will be changed. I remind the Australian people that they have changed only eight sections of the Constitution in the 87 years since Federation. In other words, we are being asked to make many more changes in one day than we have made in the previous 87 years.

The first question in particular is nothing more than a sugar coated proposition. If the question were honestly asked, people would vote overwhelmingly No because what they are, in fact, being asked to vote on in this question is not just to increase the maximum term of the House of Representatives from three years to four years, which I guess most of us would agree with, but to do other things. They are being asked to reduce the term of the Senate from six years to four years, to abolish fixed terms in the Senate; and to abolish the system of rotation in the Senate. These are quite major and far-reaching changes. In fact, question No. 1, which is the most important of the four questions to be asked, is designed to emasculate the Senate and to make it a feeble appendage of the House of Representatives. Of course, the Labor Government has long had a hatred for the Senate. Senator Gareth Evans said, as far back as July 1978, that the Senate `ought to be abolished'. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself said soon after he was elected Prime Minister:

I've had enough of this recalcitrant Senate blocking the will of the Government. I'm not going to be in a situation . . . where we are dictated to as the democratically elected Government by the mishmash of opposing forces in this country. If they think they can determine the pattern of the Government, then they have got another think coming.
Previous to that, the Prime Minister also said in his Boyer Lectures in 1979:

I believe the logical implication is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of Government-i.e. the States which no longer serve their original purpose and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government.
Of course, the Senate is the States House. Even the Governor-General designate, heaven help us, Mr Hayden said in August 1980:
The Labor Party is committed to its-
the Senate's-
eventual elimination.

That is the Government's track record. Here we are in 1988 with a referendum question that will be put to the Australian people in a deceptive way. A Yes vote will have the effect of emasculating or gutting the Senate. I remind the people that a weaker Senate will lead to a weaker federal system in Australia because federalism has proved to have been the best form of government for Australia with its vast areas and small population. I might add that the question the Government is putting ignores the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission that the Government itself set up and on which it spent $6m of taxpayers' money. One could well ask why the Government ignored the recommendations of its own Constitutional Commission. The Constitutional Commission wanted to maintain the system of rotation of senators in this country. But the Government has swept that away. It is trying to pretend that it is a recommendation of the Constitutional Commission. I can say quite emphatically that it is not.

In this country the Senate has been a House of review. It has done that job very well. It has done that because it has a degree of independence from the House of Representatives. The founding fathers who drew up our Constitution at the turn of the century deliberately put into the Constitution this degree of independence for the Senate, which is now proposed to be taken away on 3 September. The Senate will change from playing the role of a watchdog to playing the role of a lap-dog if this proposal goes through. There are many consequences that will flow from it. Even the valuable committee work that the Senate does will cease for three or four months every time an election is called. The present federal parliamentary system would never have come into existence without the guarantee of a strong States House as part of our parliamentary system. However, if this question is passed on 3 September the Senate will become merely a rubber stamp for what the lower House passes. I remind honourable members that no legislation is introduced into the lower House without the government of the day having first considered whether it will be passed by the Senate. All legislation that is presented to the House of Representatives is conditioned and tempered by this reality. It will be a great shame indeed if that check and balance is done away with.

I would like now to address the proposition that the Government is putting that a Yes vote will lead to fewer elections. There is indeed no such guarantee. All that is being proposed is that the lower House have a maximum term of four years which, as I said earlier, goes against the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission which said that the term of the lower House should at least be a minimum of three years. The Senate term which has been fixed at six years is proposed to be reduced to a maximum of four years. In other words, the term of the Senate will not now be fixed and senators could find themselves going to the people within terms of much less than four years, if it is the whim of the Government to do so. The Senate will always go out to election with the House of Representatives. In other words, every election that this country has from now on will mean a double dissolution if the proposition is passed.

Let us not forget that in the past we have had some very short terms indeed. I think that one of the shortest was back in 1929 when the government of the day went to the people seven months after it first sat. It will be ridiculous indeed if we have all the Senate going to the people after a term of only seven months. That has not been allowed in the past. Even in 1963 the Government went to the people in a period of less than two years. The narrow majority of the coalition Government at that time made it difficult to govern. It does not take much imagination to see that when governments are elected with majorities of one, two or three in the lower House, or with similarly low numbers, they will want to go to the people quite early. Now governments can go and take the Senate with them. If they gain a majority in the lower House, they will most likely gain the same majority in the upper House and have the Senate merely as a mirror of the lower House.

A further question that is worth asking is: Why is this referendum being rushed through in the way it is? It is costing $35m, for heaven's sake, and it could have waited until the next election. But, no, the Government has to rush it through and give the Australian people only three months to consider it. The Bill was even guillotined through and we did not have a chance to debate it. Now it will be put to the people a little more than a week after the Budget, when the referendum is not being much discussed in the media. If we had another three months to discuss the matter and the Australian people could realise for the first time what is proposed in these questions, then I think that these proposals, in common with the ID card, would be overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian people. It seems that the only people who support these proposals are Labor politicians, who have a particular hatred of the Senate and of State parliaments.

If the Australian people value our bicameral system of parliamentary democracy, if they value the independence of the Senate, which they have reaffirmed in previous referendums on the Constitution, and if they value the Senate as a House of review, they have no choice but to reject these proposed major changes to our parliamentary system which are being disguised in the misleading words of this question and other questions to be put on 3 September. I hope that people will vote a resounding `No' to question 1 and to the other three propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. The central thrust of the argument by my colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is that with this first referendum question, as with the other three questions, there is much more to it than meets the eye. Does this House and do the Australian people realise that these four seemingly simple questions involve 33 changes to the Constitution? One must read the fine print, as opposed to the bland and deceptive formulation of the questions on the ballot paper. For example, question 2 asks: Do you approve of fair and democratic elections in Australia? Who could say that they do not believe in such a concept? But that is not what that question is all about. What the people are actually being asked to vote on is the Act of Parliament that set up that referendum. In that Act there is no use of the words `fair and democratic elections'.
—It is a blatant fraud.

—It is a blatant fraud. That second question is all about 13 other changes to the Constitution. I challenge anybody here to tell me what those 13-plus changes are, but that is what people are being asked to vote on. The same argument applies to the question with which we are now dealing. It underlines the fact that the whole exercise is misleading. It is deceptive, and indeed fraudulent-when one considers that the Government was engaging in illegal advertising, as has been declared by the Court. The pamphlet sets out the word `Yes' in great letters, and `No' in very tiny letters. Also look at what this is all costing. The Government went through a lot of electoral pain in the May mini-Budget to cut road funding by $50m. In that context the Government has spent $6m on a Commission and is spending some $35m, over $40m all told, on these referendum questions. It has cut road funding by $50m, money which local government authorities particularly need, but is to spend $40m on this whole exercise.
—It demonstrates their priorities.

—Yes, and it also demonstrates that there has to be a secret agenda, or the Government would not be pursuing this exercise. There has to be a secret agenda, a hidden meaning and a hidden purpose. And indeed, there is a secret agenda, a hidden purpose, in all these questions, but particularly that which we are now debating. This question, in common with the other three questions, is all about concentrating more power in Canberra's hands-giving more power to the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. It is all about cutting back the power of the Senate. It will give to the Government power to introduce the ID card-put people's faces on ID cards-or the power to pass a raft of other measures which a strong Senate over the past five years has been able to hold at bay.

SPEECH.PARA: Question 1 on the face of it asks whether people approve of a maximum four-year term for the Parliament, with the expectation that there will be fewer elections. I very much doubt whether it will lead to fewer elections, but I shall not enlarge on that point. That is only one question but, as with all the other referendum questions, other and even more important questions are involved. It is asking as a separate additional question: Is every election to consist of a double dissolution?-that will be the effect of it. It involves maximum concurrent-underline that-four-year terms for the House of Representatives and the Senate. So if the Prime Minister takes out the House, he takes out the Senate as well and there is then in effect a double dissolution. This is all about reducing the term of the Senate, which the Constitution now provides should be six years, or twice the term of the House of Representatives. Are people aware they are really being asked whether they approve of reducing the term of the Senate from the six years as provided by the founding fathers, with a rotation of senators to ensure continuity and independence? Are people aware that they are being asked to reduce that term from six years to whatever the term of the House of Representatives turns out to be?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are conning the people.

—It is conning the people. The whole exercise is misleading and deceptive and the Australian people have to realise just what it is all about and give a firm and resounding `No' to the question we are discussing. I sincerely enjoin them to vote a firm and resounding `No' to the other three questions also. The fourth question asks: Do you approve of extending the right to trial by jury, freedom of religion and fair compensation for property acquired? Who would oppose those? They happen to be freedoms we already have. What the people are being asked to approve-if they closely examine the small print, where again one sees the deceit and the dishonesty-is in the question regarding freedom of religion, for instance, a proposal to change the existing section 116 from `The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing a religion . . .' to `The Commonwealth shall not establish any religion . . .'

SPEECH.PARA: It leaves out four words-`make any law for'. A whole lot of things are put at risk by the deletion of those words-such as government assistance to denominational schools, which some people might support but not the majority of Australians, and government assistance to church-run hospitals or other institutions. Because it would in effect introduce into our Constitution the sort of situation that prevails under the United States Constitution, it would put at risk the saying of prayers or any form of religious observance in state schools. Do the people of Australia want that to happen? Do they want these things to be put at risk? That is why this whole proposal is so misleading and deceptive. The people are being asked to say whether they approve of extending the right to trial by jury, freedom of religion, and fair compensation-things one might think one could not possibly disagree with, but the fine print suggests otherwise. In fact we would be restricting freedom of religion as we know it today in this country, to a significant degree. So to that question also, question 4, I urge the people to vote no.

If I had further time I would be urging the Australian people to vote no to all four questions because there are hidden meanings and risks in them. There is a secret agenda, there has to be a secret agenda with the Government spending all this money. I urge the Australian people to vote no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) got it half right. He indicated that our referendum proposition does not guarantee four-year parliamentary terms. That is absolutely correct; but we never promised that. We seek to guarantee only that there will be fewer elections, not set four-year terms. He was quite wrong on the second point, though, that the proposition will weaken the independence of the Senate. The powers of the Senate will be absolutely untouched. The alternatives the Opposition has put up are either that we have a fixed term parliament or that there be eight-year terms for senators. The problem with the notion of fixed term parliaments is that that itself would deny the Senate the power to block supply. It would absolutely neuter the power of the Senate. As for increasing the term of a senator to eight years, that is simply unacceptable. Having a senator sit in the Parliament for eight years would be like a lifelong sentence. Senators would be unaccountable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's whole proposition is that we should have fewer elections. The notion is that when this proposition is passed the maximum term of the House of Representatives will be extended from three to four years, beginning with the next Parliament. In addition, the terms of all senators would finish upon the expiry of the term of the House of Representatives. So, yes, we do want to put the two Houses in unison. That does not affect the power of the Senate, but it does take both Houses out at the same time. It will provide greater stability in the system by reducing the frequency of elections and ensuring that both Houses of Parliament are accountable to the people for their actions.

There can be no doubt we have had too many elections since World War II. Since 1945 we have been to the polls, on average, less than every two years. The cost of that is unacceptable. There is also no doubt that because we have such frequent elections there is uncertainty in the decision-making of the Government. It means that in a normal three-year term there is only one real Budget. The first Budget is to turn around the mistakes of the previous Government, the second is the real one, and the third is the sweetener before the election. We all understand that; we are all mature enough to know that in a three-year term there is only one opportunity to bring down a proper Budget. At least if we move to four-year terms we can get two decent Budgets out of any given government. Groups such as the business community are very keen on the notion of a four-year term, which we do not guarantee. We understand that. But if we introduced a guaranteed four-year term, there would go the power of the Senate. We can have it one way or the other, not both.

The need for longer terms could not be more obvious. It is not a novel idea. The fact is that every parliament in Australia-except Queensland, of course-has four-year terms. It is hardly a shocking revelation. Four-year terms are the norm in Australian parliaments. Think of the effect if this proposition is passed. A Prime Minister would have to justify a decision to call an election ahead of schedule. In general the justification has been either that the Houses of Parliament are running out of kilter, as is currently the case, or that the Senate has blocked legislation. This referendum proposal will remove the Prime Minister's excuse for calling an early election simply because the two Houses run on different schedules. That happened in 1977 and 1984. That excuse will no longer hold because the two Houses will always come out together.

Our opponents have claimed that the four-year term will somehow rob the Senate of its powers and therefore weaken the States' powers in favour of the Commonwealth. That is absolute nonsense. The Senate's present power to reject, amend or block legislation-including Supply Bills, the lifeblood of any government-will remain absolutely untouched. If a government is forced to an election through either the blocking of Supply or the rejecting of important legislation for which the government believes it has a mandate, the people will decide the issue. If the electorate supports the stand taken by the Senate on any legislation the government can be thrown out of office. Senators will become more accountable for their actions in the Parliament. It has been claimed by some that the Senate would be given even more power by our referendum proposal as it would be able to claim a mandate as a result of its being elected at the same time as the government. At the same time, the Senate will lose none of its present power to function as an efficient House of review.

The suggestion that senators presently enjoy some form of fixed term ignores the experience of the last 20 years. The last senators to serve a full six-year term in the Senate were elected in 1965. The proposal in regard to the terms of senators will therefore bring the Constitution into line with the real practice of the last 20 years. It is also worth remembering that over this same 20 years, during which time not one full Senate term has been served, there has been a most dramatic increase in the Senate's powers. This makes nonsense of the claim that only a Senate serving its full, fixed term can exercise any real power.

There are only two alternatives to the proposed parliamentary system instigated by this referendum. The first is to fix parliamentary terms and the other is to enable eight-year terms for senators. Does anyone really believe that the Australian people would support an eight-year term for any politician? It would mean that after one term a person could walk out with a pension for life. Politicians would be unaccountable and remote. It would be undemocratic. Believe me, there are many senators on our side who simply would not cop that. I do not understand why Opposition senators seek for themselves an eight-year untouchable term.

Let us forget this whole business that the Senate is somehow a States House. Senators get into Parliament because they are placed high on a party ticket. That is the only reason they are elected to the Senate. The reality is that since the end of World War II, and perhaps even before that, the Senate has divided on party lines. The vast majority of senators are bound by party room decisions before they even walk into the Senate chamber. So why not have all senators free to face the people at the same time as members of the House of Representatives? It is an easily understandable proposition; both Houses can be accountable at the same time.

The problem with the notion of a fixed term to increase parliamentary terms is that the Senate's power to block Supply would be removed. If senators had to wait until their full four-year term expired, what would be the purpose of seeking to block Supply, of placing pressure on the Government or of amending legislation? It is the Opposition's proposition that would neuter the Senate. Our proposition leaves it untouched. It has all of its powers. We do not seek to amend in any way the powers of the Senate. In framing the question on four-year parliamentary terms the Government was acutely aware that any proposal that sought to reduce the powers and independence of the Senate was unlikely to succeed.

Australians are clearly fed up with having too many elections. The business community has long been after the stability and certainty that comes with four-year terms. Nobody would suggest that the community wants governments which cannot be removed if they are doing a bad job. The proposal for four-year parliamentary terms, which will be decided on 3 September, meets all the concerns of Australians and the needs of the community and does so without threatening the powers and independence of the Senate. The question does no more than offer enhanced rights to the Australian people in regard to their elected representatives. I cannot and I will not support the proposition put forward by the honourable member for Parkes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises the impact of the EEC and the US farm subsidies upon the viability of the efficient Australian wheat industry;
(2) acknowledges the contribution made to Australia's export earnings by primary industry; and
(3) accepts an urgency to address the alarming increase in rural poverty.

This House should be aware that rural Australia, particularly those regions involved in broad acre grain production, in recent years has suffered the worst economic conditions in the history of agricultural development. This has been brought about by a combination of low commodity prices, corrupt world trading conditions and, most importantly, domestic policies that have imposed massive costs such as record interest rates and fuel prices, together with social policies, at the forefront of these being the assets test that has discriminated against people requiring the asset of land to earn income.

It is in this environment, therefore, that this Parliament will be legislating in the autumn session of 1989 for the next five-year wheat marketing scheme to commence on 1 October of that year. These arrangements will follow the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) inquiry. The IAC inquiry basically recommended the extension of the current permit system for domestic stock feed wheat to all wheat and the removal of the Australian Wheat Board's sole stock feed export power as well as the sole domestic power for wheat for human consumption.

It should be noted by this House that there is no free international or domestic wheat market. All the major world trading countries, with the exception of Argentina, operate some form of regulation designed to protect grower returns and ensure supply to consumers. Furthermore, lower world wheat plantings, particularly in Australia, are not a free market response. They are a response to other governments in terms of how much the United States or the European Economic Community (EEC) is helping its farmers to break into the world trade.

The support received by Australian farmers is negligible in comparison with that received by wheat farmers from Europe and North America. Underwriting payments incurred by the Commonwealth for 1986-87-and I remind the House that this has been the only payment from these wheat arrangements for 15 years-will be approximately $170m. This includes $47m of interest payments that have been incurred by the Australian Wheat Board on borrowings which would have been avoided if this Government had paid its underwriting commitment earlier. Of course, such support is a once only benefit of approximately $US9 a tonne in assistance to the Australian wheat grower.

I wish to mention some of the corrupt support mechanisms that operate, particularly in the United States of America. The United States Federal intervention has evolved largely in the past 25 years. These arrangements enable farm policy to be directed towards objectives in three major areas: through price support, through supply control and the loan program; through income support by deficiency payments to United States farmers; and, finally, through export promotion with the use of credit instruments and subsidies.

The object of the EEC's pricing system is to support returns to producers. To do this for grain producers, intervention, target and threshold prices are set, with each being related to a particular geographic location. The intervention price is the price at which intervention agencies are obliged to buy grain. It provides a floor below which theoretically market prices should not fall. I repeat that the arrangements we have in Australia have provided a benefit of only $9 a tonne to Australian wheat growers. By comparison, EEC growers receive assistance of $US83 a tonne subsidy and US growers receive nearly $70 a tonne subsidy through their arrangements. Canadian wheat growers have received some $3 billion in price support over a short period.

The stature and resilience of the Australian wheat industry, despite these corrupt world policies, indicate our industry's efficiency and indicate its capacity to respond to changing production and economic circumstances. Central to this is the history of stability of past wheat marketing arrangements and the successful operation of the Australian Wheat Board. On any criteria we wish to put on the Australian Wheat Board's operations, it comes out as being seen as highly effective. It has been extremely effective in the marketing area. This has been proved in the last few years when we have sold crops in extremely difficult trading circumstances. One recent example is the Australian Wheat Board's ability to increase sales to our near neighbour Indonesia from a base of some 439,000 tonnes in 1983 to over 700,000 tonnes last year.

The Wheat Board has been successful in ensuring that Australian wheat growers are exposed to market signals. Anyone who knows of the rapid change and diversity that have taken place in Australia's broad acre farming areas in the last few years will recognise that farmers are aware of the market signals and have responded very rapidly to them. The Wheat Board's arrangements ensure that growers are rewarded for quality and that the quality of the Australian crop is maintained. This has been a vital factor, given the difficult world trading environment, in ensuring that we have been able to maintain and expand sales, because we do have consistent quality and we can ensure hygiene.

More importantly, the Wheat Board has been very successful in ensuring stability and equity between growers. The Australian wheat industry has 40,000 growers, of whom 95 per cent are family farmers. The present arrangements, after adjustment for different freight and handling costs, ensure that growers receive the same guaranteed price-I emphasise the words `guaranteed price'-irrespective of any property's geographical location, so long as that grain is of the same quality and type.

In saying this and expanding on the importance of the Australian Wheat Board, I point out that the industry does have a progressive outlook to marketing conditions. There is no doubt that the Board's marketing powers can be strengthened to allow greater commercial flexibility. This would apply particularly to allow the Wheat Board to offer other grain throughout the world to assist wheat sales. It is almost mandatory that the $16 per tonne fixed charge be replaced for direct grower to buyer sales with the actual cost of those transactions. This will encourage a greater percentage of wheat for human consumption to be sold by growers direct to flour mills. I believe that the industry should ensure that the Board is committed to compete more effectively in the open domestic stockfeed market by offering a cash price, so creating greater price stability in that market.

Of course, we could remove the requirement for the Board to store wheat with only the State bulk handling authorities. This would allow the Board to negotiate commercial contracts with State bulk handling authorities to disaggregate costs and so allow considerable flexibility or deregulatory initiatives in domestic markets and cost allocation. I remind the House that all these changes to the Board to make it more commercially effective can take place while still retaining the AWB's sole domestic and exporting powers. Central to this is also retaining an underwriting scheme that will cushion the effects of a corrupt world market and the destabilising nature of fluctuating wheat prices and subsidies.

I am convinced that if the domestic market is deregulated-as I understand a large percentage of Government members seek to do-domestic market prices will fall to, at best, average export returns initially set by the weakest seller, with no commensurate price reduction to the consumer. It is important to note that the flour component in a loaf of bread retailing at 90c to $1.20 is worth only 7c, so even a significant shift in the price of grain would not substantially affect bread prices for the consumer. In fact, domestic prices could even drop to the levels offered in markets which are affected by the United States export enhancement program (EEP). The effect of this would be for Australian wheat to suffer further the effects of subsidised grain exports, this time on the domestic market where the current arrangements have quarantined the Australian market from the harmful effects of EEP. I believe that such a change and such deregulation would almost certainly see the loss of $35m to $50m to Australian grain producers in a single season.

By far the most significant and important area for debate in relation to the future of the Australian wheat industry and its growers is the report of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. The grain producers of Australia have been plundered over the years by the greed of governments through excessive freight and taxation charges and by inefficiencies in handling and storage, brought on and aggravated by restrictive work practices and industrial blackmail. The real advantages and cost savings to the wheat industry can be gained for growers and consumers by the partial implementation of the Royal Commission's proposals on transport, storage and handling. Over the last few months this Government has been very generous to the influence and power of big business and it must here resist the powerful agribusiness lobby which, while it has a legitimate right to pursue its commercial interest, does not have a legitimate right to bring about a situation in which Australian farmers who own their own wheat and who have to operate in a high cost domestic economy have their marketing and pricing policies determined by people outside the industry.

The Australian Wheat Board has shown its capacity to maximise returns while maintaining equity for growers and a high standard of quality and hygiene. Opponents of the present system will need more than a theoretical or philosophical argument to convince me, and the Australian wheat industry, that the destruction of the present system is warranted. The Royal Commissioner, Mr Jim McColl, in his report has clearly indicated that the implementation of his recommendations for greater efficiency and accountability in grain handling and storage and at the waterfront will not be affected by changes to the Australian Wheat Board or private traders being allowed to control the domestic market.

The wheat growers of Australia are some of the most efficient producers of any product in our country. They provide Australian consumers with high quality and cheap grain. They should not be required to accept a lower price for what they sell in Australia-in other words, below import parity-than is required of any other Australian, no matter what he produces. I remind the House that most Australians are protected by a regulated and indexed wage structure. The Royal Commission recommendations to improve the efficiency of handling, transport and port facilities will not be affected by deregulation. Actions taken by State and Federal governments are important and these proposals, together with amended domestic selling arrangements, constitute considerable change and challenge to the industry. Federal deregulation will not succeed: enough of the States will use their acquisition and price powers to thwart the move. This could actually lead in some cases to greater regulation and to the replacement of a uniform national wheat market with a confused mess. We must not allow the Australian Wheat Board to be used as a scapegoat for the tardiness of State or Federal governments effectively to move into this area and to deal with the rorts in transport, handling and storage.

Time does not allow me fully to explain or canvass the extent of the third part of my motion, which deals with rural poverty. I simply say that despite increases in commodity prices, from a very low base, rural poverty continues to increase. In rural Australia at the moment we are seeing a massive movement of young people from the land to the metropolitan areas. Paradoxically, combined with this is a significant movement of retired people, homeless people and social security recipients into rural Australia in search of low cost housing and services. The implication of these demographic changes should be obvious and so indeed should be the impact on local government as it struggles in the rural areas to provide services such as health, education and particularly roads as we see a decline in State and Federal funds to these important areas. As rural Australia lifts this nation out of economic debt and attempts to halt the decline in living standards for all Australians, tragically in the Budget on Tuesday night there was a proposal to apply an assets test to Austudy and education allowances. This will ensure that almost no rural children, particularly those from farms or small business, will ever again receive any assistance to further their education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion. As the member for Maranoa I find it a very historic occasion to be standing here making my first speech in the new Parliament House. In seconding the motion I support its mover, the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). I represent in this House most of the wheat growers in Queensland. I do not support the removal of the underwriting which the Government is proposing. I also do not support the total deregulation of the domestic market. The main reason is that the boards throughout Australia, particularly in Queensland, have gone to a lot of trouble to build storage and if they lose some of their throughput they will find it very difficult to pay back interest and redemption costs, which in Queensland amount to some $80m. The facilities were established under the present legislation which allowed the boards to have the total throughput, or at least most of it, of the domestic market. They now find that the Australian Labor Party Government is going to withdraw that from them and put them in a very difficult position in continuing to finance the storage facilities. They were able to get licences to sell feed grain and I continue to support that concept.

SPEECH.PARA: The other problem with freeing up the local market is that the price set will be the world price; it will no longer be the price set with government arrangement. We know how corrupted the world price for grain is due to the subsidisation by various governments-America and the European Community. The world price is always well below the domestic price. We also have to take into account our cost of living and cost of production. In many cases we face the problem of having to pay an exorbitant excise on fuel. We have to remember that half of the fuel used on farms is petrol, not just diesel. We must also understand that wheat is not like sorghum or barley which are used in the feed markets. Very little wheat is used for this purpose. I have much pleasure in supporting the honourable member for Mallee and in seconding this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rising to speak in this debate on the motion moved by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), I would first of all like to acknowledge that the first and second parts of his motion would certainly present no problems in terms of this House supporting them. I think his third proposition could certainly be open to debate. Because of time constraints, I do not believe he had a lot of time to go into this part of his motion. Therefore, I will concentrate a little on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I think everybody in this House recognises that the policies of the European Economic Community (EEC) and the United States of America in regard to their farm subsidies programs are certainly having a detrimental effect on the Australian wheat industry. That point does not need further clarification in this House. I had the privilege of leading an all-party delegation from this Parliament to the US Congress and Senate to impress upon them the importance of the US and the EEC taking into account the damage that their policies were creating in countries such as Australia and Argentina, which are part of a group of nations that was formed to argue a case against the sorts of policies put forward by the EEC and the US. Those policies, which have been in place now for some 30 years, are continuing to distort the markets and the economies of the world in such a way that they are seriously affecting a lot of the agricultural producing countries in terms of their ability to improve the living standards of their people.

Of course, these policies have impacted very severely on the Australian wheat industry. The honourable member for Mallee said that he is seriously concerned about this because his electorate covers a large proportion of the best wheat country in Australia as well as some of the marginal areas. These areas have been seriously impacted because of the downturn in prices created by those policies.

Over the last two or three years the Americans have always put it to us that one of the chief reasons for their export enhancement program was to move surplus stocks so that the market system eventually could work. That has been their argument all along. Now, of course, the serious drought that has occurred in the US will mean that the supply of grain around the world will be seriously depleted. So whilst we have argued very strongly for many years that these policies and approaches have been impacting seriously on us, I can see light at the end of the tunnel. As US stocks are depleted, we can expect that prices will increase dramatically over time.

The honourable member for Mallee argued strongly that we should keep the Australian Wheat Board's regulations. This is a subject of debate in Australia at present. It is one that I am sure that this Government will work through to the satisfaction of all in relation to the wheat industry. We need only look at the evidence of this Government's policies in respect of other industries in Australia which have been reformed and restructured in a deregulated way and are certainly well on the road to recovery. We can see that the policies in the EEC and the US that our National Party friends complain about are clearly the types of policies which they have followed in Australia, which have created a lot of problems for the rural sector over the years. Growers have been given distorted market signals. There is no argument that such policies distort decisions that are made by growers in relation to when and what they should plant. This is one of the real problems of agriculture around the world, which Australia has been putting to the US and the EEC in world forums: that when one has subsidy structures, when distorted economic indicators are given to the farming sector, one gets boom and bust approaches. Whilst I recognise the concerns of the honourable member for Mallee, I think the Party that he represents and the policies that it puts forward are certainly not the ones that would ever overcome the problems in Australia or anywhere in the world, because they are all aimed at that type of subsidy approach to the farming sector.

In the second part of the motion the honourable member says we should acknowledge the contribution made to Australia's export earnings by primary industry. I do not think there is any doubt that this House would very clearly support that position. We have never at any stage argued any other case. Of course, we on this side of the Parliament have argued that the conservatives did not support the agricultural sector effectively as an economic base in Australia over the many years that they had control of the treasury bench. What they sought to do was to create a climate in which many in the rural sector based economic decisions on perhaps tax incentives and subsidies rather than seriously look at the economy of the nation.

The conservatives also allowed Australia to get into a situation where we became totally reliant on the rural and primary industry sectors for our national income. Of course, that neglect by honourable members opposite when they were in government certainly led to the problems that our Government has had to face since 1983. Their very policies led to the serious situation that as soon as commodity prices collapsed, as they did around the world and as they do periodically in about a seven-year cycle, we had a loss of income from our commodity prices at the same time as our manufacturing industry was being decimated by incorrect policies.

The honourable member asks the House to support the rural sector. I believe that the greatest thing that can be done for the rural sector is the establishment of a strong base in our manufacturing sector which supports the total economic base of Australia, which gives the economy the capacity in times of downturn to assist those sectors of the community which are in difficulties. We have certainly set out to do that by restructuring the Australian economy.

Today the quarterly review of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural Resource Economics was released. I shall refer to that report in the context of the third part of the motion that was put forward by the honourable member for Mallee-that we should accept that there is an urgent need to address the alarming increase in rural poverty. Certainly that part of the motion is at least five years too late-perhaps six years too late. I think the people of Australia made the decision to address that problem when they looked at the economics of Australia back in 1979, assessed them in 1980 and changed the Government. They realised at that stage that if the economic policies that we were facing then continued, there was going to be a real problem in terms of an increase in rural poverty. So, in addressing the need for urgency, I think the honourable member for Mallee is five years too late. The people of Australia made that decision. The measures have been put in place. I think I can quite confidently quote from the report of the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. I would like to go through a few of the statements in the report, which clearly put the evidence in perspective. The report states:

The recovery in world commodity prices continues to broaden, with indications that prices of many rural commodities will rise further in 1988-89. The associated strong recovery in the Australian dollar, however, will tend to dampen price increases experienced in Australia. Nonetheless, the gross value of rural production is forecast to rise by 7 per cent to $21,200 in 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —From what base?
—This is from a base which increased last year, of course. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The improved performance of the rural sector in 1987-88 reflects substantial price increases for a number of commodities, while the outlook suggests that others that so far have experienced only small price recoveries are likely to perform better in 1988-89. This is particularly the case for grains and oilseeds, where concerns about possible droughts in the United States and Canada have already created some speculative prices rises. Whether or not these price increases are sustained, or are added to, will of course depend on weather conditions in the Northern Hemisphere over the next few months.

That is a clear indication from the report that there are signs that even the grains industry, which is the only industry that has not fully recovered, is well on the road to recovery. The report continues:

As these revised forecasts were being prepared a number of potentially conflicting developments occurred that create an unusual uncertainty about the outlook for Australian rural commodities. In world markets it is becoming increasingly apparent that stocks have been reduced to the point where markets are very sensitive to adverse weather conditions affecting 1988-89 crops. This is particularly so for oilseeds and to a lesser extent coarse grains, wheat, sugar and cotton. Recent dry conditions for the sowing and early development of spring crops in North America have already created strong, although tentative, price rises.
Let us see what the report has to say about the production side of the rural sector in Australia:
Over the past few years there has been an appreciable change in the mix of rural output . . .

Farmers are making the economic decisions. They are responding to the economy; they are not responding to subsidies and the sorts of measures that were in place under the previous Government. They are responding now to real economics. The report continues:

. . . there has been an appreciable change in the mix of rural output as livestock and wool prices have improved relative to grain prices. Sheep numbers have increased to 165 million and wool production is forecast to reach a record 960 kt in 1988-89. Beef and veal production is forecast to decline slightly from 1987-88 in line with a marginal herd buildup and improved pasture conditions.
This is an indication, once again, that the farmers are making the correct economic decisions for the correct reasons.

Favourable weather in recent months has established good sowing conditions for winter crops. After five years of decline, crop production is forecast to recover slightly in 1988-89. The area planted to wheat is forecast to be 9.5 million ha, still 25 per cent below the record area of 1983-84.
Australian rural output in aggregate is forecast to increase by about 3 per cent in 1988-89, to a level similar to that of 1986-87.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its disappointment at the selection of recipients of the Companion of the Order of Australia on Australia Day 1988;
(2) is of the opinion that the bulk of awards are issued to machinery positions, that is, to persons because they hold the positions rather than because they earned the award; and

(3) notes that on the day of the 200th anniversary of white settlement, the Council has demeaned the Order and failed to give appropriate consideration to the main purpose of the Order of Australia to recognise achievements by Australians as distinct from the position, patronage basis of the imperial honours.

This motion was generated by what I feel was a very great sense of disappointment on Australia Day 1988, the 200th anniversary of white settlement in Australia, when we awoke to read of the awards made under the Order of Australia on that most historic occasion in this nation's history. The awards to Companion of the Order of Australia, the highest honour that can be bestowed on an Australian, consisted almost exclusively of awards to positions, not persons. I do not in any way detract from the individuals, their integrity or their worth to our community. But the facts are that of 13 awards made on that day seven were pinned on chairs at the High Court of Australia, to be allotted to the persons who occupy those chairs. Of those seven recipients, six already held knighthoods in the imperial honours system and only one was receiving a new award. Five other persons were honoured in the general areas available to the Australian community. Two of those also were imperial knights. Their worth to the Australian community is not questioned.

Was that the appropriate way for the highest honours available to Australians to be awarded by the Council of the Order on the day on which we celebrated the most historic occasion in the history of white settlement in Australia? It is my belief that on that day of all days the honours should have reflected those persons-I would like to think living and dead, but I am certain that living was the only option open-still living in this country who have made the greatest contributions and achievements towards making this country what it is today. Many Australians-some already honoured, some already in receipt of honours under the Order of Australia-could have been specifically and directly recognised to the credit of the nation and, I believe, to the pride of the Australian people in that list.

The second list in the year did not reflect a great deal of change. The majority of those appointed to be Companions of the Order of Australia in the Queen's birthday honours in this our bicentenary year were already honoured previously as imperial knights. Are there no people in Australia who have not so qualified by outstanding contributions to our community that they should not have been honoured without first having to qualify through the imperial system? I believe the Council has let down this country this year by the awards it has made. I believe it has not done what was expected of it; that is, to honour people for their individual achievements.

The Council has, in fact, opted to go back to the old patronage system. If a person happens to occupy a position, then irrespective of whether he does it well or badly he gets a certain level of award for the position. A High Court judge who used to become a knight now becomes a companion. A senior public servant, Commonwealth or State, will receive the level of Order of Australia which is appropriate to the position that has been held. If a person happens to be moved on by the Government in that system he will probably get a higher award than he would have earned had he retired normally.

It is not really good enough. On Australia Day we should have had the most outstanding Australians, such as Don Bradman and Heather McKay. Heather McKay is the most outstanding woman athlete in Australia's history. They should have been honoured. The achievers, the people who have led this nation, the people who have created this nation, should have been there and they should have been named. I do not wish to go through a lot of names because that would be unfair to the people I do not name. But there are some people who should be named. For instance, Tom Uren has given a lifetime contribution to this Parliament. I mention one other member because he has already been honoured-Clyde Cameron. When Clyde Cameron retired, his contribution of a lifetime to Australia got the second, not the top, honour. But if he had happened to have lived in a cloistered atmosphere and had become a senior public servant or a judge of the High Court, his contribution would have been honoured by his becoming a Companion of the Order. I make those points.

I do not begrudge the awards to anyone who has already been honoured, but I believe that it is appropriate that this Parliament should indicate its displeasure that on this, the occasion of our bicentenary, the awards were pinned on positions, not people, and at least one judge was not prepared to accept that. In all the awards made this year-I have excluded the Duke of Edinburgh and the military awards-some 25 of them to the senior positions, not one Australian woman, Aborigine or trade unionist has been seen as having contributed to Australia to the extent that he or she is entitled to be acknowledged by Australians. I do not believe that. Not an architect and not an artist has been honoured. No performer--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about accountants?

—I am sure there are a couple of accountants. There are also a couple of politicians, two former Prime Ministers. Both were entitled to the award. Any person who has been Prime Minister of this nation has contributed, whether we agree with his politics or not. We are talking about something which was established to reflect real honour and real credit; an award which those people who wear it, can wear with pride in personal achievement. The awards, as they are now being conferred, do not enable that to be done.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and congratulate the honourable member for Corio for raising this matter.
—Do you reserve your right to speak?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this motion which was raised by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). We have before us a motion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) expresses its disappointment at the selection of recipients of the Companion of the Order of Australia on Australia Day 1988;
(2) is of the opinion that the bulk of awards are issued to machinery positions, that is, to persons because they hold the positions rather than because they earned the award . . .

It is timely to raise these questions in the context of the specific awards that have been given in conjunction with Australia Day because appropriately, as the honourable member for Corio has said, this commemorates a unique period in Australia's history. It was a time in which one could look back over a person's lifetime of contribution to Australia and make a judgment as to who were the most outstanding Australians at that time. Whereas I suspect that in relation to awards which are granted at other times there is a certain framework against which judgments are made as to particular organisations which may have had people who have rendered outstanding service, the award could have been given at another time and in another framework, I have some other complaints about the way in which the award system appears to operate.

Whilst commending the honourable member for Corio on the issues he has raised, I take the opportunity to put them in a somewhat broader context. I have heard these remarks uttered before but it does not seem to matter whether awards are being granted by governments on this side of the House or in accordance with the system that has now been established where State governments, the Commonwealth and presumably a range of other people nominated by those governments are involved in making the selections.

TALK.START.PARA: —People of power.

—The honourable member says, `People of power'. It strikes me as strange that the complaints that have been made before do not appear to have been remedied by those who have been put into power to make these decisions. I have made a simple analysis of the information that is available to me. Not a great deal of information is published about the service given by people and therefore it is difficult to make judgments as to whether the person who has received an award is the most outstanding person to receive the award in that particular field. I certainly would not want to reflect upon any of the recipients but it is remarkable that, in New South Wales, all the people who seem to have the qualities necessary across the whole range of human endeavour appear to come from the eastern and northern suburbs of Sydney.
—That's what I am saying. It is wrong.
—I do not know whether it is right or wrong but it is remarkable that when this Government makes the decisions and when its people are involved whom it has nominated--
—It is remarkable.

—Yes, it is remarkable. I have before me the figures for the honours list for January 1987: 23 came from the eastern suburbs, 43 from the North Shore, 29 from country areas, and 16 from elsewhere in the southern and western suburbs of Sydney. In June of 1987 the figures did not seem to change so much: 22 from the eastern suburbs, 40 from the North Shore, 32 from the country and 11 from the western and southern suburbs of Sydney. Even on Australia Day when, presumably, different criteria were being used, on my analysis there were 60 from the North Shore and eastern suburbs, 41 from the country, and 35 from elsewhere. If one looks at the principal awards, those in the Order of Australia, of companions in the general division and member in the general division as distinct from those who received the medal of the Order in the general division and the other awards, in relation to the more senior awards, one finds that 35 came from the eastern suburbs and the North Shore, 13 from the country, and 12 from the western and southern suburbs of Sydney. In relation to the more junior awards granted, the eastern suburbs and the North Shore only shared in 25, the country areas got 28 and the western and southern suburbs received only 23. That is a mere observation but as one who has from time to time nominated citizens whom I believe were worthy recipients, I am surprised at the large list of people which the committee which deliberated on these matters must have had before it to consider. I think it is many years since I have seen any of those whom I have nominated in any of those lists. I happen to be one of the few members of the Liberal Party of Australia who live in the western suburbs of Sydney. I do not know whether there is anything significant in that. I notice that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) is nodding, I assume with a degree of general agreement.
—Send them up to Queensland to buy a knighthood; no problems.

—The honourable member for Bowman makes a reflection of that sort but I would hope that that would never be the case. In relation to any of these awards, I would not want to reflect on his Government by suggesting that the mere fact that those who seem to have earned the awards and who live principally on the North Shore and in the eastern suburbs means that they could buy his Government. But if the honourable member were suggesting that it was possible, he should stand up and say it. I would be interested to hear the nature of the contribution he would make. I do not make that charge. That is not the basis upon which decisions are made as I understand it. In my view nor should it be. There are many fine Australians who have received awards and I know many of them. However, there appears to be a lack of balance in the outcome. People ought not to be chosen on the basis of where they live. They should be chosen on the basis of their distinction; that is, the quality of the contribution they have made to Australia in the whole range of human endeavour. In other words, the same sorts of principles ought to apply to awards as those which apply to all fields of human endeavour. We should strive to pursue excellence. We should contribute to the greatest extent humanly possible and when people make that contribution they should be so recognised. I know how difficult it is, but like the honourable member for Corio who spoke in this debate I am also of the view that no award should attach to a position merely because a person has held that position. I think that is what he was saying. I do not think awards should attach to a position merely because a person has had the privilege of being able to sit in the appropriate chair.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme-Former and Present Members of Parliament-Immigration-Referendum Proposals-Olympic Games-Brisbane Airport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1988 May economic statement, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced a number of major changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). One of these changes was a massive extension of the authorities mechanism, which requires doctors to apply to the Department of Community Services and Health for approval to prescribe certain medications under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: As from 1 August, 53 additional drugs have been placed on the `Authority Only' list. These include the latest, and in many cases the best, drugs for treating cancer, epilepsy, multiple sclerosis and circulatory diseases. The most significant cost factor targets, however, appear to be six products used in the treatment of high blood pressure, heart problems and elevated cholesterol levels. These products make up approximately 75 per cent of the total prescriptions for the 53 newly listed drugs. It is worth noting here that in Australia, almost half the deaths each year are due to cardiovascular disease, for which high blood pressure and elevated cholesterol are major risk factors.

Articles in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian last Tuesday, 23 August gave details of a recent study undertaken by the Institute for Health Economics and Technology Assessment, commissioned in part by the Department of Community Services and Health. This study has shown that in 1987 Australians lost more than 900 million days or 25 million years of normal, healthy life because of sickness, disease and premature death. Heart attacks, strokes, hypertension and other circulatory diseases were responsible for more than a quarter of all healthy days lost. In spite of this the Government has just restricted access to some of the most effective drugs for the treatment of high blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

The `Authority Only' list was originally introduced to monitor the use and possible dangerous side effects of new and/or addictive drugs. Drugs were placed on the list for legitimate medical reasons. It was in no way a means of rationing or limiting access to drugs on the basis of cost. The Hawke Government has now decided to change the rules governing the use of the authority mechanism. Cost rather than patient welfare is now the major consideration. In a press release issued on 26 June 1988 by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is responsible for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the changes to the authority list were described as `steps to avoid unnecessary prescribing of expensive drugs'. The Minister stated that the Government was:
simply prompting doctors to think twice before prescribing expensive drugs where there are possible cheaper alternatives.

As from 1 August this year, the Government has, in effect, bestowed second opinion status on public servants by giving them the power to approve or overrule a doctor's professional judgment as to which is the most appropriate medication for a particular patient's needs. From 1 August, a doctor seeking authority from the Department to prescribe one of the 53 hit list drugs must indicate that no cheaper alternative is available. This policy is both offensive to doctors and prejudicial to the best interests of their patients.

It is a fact of life in medicine, as in most other scientific and technological fields, that research and development cost money. Older is often cheaper, but not better. These 53 drugs are not luxury or addictive items; they cost more because drug companies must recover their research and development expenses. The Government is well aware of this fact-in this instance literally a fact of life-but has chosen to ignore it, and to encourage doctors to opt for the cheaper, less than best alternatives by making it difficult for them to prescribe the newly developed, state of the art, drugs. Page 131 of 1988-89 Budget Paper No. 1 clearly states:

Items available under the PBS and the rules under which they may be prescribed are determined by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care on the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.
A similar assurance is contained in the previously referred to ministerial Press release of 26 June, 1988 which stated:
in selecting the specific drugs the Government took full account of advice from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.

These statements are somewhat misleading. In regard to most, if not all, of the newly listed authority drugs the Government's decision flies in the face of Australian and international expert medical opinion. For example, the vast majority of experts disagree with the decision to include the six cardiovascular drugs on the authority list. The High Blood Pressure Research Council of Australia, the National Heart Foundation, the Cardiac Society, the Australasian Society of Nephrology, and virtually all of Australia's eminent specialists in cardiovascular medicine, have expressed enormous concern about the inappropriateness of an authority listing for these drugs and its implications for the effective treatment of cardiovascular disease. In fact, the Government has ignored the advice of its own expert committee, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which considered the possible authority listing of two of the six drugs at the end of last year, but finally recommended against such a move. Instead, it proposed a change to the listing of the drugs to encourage their more considered use.

The two drugs to which I specifically refer are ACE-inhibitors. They are prescribed by doctors to treat moderate to severe hypertension and represent a significant advance in the treatment of high blood pressure. They are prescribed more often because they are more effective, have fewer side effects and enjoy improved patient compliance. These factors should be weighed against additional costs. It should be noted, however, that the forward estimates used by the government in an attempt to justify its decision to authority list the two ACE-inhibitors are based on initial growth patterns for the two drugs. These growth patterns no longer apply, and reflected only the expected early growth from a zero base for any new and improved product. The early accelerated growth rate is now progressively slowing as these drugs establish their proper place in the medical armamentarium.

The Government's ill-conceived decision to authority list these 53 drugs will have many objectionable practical consequences. Amongst other obvious disadvantages, it will result in unacceptable delays for patients and a bureaucratic red tape nightmare for doctors and pharmacists who, in common with many other people, are already, and increasingly, inundated with unnecessary and unproductive government inspired and required paperwork.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it proper for the honourable member to mislead the House by saying that there is unacceptable red tape in the supply of drugs by pharmacists.
—Order! That is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a new agreement between the doctors and the Pharmacy Guild that gets rid of all the objections that the honourable member has raised.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Casey.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That was not even a good try by the honourable member. The Minister responsible has warned patients that delays will be inevitable under the new system. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Patients should bear in mind that the processing will take a few days.

Experience has shown that obtaining government approval for authority listed drugs can take much longer than a few days-sometimes it takes up to two weeks. With an anticipated increase of at least 1.6 million authorities in a full year, the potential for bureaucratic bottlenecks and delays is awe-inspiring. We have just seen some. In the 19 August edition of Medical Observer an example is cited where a doctor who had for sometime been prescribing Imuran for a patient with multiple sclerosis had the request for authority rejected. The reason? The doctor had written `immuno-suppression for multiple sclerosis' as the reason for requesting the drug. A clerk from the Department informed the doctor that the correct reason should have been `no cheaper drug available'. According to the same article, doctors from around Australia have been contacting the Medical Observer in regard to the difficulties the changes to the PBS are causing. What happens if a request for an authority drug is rejected? The Government has claimed it will not reject any application and is relying on the nuisance value of completing the application forms to discourage busy doctors from prescribing these drugs. If this is just a rubber stamp exercise, it is a very wasteful and potentially dangerous one.

Considering the estimated 3 million prescriptions per year that will now require approval, it would be interesting to know whether the anticipated cost savings will in fact be less than the set-up and ongoing costs of processing the authorities and administering the expanded system.

This Government has a responsibility to provide a fair, effective, cost efficient and affordable health care system for all Australians. This can not and should not be achieved by introducing a rationing system based on the cost of essential drugs-a system which reduces patients requiring these particular medications to the status of second class citizens who must prove their need to a bureaucrat when a doctor has already decided that the need exists.
In conclusion, I remind the Treasurer, who so proudly boasted in his Budget speech that `we are now well on the way back to prosperity', of the words of Benjamin Disraeli who said:
The health of the people is really the foundation upon which all their happiness and all their powers as a state depend.
In the final analysis the nation's health is just as important-perhaps more important-than its wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made some comments about my experience and observations during my 30 years as a people's representative in the national Parliament on 3 June in a special adjournment debate on the last day of sitting in the old Parliament House. The time constraints prevented me from placing on record several aspects, and even in this debate my comments will be limited by the amount of time at my disposal. I am taking this opportunity, in the first week of the new and permanent Parliament House, to put these few comments on record.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention an old and respected colleague, Reg Pollard. Reg Pollard may not be known to many members of this House, but he was Minister for Agriculture in the Chifley Government of 1946 to 1949. He was defeated in the landslide against the Labor Party in 1966 over Vietnam. He was then 70 years of age-but the youngest man in the Parliament in so many respects. He was always an inspiration to me with his positive and radical outlook on life, and he is one of the people who have inspired me in terms of longevity. The other person is Lloyd Rees, now in his ninety-fourth year. Pollard and Rees are givers and thinkers as to what the world could be if the human race could come together in a collective or a sisterhood and brotherhood. Their horizons were never dim, and I hope that I can emulate their vision and horizons in the years ahead.

The history of the Labor Party, even the history of Australian politics, may have been different if Reg Pollard had defeated Arthur Calwell for the leadership of the Parliamentary Labor Party when Doc Evatt retired in 1960. Eddie Ward was then a member and had six votes around him. Ward was standing for the deputy leadership if Arthur Calwell was successful in the leadership ballot. Ward knew that Pollard would have been the best leader, but Ward put his own interests first and Calwell defeated Pollard by 42 votes to 30. In the next ballot for the deputy leadership it was a wide field, and the last remaining in the ballot were Ward, Haylen and Whitlam. The left supported Pollard for the leadership position, but in the ballot for the deputy it was a free vote, and personal interests were involved.

Between the ballots I spoke to Reg Pollard in the corridor outside the party room. Pollard was not a `personal' man, but when I said `Reg, you've run a good race', Reg said with some emotion, `If it wasn't for that bastard Ward, I would have won'. Although I never vote out of emotion but try to be rational in my vote, I was emotionally upset over Reg's attitude to his defeat. Soon after I met Jim Harrison, then the member for Blaxland, and I knew that he had Alan Bird's proxy vote-in those days there were proxy votes, and he was then the member for Batman. So I relayed to Harrison Reg Pollard's attitude to Ward, knowing that Harrison thought the sun and moon shone right out of Reggie. In doing so, I switched Harrison's vote, I switched Alan Bird's proxy vote, and switched Tommy Uren's vote from Ward.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be the first and only time.

—It was a change of six votes, and I might tell the honourable member that Whitlam beat Ward by four votes. The other person I want to talk about is a present member of parliament. Colleagues might have remembered that I said, on 3 June, that Menzies and Whitlam were the two who dominated the Parliament most in my time but there was another emerging. Of course, that person was Paul Keating. I have known Keating for over 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1968 the seat of Reid was redistributed into four electorates. A good part of it went into the Blaxland seat and Keating won the preselection in 1968 and was elected to this House in 1969. At the outset I want to stress to make it quite clear that I am not one of those who is an advocate of Keating for Prime Minister; not at this stage of history, anyway. But to give credit where it is due, I have seen Keating grow as a member of parliament. This House is his forum, in a way it is his home. He feels secure; not out there with the people but here in the bullring of Parliament.

He is the Jack Dempsey of Australian politics. You can put him on the canvas but then he will get off that canvas and achieve victory. That is what happened when he was defeated on the consumption tax debate within our Party; he was on the canvas but the tax package he came up with was his victory. It was a Keating victory. It was not ours, it was not mine. He knows I do not agree with his tax priorities but he is tough and he knows what we wants to do. I think Keating is one of a handful in this Parliament-and I am talking about both sides of the House-who are visionaries. There are very few visionaries but Keating is one.

Keating can even be sensitive on some issues, but what worries me is that he is not a democrat and he is not a collectivist; he is an elitist and he is arrogant, but he is quite a remarkable character. He has such ability that he may even overcome those great flaws. He always talks publicly about his father. I think his mother is a pretty wonderful person and I think his wife, Anita, is pretty special also. I will never forget looking into the eyes of his first-born son. They were the most beautiful eyes I had ever seen. I thought to myself at the time there must be something of great beauty inside Keating to produce such a son.

Perhaps I could give Paul just a little advice. There is much I could say about the benefits of collectivism against elitism, but he might close his ears to that, so I will give him one word of advice-patience. And I suggest that the next time he goes to Washington he should study two exhibits standing in front of the National Museum. They made a great impact on me personally. One is a petrified log of wood 200 million years old. It comes from Arizona. The second is banded iron ore, with alternating layers of red jasper and black haematite, about 2,250 million years old from Jasper, United States of America. It is something to remember, particularly about one's own importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to speak in a grievance debate which is synonymous with the occasion and impact of this Parliament. It is an opportunity to talk about immigration.
