In fact, last week I had the opportunity to work with an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) Four Corners crew on an immigration feature which goes to air next Monday. Some quotes in a Sydney Morning Herald of this week testify to that. I took the ABC crew to Adelaide hotels as well as to the Vietnamese community. What disappoints me is the interpretation of a policy espoused by sections of the media but fuelled by the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government, remembering that it was his eminence himself, Bob Hawke, who said, `We do not want the Indo-Chinese refugees, send them back whence they came'. I do want them, my Party wants them.

SPEECH.PARA: Immigration is still vital for Australia's future. I sent out 43,000 Adelaide reports which were letterboxed into my electorate, the Federal seat of Adelaide, quoting some people whom we have helped on immigration. I want to cite some facts as well. Migrants and their families make up 40 per cent of Australia's 16 1/2 million people. Asians make up roughly three per cent of that 16 1/2 million--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you worried about it then?

—Not worried, Con. More than one million people annually inquire about migrating to Australia. More than 85 per cent of those people are refused entry on a variety of grounds including age; the point system prevents them from entry. Bigotry and prejudice cannot be tolerated in the world's most varied cultural mix, commonly known as Australia. As John Howard has stated, the foundation stone of the Opposition's immigration policy will be selection on a non-discriminatory basis. With this in mind the Opposition reserves the right, I suppose, to change the immigration policy and that must be its right.

SPEECH.PARA: We found out this week that the former immigration Minister, Mick Young, from the electorate next to my seat of Adelaide, moved to curb the flow of Asian migrants at the end of last year and that policy is still in force. I stand by my public statement that race should not play any part in our selection process; it is a cornerstone of our policy.

Let me dwell on social cohesion. I am reminded of an article written by the late and great Professor Julius Sumner Miller. He was asked, `Do you think the world will find peace? Will countries and nationalities find peace with each other?' He probably said, `Why is it so?' Families and brothers and sisters have irreconcilable disputes and feuds, yet we are asking and expect the world to be at peace. Australia is a very tolerant country. Our social cohesion is not under threat, but perhaps it is under pressure.

Australia is a country only 200 years old in terms of new settlement. Our indigenous inhabitants share similar views. Yet in the last 40 years we have recognised the need to populate or perish. As an emerging country, a fantastic country with a free spirit, we have inherited 150 new and different nationalities, religions and cultures, and of course we are going to be under some sort of pressure; but it is a pressure that we can live with and overcome but certainly not be threatened by.

We have pseudo allegations that our Asian- Pacific rim trade is in jeopardy. The Asian traders for centuries have been free traders and will go where the price is right, including paying for and coming to this country for education. What about one Australia and multiculturalism? Multiculturalism has not failed Australia or we it, yet this word seems to be at the heart of this debate-words and isms. We have horticulture, agriculture and now we have multiculture.

We love hijacking words or cataloguing people into areas. We had immigrants and then they became new Australians; then they were known as ethnics and now we have to know them as multicultures. It sounds like some new pathologist's yoghurt. My life, my family, and my country have been enriched and embellished by the impact of migrants who have come to Australia. I am grateful and proud of the contribution that they have made, firstly, to populate and the impact they have made on our arts, our theatre, cuisine, fashion and culture, language and lifestyle as has the Aboriginal population.

Australia went from a country of braces worn outside its shirts, felt hats and sauce on steaks, yet we have emerged to what we are today-Australia enriched by the world that has come here. Yet if we were fair dinkum and analysed the word we would have to be honest and say that multiculturalism envelops the ethnic community. What about middle ground Australia? What title do they afford us? We do not require a title, because we have one Australia. My children go to a school that is enriched by the children of immigrants, yet it is not called a multicultural school; it is called a school in Australia. What is wrong with that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it matter what you call it?

—It does not matter what it is called, my friend. Do not let anyone forget that it was less than 50 years ago that tens of thousands of Australian men and women offered their lives in the defence of this country and went abroad to do it. They went to Korea, New Guinea, Hong Kong, Vietnam. Why-to give Australia and Australians a free and democratic country to live in. The legacy is the veterans of Australia-`Lest we forget'.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no greater sacrifice than to offer your life for your fellow man and your country. Australians did this, yet when we dare to talk about social cohesion, multiculturalism, immigration or 150 different races, colours, creeds and religions, we are branded as racial bigots. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am going to espouse part and explode part of that. What I have difficulty coming to grips with is the moral high ground that this Labor Government uses to preach on immigration and its stance on immigration. I was introduced to its seedy, sordid, despicable attitude of racial discrimination in my own political campaign during the February by-election in Adelaide. The racial attitude was endorsed by Bob Hawke, the Labor Party, the minders, the back-room boys who prevented a Labor Party candidate going public with his delightful Filipino-born wife and his child, his own flesh and blood born in Australia.

Forget the lame excuses, sir, perpetuated by the Labor goons, saying Mr Farrell's wife was ill or unavailable for a photo. Do honourable members know the imposition Bob Hawke placed on his candidate? The glossy pamphlet portrayed the Labor man as the caring, sharing family man, yet in the pamphlet-remember, he was endorsed by the ALP-was the family picture of Farrell the candidate with a fill-in wife and children in the garden. The propaganda machine was portraying its man as the candidate living in the area-he was living in a safe house, and has since gone back to live in Unley-as the family man with children dedicated to serving the electorate. It was not the fault of the candidate and his wife, but the Labor Party who saw the family cohesion as a threat to its chances in that election.

The deceitful, racist, discriminatory Labor Party had substituted for Mrs Farrell, the Filipino wife and their beautiful young daughter, office staffers and the children of Mr Dugan, the State member of Adelaide. They superimposed them. Why? Were the mother and daughter that ill? Were they contagious? No. The Australian Labor Party machine would stoop to such rotten tactics as racial discrimination. The Labor Party said, `We will endorse you, you are all right, but we do not want your wife and child. We will put you out on the hustings, but do not let anyone see you with your wife.'

When Bob Hawke, Paul Keating and John Bannon went on the hustings in Adelaide they endorsed those actions. Mick Young, Mick Noonan and John and Angela Bannon were at the famous meet the candidate barbecue, but they did not include the candidate's wife. When the Prime Minister appeared at a social function at the North Adelaide Football Club, scene of the famous telephone time charge expose, there was no wife. This Government and this Party dare to stand and play the devil's advocate on multiculturalism and accuse my Leader of being racist and discriminatory. In the eyes of the people of Adelaide and Australia, they stand condemned because this has come back to haunt them just as the famous words of Bob Hawke in 1977, the message to the boat people, will come back to haunt them.

What price do honourable members think the candidate for Adelaide has to pay to know that his Party wanted him, but not his Australian-born delightful daughter? When they were flushed out, there was nothing wrong with what was going on, but here again was a classic case of meddling by the Labor Party back-room boys who saw this as a threat to their chances of winning the by-election which, as we know, they subsequently lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased in many respects to be talking today in the grievance debate on the very issue that we have just heard being spoken about by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt). The very nature of what he had to say to this Parliament today is a result of the recent intervention of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and what he has in fact perpetrated within the Australian community. It is a direction which seems to be tearing the nation apart and, without exaggeration, has the potential to tear apart the very fabric upon which the Australian community is based.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sad to say that it is causing very serious racial disharmony and even racial violence in the community. It is sad that these problems have been occasioned as a result of the deliberate intervention in the present immigration debate by none other than the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. Either wittingly or unwittingly, Mr Howard has embarked upon a cynical political exercise with no real thought or concern for the divisiveness that it has caused and will cause within the Australian community.

I believe that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, is in fact a very decent person, but he is a person who has been under a great deal of pressure from within his own party. He came back from overseas to find that the troops had been playing up, to find that Senator Chaney and of course, of late, Mr Wilson Tuckey were talking quite openly about the question of leadership of the Liberal Party. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I realise that a couple of speakers before the honourable member have transgressed but I would ask him not to refer to people by their names but by the names of their electorates.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Leader of the Opposition has started thrashing around like a dying shark, trying desperately to gain some relevance in the community. To his everlasting shame, he has sunk to the bottom of the political barrel by trying to win votes by pandering to those racists and bigots who unfortunately exist in every world community and no doubt exist in the seat of Adelaide. I will quote Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald of 22 August 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, let me repeat for the record: I do not think Liberal leader John Howard is a racist. If he were, his approach to the issue would actually be more defensible.

Mr Deputy Speaker, what is the effect of this new one Australia policy? In case you think I am being a little bit alarmist when I say that, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say this: Who would have thought just several months ago that a self-proclaimed leader of the Ku Klux Klan would actually have the gall to proudly proclaim the existence of the Ku Klux Klan as a branch in this country and proudly proclaim the fact that he was the leader of it? This happened on a Jana Wendt current affairs program some three weeks ago. There he was, dressed in his full white-hooded regalia. It was disgusting to see and I never thought that in my life I would ever get to see, in a country like this, a person who was prepared actually to go before millions of viewers on television in that way. Only yesterday, an Adelaide reader wrote a letter to the editor to condemn racism. He had his tyres slashed and his garage burned down and later received a telephone call saying, `Next time it will be your house. Long live white Australia.'

Honourable members may think that that is an isolated example. May I also refer to the experience of prominent journalist Max Walsh, whom I quoted earlier, a journalist who dared to adopt a non-racist approach in his features. He wrote:

Howard, from his position of political leadership, is giving comfort, support and even respectability to a cause that every mainstream politician has eschewed for decades. Because I have pointed to the dubious morality, the incorrect assumptions and the inherent economic risks in Mr Howard's policy, I've had the dubious honour of being targeted by his supporters.

My home and my wife's car-and, unfortunately, the home of a gentle neighbour-have been attacked by the National Action's graffiti artists armed with their aerosol cans of paint. Apart from their penchant for obscenity, this organisation has as its signature the swastika.

How did the policy come about? To the credit of prominent Liberals with a proven interest in the social cohesion of this country, they have either publicly or privately strongly disagreed with their Leader. A number of senators in the other place and a number of well respected Liberals in this House have also come out very strongly publicly and privately against the policies as outlined by the Leader of the Opposition; not to mention, of course, such prominent State leaders in the Liberal Party as the Premier of New South Wales and the leaders of the Opposi- tion both in South Australia and in Victoria.

Frankly, it is fairly obvious to me and to other members of the Labor Party that the Liberal Party has been hijacked by the National Party and, in particular, by Senator Stone and the Leader of the Federal National Party. They now have a policy which gives comfort to the racists, but they also try to pretend that it is non-discriminatory, in an attempt to win votes. As with other Liberal policies they are in a mess, because they try to be all things to all people. But people will not be fooled.

The Sydney Morning Herald editorial of today is correct. The Liberals are sending out two messages-one to the racists and the bigots in an attempt to win votes and the other to try to convince the public that their policy is not based on discrimination. I ask the Australian public not to be fooled by this two bob each way attitude. Today it is the Asians. Who will it be tomorrow-the Greeks, the Italians, the Jews? Who is it going to be tomorrow? At the moment, frankly, we could not possibly trust the Liberals to walk the dog, let alone run the country.

On the question of business migration, for instance, their policy effectively says that we like the colour of their money but not the colour of their skin or the slope or slant of their eyes. To restrict Asian immigration would virtually destroy the business migration program. Howard and Stone do not know what they are talking about when it comes to the question of immigration policy. The policies of the Opposition are wrong and the Leader of the Opposition knows it. The editorials or our nation's papers know it and so does the Opposition back bench. The Australian Financial Review, with the readership of people one would imagine would support the Liberal Party as a rule-until, of course, we showed that we could manage the economy better than them-has been staunch in its criticism of the Opposition's policy.

The Americans are rubbing their hands in glee, according to one article by a prominent journalist from Washington. I think it was Gregory Heywood. That particular article said that Asian investors in Australia were now looking elsewhere. So, in effect, the policy of the Liberal Party and the coalition is threatening not only the very fabric of society that I have been talking about but also our economy. It is placing our economic recovery at risk and I think that is an absolute shame.
Today's editorial in the Melbourne Age eloquently sums up the position. Referring to the Leader of the Opposition's victory in having his party support his stand, it states:
For a political leader, a victory achieved at the cost of continuing bitter division within his own party, and the community, is not a victory at all. It is a tragedy.

It is not multiculturalism that is divisive; it is the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition should be ashamed and so should the coalition for not having the collective guts to stop him in the party room.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I want say to the people of Australia this afternoon is that while I am not a lawyer, and certainly not a constitutional lawyer, what I do claim very proudly is the title of being an Australian. As an Australian the Constitution is one of the things that I hold very dear. Some people will say it is a 1901 institution. It is a 1901 institution that is revised continually in sympathy with Australia's changing conditions. This is an institution which in its own way provides for many of the other institutions that we enjoy here today; for instance, this Federal system of Parliament, our Government and our Westminster system.

SPEECH.PARA: We also, through this Constitution, bear witness to the monarchy. It is also a blueprint for the justice that is given with the High Court just down on the lake. It also sets out States' rights and their responsibilities and it has worked well. It is a living testament to the freedoms that we enjoy in Australia today.

So when it comes to a matter of changing one of these institutions, bearing in mind that it is not only the Constitution, the proposed referendum will also change many of our other institutions, I think the people of Australia ought to ask themselves why. If it is to change, I want to make sure that those changes are appropriate to Australia and its Bicentennial and that they actually improve the liberties and rights of the individuals whom I am quite proud to call my fellow Australians.

As to the propositions that are coming up, I have to advise my fellow Australians that as far as I can ascertain, and as far as the Opposition ascertains, these changes will not improve the rights or the liberties of any individual Australian; in actual fact they could reduce or deny them the liberties that they have had in the past. What it does is affect the very delicate balance between the States and the Commonwealth, something set out in the Constitution, by concentrating more power not with the person or the States but on this place in Canberra, this new Parliament House that we are sitting in and the Government that controls it for the time.

It also takes power away from the people and puts it into the High Court that occupies the shores of our lake just down the hill. Therefore I say that the changes are not appropriate, because the four questions in themselves will propose 33 changes to sections and they will alter significantly the 1901 agreement that we proudly call our Constitution. The real danger is not in the fact that people will be asked to make a decision, but in the nature of the questions. Nobody can say that the questions are fair and reasonable or that they indicate the particular nature of the legislation that goes behind them. Four Acts are involved, 1,700 words added and 600 words deleted.

Those four questions on the ballot paper do not reflect what is actually the intent of the Government in this regard. I want to quote what Gary Morgan, Managing Director of Roy Morgan Research Centre, said in the Courier-Mail on 18 May just shortly after the introduction of the legislation:
Any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility.

I claim that in proposing these questions it is the Government itself that has lost credibility and deserves to wear that tag. What the Government proposes is not what it claims it is, a great example of people's power. In other words, $6m has been spent on a Constitutional Commission to which the Government says the people have had access. These actual proposals are not the recommendations of the Commission. Two of them have been changed and two of them must stand in this House at the moment as being Government proposals, not people's proposals.

Question No. 1, which seeks to alter the Constitution to provide for a four-year maximum term, indicating that the terms of parliament would in future go four years, has not the safeguards sought by the Constitutional Commission of having a three-year minimum. I want to take the point that a Prime Minister who already should be in the last year of his second term is now half-way through his third term. Whether a change of that nature would provide fewer elections or more elections, on that record one must come to the conclusion it would most certainly mean more and not fewer. I come back to the point that it is the Prime Minister's question, the Government's question and not that of the people.

The third question also has been altered from the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission to add extra words which fly in the face of any definition. Of course, that definition might have to be given an interpretation by someone somewhere else. I will deal with the four questions that people will be asked. They are simple questions. One is proposing that there be a maximum of four years. It does not give that right to the Australian people. What it does is give the opportunity for the Government, for the Prime Minister of the day, at any time that the Senate as the House of review proposes looking at or amending any legislation, to take the Parliament to the people for an election. So it does not have that safeguard of having a lesser term.

The Constitution set up two Houses for very particular reasons. This House, the lower House, proposes the legislation. The Senate across the road is to look at that legislation, to send it to committees for an interpretation to make sure that the legislation is correct and then alter and amend it if necessary. That is the point. The Constitution provided different terms of sitting for the two Houses so that there was always a continuing Senate, out of the scope and out of the reach of the influence of this House. It will be a fundamental right lost to the people of Australia to have two Houses, one acting as the Government, the other one acting as a mirror without any opportunity of that review and objection to any legislation. There will be no brake on the Prime Minister of the future. The second question is also deliberately misleading: `Do you believe in fair and democratic parliamentary elections?'

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.

—We have had the interjection. May I tell honourable members what this proposes. Democracy, as far as elections are concerned, I would think is getting as near as possible to 50 per cent of the people to provide a government.
—Federally.

—Right, federally. I will give an example. To change this Government the conservatives have to poll over 52.5 per cent of the vote. In Queensland, whose State rights are attacked by this question, the government can be changed with just a little less-a little over 51 per cent of the vote. So, which is the more democratic-the proposition that is in the referendum or the proposition that is in Queensland?
—That is Trades Hall democracy.

—Trades Hall democracy. We might also take the New South Wales example, and we have a New South Wales member in the chamber now. Mr Greiner, in order to take government, had to get 52.7 per cent of the vote. Where is the democratic vote in that? It is put that it stops gerrymanders. Anybody who believes that is a fool because the present boundaries on which this legislation is based are quite subject to gerrymander. In fact, I can give an example of my own seat about the number of electors there as compared to a more densely populated area. So, it may stop one gerrymander but what it will do is implement the gerrymander that this Government provides.

SPEECH.PARA: The third question, as I have already said, has been changed by this Government to provide a vehicle for itself to take control of local government throughout Australia, because it will have to involve a definition of the High Court of what is a system of local government. We could have throughout Australia a system of regionalism that Mr Uren, the relevant Minister at that time, wanted in 1974 under Whitlam.

The fourth question is a denial of rights that are not already in the Constitution. The Constitution and the law of this country already determine that a person will have the right of trial by jury irrespective of the offence. This particular referendum will curtail that right.

The other question is on freedom of religion. Section 116 has already been tested before the High Court of Australia to guarantee that this Government or this Parliament can distribute funds to religious organisations for education and medicine, and everything else. This will, in fact, under the American experience, deny the freedoms that we already have. I referred earlier to people's power. I am asking the people of Australia to demonstrate that power, that power of the ballot box, by refuting and negating the whole four of these questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise today to speak in support of Greece's bid to host the 1996 Olympic Games and to call on all Australian States which have proposed to make bids to withdraw them. I take this position only after careful consideration. Having worked for eight years in the New South Wales Department of Tourism, I am well aware of the many benefits generated by being the host country of an Olympic Games. I realise that holding the 1996 games in Sydney not only would be a shot in the arm for Australian sport generally but also could provide the opportunity to make a significant and lasting contribution to a great city.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that the Olympics could provide the opportunity to generate a greater incentive for sporting excellence in Australia; a great deal of international publicity for Australia, generally; possibly economic profit; and the opportunity to transform our urban living habits. Whilst these are all valid reasons I believe in 1996, the centenary of the modern Olympics, there is a greater need to forgo self-interest for the shared benefits of upholding Olympic tradition. As all Australians can appreciate in this, our bicentennial year, a centenary is an important event, one based on history and tradition.

Clearly, Greece is the country with the longest Olympic tradition. Indeed, it is the land where the Olympic ideal was born. According to Greek legend the Olympic Games were founded by Hercules. However, as the first historical mention of the Games of Olympia occurred in 776 BC, the games held that year are now considered the first official Olympia. From then on, we number the games as they were held every four years, but numbering was not how the Greeks preferred to record them. Rather, each Olympiad was given the name of the winner of the first men's race, which was a sprint of about 200 metres, the length of the stadium. The first Olympiad was therefore named for Koroebos, the winner of that race in 776 BC.

In fact, for many years there was only that one race and the Games lasted only one day. It was not until the fourteenth Olympic Games in 724 BC that a second race was added. Later Olympics brought the addition of even more events until finally the Games lasted five days. In contrast, the summer Games now last for two weeks. We know quite a deal about the traditions of the ancient Olympic Games-its religious, literary, and artistic aspects. But the ancient Olympics were also fostering peace. For the month when the Games were heralded, trained for and contested, no fighting was allowed. Heralds visited the far corners of the Hellenic world to announce this truce. The region of Ilia in which Olympia is situated was then considered sacred and nobody could bear arms in this area. During the Peloponesian War in 424 BC, Sparta broke the truce and so her athletes were denied permission to the Games and her warriors condemned as a miserable disgrace.

There are many stories of the ancient Games; for example, of the woman who sneaked in disguised as a trainer. As the attendants were strictly confined to men, a new rule was brought in that trainers as well as participants in the Games had to be nude. There are many other stories-of the boxing matches that lasted six hours, or of a runner who completed 24 laps of the stadium in winning time and then, without waiting to be crowned, kept on running back to his home city 90 miles away to proclaim his victory.

From all our records, the overriding element of these ancient Games was the importance of fostering development of an excellent mind and a beautiful body. The relevance of this history and its traditions was not lost on Baron Pierre de Coubertin of France, who in 1892 began a public campaign to resurrect the Games. His vision of the Olympics is encapsulated in these words:

I shall burnish a flabby and cramped youth, its body and its character by sport, its risks and even its excesses. I shall enlarge its vision and its hearing by showing it with wide horizons, heavenly, planetary, historical horizons of universal history which, in engendering mutual respect, will bring about a ferment of international peace. All this is to be for everyone, with no discrimination on account of birth, caste, wealth, situation or occupation.

De Coubertin's main objectives are contained in that resolution. The practice of sport would help to fight physical or moral decadence, a new and broader approach to teaching would counteract the harmful effects of specialisation. The teaching of history would have to be fundamentally transformed in order to allay the threat of nationalism and for nations to be looked upon as part of one humanity. De Coubertin continued:
The time will come for deciding whether history must continue to be used as a material for war, or whether it will be allowed to play the peacemaking role of which it is capable.

The Olympics to de Coubertin was an opportunity for nations to come together on a universal scale, putting aside partisan self-interest. Despite his own personal motivation to use the Olympics to revitalise France, which had been recently humiliated in the Franco-Prussian War, de Coubertin recognised the historical relevance of holding the first modern Olympic Games in Greece. I believe Australia and other countries should now recognise the symbolic importance of holding the centenary of the modern Games in Greece in 1996.

Symbolism has always been a central feature of the Games. The torch is lighted at Olympia as homage to those who had given birth to the idea; the pigeons carry their message of peace between all nations to the heights; and there is the raising of the national flags of the winners and of the Olympic flag. Over recent years, the fundamentals of the Olympic tradition have been shaken, with the terrorist attacks in Munich and the constant boycotts by certain countries for political reasons. I believe the Olympic tradition could do with a shot in the arm and the symbolic importance of holding the one hundredth anniversary in Athens could help to provide this, just as the holding of the unofficial Games in Athens in 1906 helped to put the Games back on the rails after two failures, in Paris and the United States.

So, too, could a 1996 Athens Games help to rekindle and remind a forgetful people of the objectives of the Olympic Games. I understand that Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane will soon be making their submissions to the Australian Olympic Federation and that further bids will be made to the International Olympic Federation by Athens, Toronto, Atlanta, Manchester, and perhaps cities in South America. Had this been 1978-79, when the New South Wales Government had the chance to lodge a bid for the 1988 Olympic Games, I would have been in total support. However, we let this opportunity slide.

Australia had its chance to hold the Games this year, our bicentenary year, but we lacked the foresight and confidence to make a bid 10 years ago; 1996 is not the time. If Greece had failed to lodge a bid it would have been a different matter. However, Greece has lodged a bid. Indeed, the Greek Prime Minister's son, George Papandreou, has been given the task of bringing the 1996 summer Olympic Games to Greece. I have read several local newspaper reports suggesting that Athens is not behind the proposal. This is not so. As the mayor of Athens, Uiltiadis Evert, recently testified in statements, Athens indeed is ready to host the Olympic Games and it is quite able with the facilities to do so. According to the Greek Under-Secretary of Sport, they are already well towards completion of the Athens infrastructure of the Olympics. It will be finished in 1990. They are also building up a sports infrastructure throughout Greece.

Recently the Greek Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, said that it was Greece's intention of staging the 1996 Olympics within a high level framework of cultural events, similar to those of the Olympic Games in antiquity. `Our ambition', he said, `is to make the Athens Games an Olympiad of peace and culture, not only an anniversary but a milestone.' Paraphrasing from the ancient Greek poet Pindar he said, `There is no greater honour for a country today than that of hosting the Olympic Games. Greece seeks this honour and I believe it has the right to it.'

I had the honour recently of visiting Greece to attend the first international congress of the World Pan-Arcadian Federation. Whilst there I had the privilege of speaking to Mr Papandreou, the Prime Minister. I advised him that I supported the bid of Athens to hold the Olympic Games in 1996. I consider that Australia and the international community should also give Greece the opportunity and honour of holding the 1996 Olympic Games in recognition of that country's contribution to the Olympic ideal and to commemorate Greece's holding of the first Games of the modern Olympiad in 1896.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I entered the chamber this afternoon I had no idea that the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) was going to discuss the Olympics, because one of the points I was going to raise was the Olympic Games. While I would have very little with which to dis- agree with the honourable member in terms of what Athens may want, part of my reason for rising this afternoon was to make sure that the Federal Government was fully cognisant of the bid by Brisbane to stage a future Olympic Games. While I do not want to disagree with the honourable member, may I say that I think it would probably still be a good idea if Brisbane went ahead with that particular bid that it is now working on and if it had the support of the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that there is a great deal of prestige to be had from any city or country which stages the Olympic Games. The fact that Brisbane made a bid last time and was quite successful with that bid, coming in in third position, put it in a sound situation to make sure that it was successful in gaining the Olympics at a future date.

I also say on that point that I think my home city of Brisbane, without being terribly parochial, has an outstanding record in the staging of these major events. I would hark back to the Commonwealth Games of 1982, which undoubtedly were some of the best ever held. The position at the moment with Expo 88 is really an outstanding achievement. More than nine million people have already been through the gates of Expo 88. As only 7.8 million people were targeted for the full six months of Expo, it really is a magnificent achievement and I think all those, from Sir Llew Edwards, down who have been involved with the staging of Expo should be congratulated.

Already we are seeing the magnificent benefits that are flowing on to Australia, especially in terms of the number of international visitors who have come through in the first six months of this year. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred the other night to the very real contribution that tourism is making to the Australian economy at the moment. Quite frankly, if we did not have events like Expo at the moment, we would not have been listening to some of the figures that we heard the other night. While foreign debts are considerably bad at the moment, they would be a great deal worse if we had not had the foresight over the last decade to make sure that we had some of these great events and the capacity to build up the inbound tourist industry.

Once again in this place I want to raise the issue of the Brisbane International Airport and the Government's attitude towards that particular airport. Members on all sides of the House during the parliamentary recess faced a very difficult situation where the southern suburbs and indeed some of the northern suburbs of Brisbane were subjected to aircraft noise that, I think it would be true to say, none of us had an inkling would happen after what we had been told about the construction and the benefits of the construction of the new Brisbane Airport runways. It was, in a bipartisan sense, that the Federal members from Brisbane got together and tried to resolve some of the situations and some of the very real concerns that faced the people in the southern suburbs of Brisbane, especially in terms of that aircraft noise.

Some adjustments have been made and not everyone is happy. It has become perfectly obvious that the only solution now is to go back to the original plans for Brisbane International Airport and urge the Federal Government to start construction of the main cross runway as soon as we possibly can. That would appear to be the only solution. I am afraid that my confidence in the Government and, indeed, in the various airport authorities that have in recent times been established by this Government, is subject to very grave fears indeed. I refer to the recent statements by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), recently established by this Government, as to what the future may be for the Brisbane international air terminal. It would seem that the board of the FAC at the moment is hell-bent on extending the present tin shed that serves as the Brisbane international terminal.

There is no other city in Australia that has had the growth in international air traffic that Brisbane has had in recent times. The fact that Queensland is presently getting 48 per cent of the total number of international tourists coming into Australia is a tribute to that. I am quite mystified as to why the members of the Federal Airports Corporation want to follow this line about a temporary extension, while in the same breath talking about going ahead with the construction of an international air terminal, maybe in four or five years time.

The plain facts of the matter are these: the present terminal does not have the capacity to be able to handle air traffic at the moment. There are times, especially on Fridays and Saturdays, when that airport is stretched to the limit. In the words of one of the Qantas hierarchy from Queensland, `It is an amazing situation when you physically see jumbo jets lined up one after each other waiting for another aircraft to leave its bay so that they can move in'. There have been complaints from Japanese airlines about the high cost involved in the burning off of fuel while they are waiting. There are continuing complaints from the passengers who have to use that terminal of delays, congestion and discomfort and yet we have had no real reaction from the Federal Airports Corporation.

I was delighted to read earlier this week that agreements have been reached with the United States Government for an increase in flights between the west coast of the United States and Australia and that United and Continental airlines will have the capacity to serve Cairns and Brisbane airports. I hope they are prepared to come at about 3 o'clock in the morning, because that is going to be virtually the only time when they will be able to handle the traffic at Brisbane international.

It seems absolutely amazing to me that the Government sets up bodies like the Federal Airports Corporation and tells us that they are autonomous, that they are going to be run in a businesslike manner, but they are talking about spending millions of dollars on a temporary extension of a tin shed that was designed as a store shed for that airport, without having regard to any of the real options. The real options are simply: that we can go ahead now with a new terminal for Brisbane International Airport at absolutely no cost to the long-suffering Australian taxpayer, because already the plans for the terminal are there; they have been there for the last 10 years on the original plans for Brisbane international. Very little design work has to be done. Already a major corporation has approached the Government and has made a bid to build that terminal at no cost to the taxpayer.

The Federal Airports Corporation apparently just will not look at this option. If the Government is fair dinkum in trying to get some of these quasi-government organisations up on a commercial basis, I really think it should be questioning some of the appointments it has made to the board of the FAC. One of the great things that is happening now is that most governments around the world and, indeed, in the Western world, have acknowledged that airport terminals in fact can be major profit centres. The British, for example, want to get rid of their terminals; they want to put them out privately.

One of the most commercial airports in the world is Manchester international which makes a huge profit. The Danes have now made Copenhagen Airport a major profit centre. The Dutch have been doing it at Amsterdam for years. Yet here in Australia when we have a build-up of tourism, when we have a great increase in the number of international flights and we indeed have the opportunity to start making money out of some of these particular outfits, we have a government organisation or a semi-government organisation which is going ahead and saying, `We really cannot build this now because it is going to cost too much money'.

I would think that it would be plain common sense that the Federal Airports Corporation should look very closely at the idea of allowing private enterprise to go in, maybe not only in Brisbane. There are other airports around Australia. Private enterprise could go in and take over the running and the construction of the international airport terminals around Australia. There is a lot of money to be made out of them. We can, by doing it this way, ensure that we have a most efficient facility that will incorporate everything that is required in an international airport.

One of the difficulties that we have in Australia is that we see international terminals as being there purely to handle incoming and outgoing traffic when we can turn them into shopping centres, into entertainment centres. We can build major hotels and create cities within themselves that can be of benefit not only to travellers but also to the whole population of a city.

It seems absolutely crazy to me that we completely disregard that attitude and say, `No, we will not build a new terminal, we will wait for a few more years and make sure that the Australian taxpayers are up for an additional $42m'. That is what the case is in Queensland. It would cost the taxpayers $42m to build that new terminal now. Why does not the Federal Airports Corporation put it out to private tender straight away? It could be constructed in about 18 months at absolutely no cost to the long-suffering taxpayers.

That is a nonsense. It in fact flies in the face of the true legal position in this country and the Opposition knows it.
—Here comes a great big distortion.

—They know it. He said `distortion'. Well, let the honourable gentleman pick up the South Australian State reports of 1985. He is well aware of the case, he knows about the case. It is called the Grace Bible case. It is a decision of the full court of the Supreme Court of South Australia. It is a binding precedent in South Australia. SPEECH.PARA: Yet, Mr Deputy Speaker, they are prepared publicly to state that religion is free and cannot be attacked by State governments. It had the constitutional power to pass legislation to prohibit religion and any other State in this country has that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they going to?

—Yet we have these inane interjections from a lawyer who has the responsibility on behalf of the Opposition to address these questions publicly. Is that not a tragedy? Is it not a tragedy that a decision of a full court of a Supreme Court of our States which has shown the Australian people the true legal position, as it applies in this country, is totally ignored? We have public comments, that somehow or other section 116 of the Federal Constitution will have power over the States to prevent them from abolishing religion or legislating for or against religion.

SPEECH.PARA: Does any Australian really want the power of a State government to pass a law, legally, to enforce any Australian to belong to a religion? Does any Australian really want that to be the law of this country or the law of a State? Yet the honourable gentleman who is so embarrassed sitting there because he knows it to be the truth is running around the countryside telling people the opposite. This is the reality where any issue involving the Constitution ultimately ends up.

The Opposition is made up of conservative parties which by instinct, inclination and thought patterns will oppose any changes whatsoever, whether good or bad; they will run out and oppose them and they will make public statements, whether they are truthful in a legal position or not, to try to confuse the Australian people. I must confess that they are doing a pretty good job. I have to admit that. They have done a very good job. They have confused the Australian people and, as they generally tend to do, they will vote no to issues they do not understand.

So the chance is that they do not trust us. They do not trust themselves to give the power in the Constitution, which is their document, to say to the State governments, `You cannot have the power to prohibit religion'. As I said earlier, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Reverend Ken Cain of the Uniting Church in Montmorency, tried to get a public debate within my electorate on the issue of the whole four constitutional questions. The honourable member for Flinders, as spokesman for the Opposition on this matter, was approached to obtain a speaker. Would you believe that no speaker is available? No speaker is available. We cannot even get a public debate within my electorate to call the public to a meeting where an Opposition member is prepared to stand up and debate a humble little backbencher of the Government on these issues.
They run away from publicity. They will not publicly debate one for one anywhere in Australia. All they do is use the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the bishops?
—They string a half story--
—What about the bishops?
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will stop interjecting.
—It is a lie.
—It hurts, Mr Deputy Speaker. He is bleeding. Look at him.
—The honourable member for Flinders will withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—He can't stand it. I do not mind whether he does or does not, the truth always comes out. Whether the referendum is won or lost the honourable member will always be remembered in legal circles for what he has said about the legal position in this country. He will always be remembered among lawyers for what he has said and he knows it. If one day this country is unfortunate enough to have him as an Attorney-General, and I might say that that is looking extremely unlikely--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Referendum Proposals-Multiculturalism-Friendly Societies-Helsham Inquiry-Brisbane Airport-Air Pollution-Sir Robert Menzies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor's referendum proposal on local government has the potential seriously to undermine this vital tier of government, not enhance it as the Hawke Government would have us mistakenly believe. Sadly, some municipal councils have naively accepted the Government line and are using their ratepayers' funds in promotion of this misguided cause, yet there is nothing in this proposal to recognise local government in the Federal Constitution that in any way protects local government's own funding arrangements. In fact, during the very time that the Federal Labor Government has been pushing its referendum proposal it has cut general purpose grants to 75 out of the 210 local governing bodies in Victoria alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, closer examination of the local government proposal reveals Labor's hidden agenda for centralisation. The proposal requires States to maintain `a system of local government' but not necessarily in the context that we have traditionally understood local government.

It is clear that this proposal allows the forced amalgamation of existing municipal councils into regional government areas, a long-held ambition of Labor in this country. —On 3 September $37m will be spent on a referendum, a referendum that has not been sought by the Australian people. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of claims by Friends of the Earth about the exposed tailings at Ranger. ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that, although the operating method eliminates free water above the tailings and reduces their moisture content below saturation at the surface, the material does remain very damp but coherent. Importantly, observations to date have detected no significant tendency to create dust. Such observations will continue, and plans are in place to rewet the tailings surface should any areas become sufficiently dry to potentially allow the suspension of the tailings to turn into dust.

I am advised further that the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Northern Territory supervising authority, as well as Ranger, have been closely observing and monitoring the situation to ensure that there is no adverse impact on the environment, workers and members of the public as a result of any radon emission. The honourable member can be assured that this will be continually observed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Treasurer. I remind him that, assuming bracket indexation had operated from 1986-87, and using the methodology of the firm Access Economics, which was established by two former senior Treasury officers and which produced that informative Budget monitor last week, a person on average weekly earnings will pay over $1,050 additional tax in 1988-89 and over $1,350 additional tax in 1989-90 due to bracket creep. I ask the Treasurer how the additional tax due to bracket creep, estimated at over $1,050 in 1988-89, can be reconciled with his claim that bracket creep is contributing only a `sliver' of the increase in tax revenue this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave the facts as to the `sliver' yesterday. It is $1.5 billion.
—And they don't add up.

—They might not add up with an ex-Treasury official working on his own model, but they add up in the Treasury. That is curious. The whole resources of the Treasury cannot add up but a couple of ex-Treasury staffers with their own ticker board can. I made the point yesterday to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that it is the height of incredulity for him to be talking about fiscal drag when yesterday on a radio interview, when asked about tax cuts, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well you phase your tax cuts over the three year period, based on cuts in government expenditure . . .
The next question was whether he would give tax cuts, to which he replied:
Yes, but I wouldn't be able to deliver on what is required in one year. I would have to phase it over the three year period because it's a very significant sum of money . . .

It is a contradiction in terms for him to say he would phase it in over three years and provide automatic indexation of the tax scales. Here he is asking me about bracket creep when the loss to revenue by express decision of the Government was $1.4 billion-the same as the increase in bracket creep. We have given back the same amount of money as we got from the increase in bracket creep; as well, we have lost $1 billion of Reserve Bank profit and $675m from oil receipts as a result of the lower oil prices benefiting the community. So we have lost or given back $3 billion as against the $1 1/2 billion raised by bracket creep, and we have tax cuts 10 months away. The Deputy thinks this is a shocking position and he says he would give tax cuts phased in over three years, with all that that implies for hanging on to fiscal drag or the bracket creep for three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the interest displayed here yesterday in alcohol related diseases and as a pharmacist professionally interested in preventive health programs, I ask whether the Minister for Community Services and Health will inform the House what action is being taken to improve the health status of Australians most susceptible to avoidable illnesses and injury.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy indeed to respond to the question from the honourable member for Streeton. I spoke to the House on Tuesday, in response to another question, and indicated the benefits that had already accrued from one particular preventive policy-the vaccination of children against measles. I suggested that very real benefits had already accrued out of that bicentennial program, and the national better health initiative in this Budget will stimulate further initiatives of that kind in defined areas. They make up a four-year program costing some $41m, to be cost shared with the States, which will implement some key recommendations of the Better Health Commission report. In addition to the $41m, we will also be putting in over that period of time some $10m from the Commonwealth health promotion program, which will be dovetailed into the better health program.

ANSWER.PARA: We have already reached agreement with the States about a national program and have identified together the five major areas in which the program will operate. The first of these is high blood pressure, which affects one in six adults and, if untreated, leads to major problems and hospitalisation. There will be particular emphasis on programs for the reduction of hypertension, particularly in blue collar communities, and we will be working with food manufacturers to reduce the salt content of packaged foods. The second area is nutrition. In many ways, unbalanced nutrition leads to lower health status. The better health program will stimulate nutrition research, again very much in socially disadvantaged groups, and will improve the availability of fresh foods.

Thirdly, we can expect the campaign to further advise women in relation to pap smears to prevent cervical cancer, as well as continuing the existing anti-smoking measures and sun protection campaigns. Fourthly, most injuries are preventable. Therefore, we will extend injury surveillance to develop a national database on number, type and cause of injuries. This will allow a trouble-shooting approach in cooperation with other groups concerned with occupational health and safety.

Finally, there will be health initiatives for the aged, concentrating on developing a much more participatory role for older people in local health planning and aged care service development. As all honourable members know, older people make the greatest use of hospital and medical services in this society. We want to help them to prevent the kind of dependency that too often occurs in old age as a result of insufficient preventive health services being available earlier.

We have pretty high standards of health in this country; they are among the best in the Western world. But we now know that there are some very well-defined health problems relating to particular groups and particular conditions. The object of these preventive health policies is to address those major disadvantaged groups and those major health inequalities which exist in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to his statement in the House last night that he had `entirely valid entry documents to enter Japan'. What were those documents? Where and when were those documents issued or, where necessary, revalidated?

—We do not call the honourable member for Mackellar `Carlton Light' for nothing. The answer is that the visa was issued by the Government of Japan in Australia and is current for four years. That is all one needs. That is how one gets into Japan. One needs a visa, which I had. That is why there was no issue whatsoever. The passport is only the vehicle that carries the visa.
—Ah!
—If little Johnnie does not know that, he does not know very much.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOBS, EDUCATION AND TRAINING SCHEME FOR SOLE PARENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security explain to the House who will benefit from the Government's new jobs, education and training scheme for sole parents? Can the Minister advise the House whether this scheme will assist to meet the Government's social justice objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The jobs, education and training scheme, known as JET, like the new start program, is a scheme designed by this Labor Government to harness the energies of different departments to help those with chronic labour market disabilities. It will provide sole parent pensioners with needs assessment, advice, counselling and assistance through my Department; improved income security through Austudy and formal training allowance paid by the Department of Employment, Education and Training; access to education and labour market programs; and child care tailored to their education, training or employment choices. It will deliver lasting employment to sole parents and enable them to join the mainstream of community life.

ANSWER.PARA: The great social tragedy of Australia in the 1970s and 1980s has been the explosion in the number of sole parent families and the marginalisation of sole parents in the labour market. In 1974 there were 105,000 sole parent pensioners, constituting 57.4 per cent of all sole parents. By 1983-there was reference to our period in government-after seven years of Opposition rule, 82 per cent of sole parents were pensioners. There were 252,000 families with only one parent and dependent on a pension. This tragedy was brought about through income security policies that imprisoned people in poverty traps, the lack of child care and community attitudes that excluded sole parents from the mainstream. Over the past two years we have substantially improved the income security aspects of that particular problem by lifting the free areas and introducing earnings credit and, most recently, the separate income test on maintenance.

The jobs, education and training program now addresses the other labour market dis- abilities of sole parents, including those who have been on pension for more than a year and whose youngest child is at school. These people will be in the prime of their working lives and with appropriate assistance will be prevented from long term marginalisation in the labour market. The second group will be those whose youngest child is 14 or over. Eligibility for sole parent pension finishes when the youngest child turns 16. These people will be needing to join the labour force within a couple of years; so we will provide every help for them to do that. The third group is teenage sole parents. One of the great myths of this country is that the explosion of sole parent numbers is due to teenagers having babies so that they can go on the pension. Of course, this is a myth and a lie. In 1979--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I hope that the honourable member will listen to this because in the social security portfolio there is no greater disability than ignorance in the community about the characteristics of the population of those on pensions and benefits. Day after day one has to face the kind of rubbish that is constantly talked about the sole parent population and is often spread by people in the Opposition who had responsibility in that portfolio in the past, including the honourable member opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1979, 4.2 per cent of female sole parent pensioners were teenagers. By 1986 this figure had fallen to 2.4 per cent. The typical sole parent is not a teenager. Yet again and again the barrier to the formation of constructive social policy in this area has been the perpetuation of that kind of mythology. Indeed, it is only since this Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't any moral fibre, Brian.

—The honourable member talks about moral fibre. Was it moral fibre that resulted in the situation in which young kids aged 16 and 17 years were being paid $20 for educational support in the education system? Was that moral fibre compared with the $50 they are currently receiving? Was it moral fibre that produced a situation in which more than 100,000 young people were thrown on to the unemployment benefit scrapheap and given no alternative? Was it moral fibre that left the family allowance--
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. The Minister's rhetoric is obviously irrelevant to the question.
—Does the honourable member have a point of order? I call the Minister.
—Was it moral fibre that left the assistance for children in pensioner and beneficiary families $20 and $30 below the poverty line?
—I rise again on a point of order, Madam Speaker. I ask you to rule on whether the rhetoric of the Minister is relevant to the question he was asked.
—Order! Honourable members on my right were not asked to rule; I was. Yes, it is relevant to the question.

—Was it moral fibre that in the Opposition's seven years in government, given the explosion in the number of sole parents, it failed to produce a policy anything like equivalent to the child support scheme that this Government has introduced? Was it moral fibre that produced the kinds of poverty traps that meant that when we came into government less than one-third of sole parents were effectively within the work force in the conditions of a debilitated economy?

ANSWER.PARA: The issue that the honourable member for Chifley draws attention to is the plight of a group of people in the Australian population acknowledged by every major welfare organisation as being the poorest group. That poverty was exacerbated desperately during the Opposition's period in government. During our period in government we have slowly but surely constructed what I believe will be recognised as one of the most progressive social policies with respect to this group in any country in the world. At a recent meeting with social policy Ministers at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, which I chaired, it was acknowledged that the polices being developed in this country with respect to sole parents were amongst the most advanced, if not the most advanced, in the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is one again for the Treasurer and it follows on from the question I asked last. Was he travelling on a valid passport or had it expired?

—The honourable member for Mackellar last night wrote to me and then raised matters in the Parliament, the specific charge being that I had breached Japanese law. Because of the nature of this charge--

—Yes, it was; it was in the letter. Because of the nature of this charge, embassy officials in Japan were asked to contact the Japanese foreign ministry. The head of the Japanese consular and immigration affairs bureau confirmed that this was not the case and that my visa was current.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! The Treasurer will resume his seat.
—Sit down, sit down.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will not usurp the Chair's authority. The Treasurer will resume his seat. I am now hearing a point of order from the honourable member for North Sydney.
—Madam Speaker, now that puffing Billy has exhausted himself--
—Just get on with the point of order.

—Can I return to the point of order, Madam Speaker, which is simply this: a very direct question was put to the Treasurer that admits of a simple yes or no answer. He was asked whether he was travelling on a valid passport or whether it had expired.
—The Treasurer will answer the question himself. He does not have to answer the question as you request him.
—Madam Speaker, may I put the point of order? He then went on to talk about Japanese law. Japanese law has nothing to do with the validity of Australian passports.

The point of order is whether or not it is in order for a person to raise a point of order in this place and at the same time go to matters of order in this House which only you, Madam Speaker, can deal with. This is a persistent pattern of behaviour from the honourable member for North Sydney-to hector you on what was clearly your role in this House, and that is to determine whether or not a person should be seated when a matter is raised.
