—Madam Speaker--
—Madam Speaker--
—The Treasurer will resume his seat.
—Madam Speaker, on the point of order--
—The honourable member will wait until I call him. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—Madam Speaker, have you just suggested to the House that it is not proper for a member to resume his seat when you tell him and it is not proper, as has been suggested by the Leader of the House, that on a point of order the other party must resume his seat? Will you clarify that please?

—What I said to the honourable member for North Sydney was that when I ask the Treasurer to resume his seat it is my authority; it is not for the honourable member for North Sydney to stand at the dispatch box and tell the Treasurer to sit down. That is my right and I will protect my right and the House will protect my right to protect my right.

—Madam Speaker, I will pick up the sentence where I left off. The head of the consular and immigration affairs bureau in Japan confirmed that this was not the case and that the visa which I had was current and that the Japanese regarded my entry as completely legitimate. Further, the Australian Embassy in Japan did not provide any assistance whatsoever to me in relation to my passport or my entry requirements to Japan which would not have been provided to any other Australian citizen.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—This is all. I will get to that part of the question. This is all relevant to the matters raised.
—The Treasurer will please resume his seat.

—Madam Speaker, the Treasurer has just said that he would get to the point and that these matters are relevant to the matters raised. The question, I remind you, Madam Speaker, is whether or not he was travelling on a valid passport.
—I remind the honourable member for North Sydney that the Treasurer is answering the question in his way.
—I submit, Madam Speaker, that does not come anywhere near being relevant.
—The Treasurer is answering the question in his own way.
—Madam Speaker--
—It is not for the Chair to tell the Treasurer what to say.
—Madam Speaker, it is not for the Chair to tell the Treasurer what to say, but to remind the Treasurer of the duty of relevance and to ensure that he is relevant.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Could you provide the honourable member for North Sydney with a copy of standing order 145. I am sure that with a lot of difficulty he could read.

—Again, I repeat the point that no assistance was provided to me that would not be provided to any Australian citizen in the circumstances. Let me deal with the specific point, now that the Opposition has shifted its ground off the Japanese visa, and make this point: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade makes it clear that, unless specific information on a person is held in the Customs computer which prohibits the exit from Australia of that person under the Migration Act of Australia, citizens are free to leave Australia when they choose. Nor do immigration officials have the right to insist that people have a valid passport. What immigration authorities have to do is satisfy themselves as to the citizenship of the persons leaving Australia.
—Why do we have this explanation--
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will cease interjecting.

—In my case, my citizenship was not in question because all MPs have to be Australian citizens. Of course, many people lose passports, leave them in airport terminals and still catch aircraft. All that has to be settled is whether they are citizens.
—So it does not matter?
—In this case it did not matter.
—What about your--
—This is little Enoch having a go here--
—What about your passport?

—They are great little mates-`Yellow Fever' and little Enoch, both in full flight. The fact of the matter is that my passport has been extended eight times in five years. The diplomatic passports issued to diplomats are valid for five years. Passports issued to MPs are valid for the period of the Parliament. We have had the practice of validating Ministers' passports for three, four and six months at a time and this is why mine was overlooked. When the entry-- Mr Beale-Oh!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Deakin that if he continues to interrupt I will deal with him.

—There is no requirement. I was invited by the Department of Foreign Affairs to validate the passport, if I wished, in Tokyo, which I did. But the relevant issue is that I had a fully valid Japanese entry visa and that is all that matters. This issue ranks with Mr Carlton's inquiries about my son's broken arm when he went into hospital in 1984.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. That is a gross misuse of Question Time, as the Treasurer understands, and I am sure you will uphold relevance on this occasion.
—Order! The Treasurer would understand that his son's broken arm is not relevant to the question.

—Madam Speaker, these matters have been raised against me before. It is relevant that snide investigations were made by the honourable member for Mackellar about my son's hospitalisation, by this Uriah Heep over here. He--
—Order!
—Madam Speaker, are you going to uphold the point on relevance?
—Order! The Treasurer will not go down that path.
—It is relevant, Madam Speaker. It has been raised three times by this loon over here.
—Not in this House. The Chair is asking you to resume your seat.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is quite irrelevant and also totally untrue.
—Order! The Chair is dealing with it and needs no help.

—Madam Speaker, let me deal with the point of order on the question of relevance. The honourable member for Mackellar received stolen documents in the case of correspondence between me and the Australian Taxation Office and he brought them here. He is a receiver and handler of stolen documents.
—Order! The Treasurer will not continue down this path.
—He now has this information. He had snide investigations made of my son's--

—Order! The Treasurer will resume his seat. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat. The question and answer are at an end.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I might add that it is very important to this country, not like the last question, that rubbish that we had.
—Order! The honourable member will get on with his own question.

—Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that yesterday an Adelaide man had the tyres of his car slashed and his garage burnt down as a reprisal for a letter which was published in the Adelaide Advertiser condemning the so-called one Australia policy of the Leader of the Opposition? Further, has the Minister's attention been drawn to another disturbing incident where prominent and respected senior journalist Max Walsh had his home and his wife's car attacked by members of a racist group known as National Action who with aerosol cans of paint drew obscenities and left their signature, namely the swastika? Can the Minister assure the House that the Government's approach to the migration debate and its policies will not incite the kind of community divisiveness which has occurred since the Leader of the Opposition entered the debate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bowman for his question. I am aware of the issues that he raised. I think I should begin to answer them by drawing the attention of the House to the statements made in the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which has been the subject of considerable misinterpretation by the Leader of the Opposition and other members of the Opposition. I refer to page 6 of that report where it says:

ANSWER.PARA: and it is talking about the question of Asian immigration-

. . . five out of the 587 individuals we spoke to were overtly against Asian immigrants on grounds of nothing other than race. And the written submissions from organisations representing hundreds of thousands of Australians and from many individuals did not even take this as an issue.
Racism is by no means excised from Australia. The potential for bigotry sleeps within most individuals, and racism in many forms pervades our society.
It goes on to say-and this is the important thing:

Systematic discrimination also is not excised from our society. But in the immigration context it is not yet apparent that such discrimination is directed at Asian immigrants more than other immigrant groups.
The report went on to say:

But we have now had Asian immigration for more than a decade, and empirical evidence tells us that we have not had race riots or many of the other social problems the opponents of Asian immigration have been predicting since the beginning.

I remind the House that the FitzGerald Committee was in session for over 12 months. It received over a thousand representations from the most widely based groups in Australian society. It spent more than 10 days eliciting oral information from people who had given written submissions. At the end of that time, what the Committee has told the people of Australia and what it has told this House is that there was no evidence that could be found which suggested that there was any level of overt racism directed against Asian immigrants which it would regard as of any serious kind.

What has happened since then? The honourable member has drawn my attention and the House's attention to a number of serious incidents. Let us just look at it. A respected political journalist, Max Walsh, following a well considered article, which was a legitimate contribution to the whole immigration debate, was critical of the Opposition's policy proposals. What was the result? Within 24 hours his wife's car and his neighbour's car were spray painted with swastikas and obscenities. That occurred in August of this year. An Adelaide man wrote a letter to the editor condemning the Opposition policy. His garage was subsequently set alight by white supremacists who threatened in a phone call to burn down his house next time. That also occurred in August of this year. My colleague--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. I take great exception to a comment from the Government benches accusing the National Party of certain acts.
—Order! I cannot hear the honourable member for Cowper.
—I ask that person to withdraw.
—Order! I did not hear the point of order.
—It is beyond the pale, Madam Speaker. It is totally unacceptable.
—I am sorry, I did not catch the inference.

—My colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh was present when a citizenship ceremony was broken up by virtue of people objecting to Australian residents of Asian origin being sworn in as Australian citizens. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has had a brick put through his window on the basis of his support for a non-discriminatory policy. He has been informed that next time it will be a bomb.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me also deal with a further aspect of this matter which I think is in the same league and raises the same issue. The Reverend Dorothy McMahon of the Pitt Street Uniting Church, by virtue of her commitment to an Australian society that will not harbour racial intolerance, found that buckets of faeces, vomit and rotting material were spread all over her front verandah and stuffed in her letterbox. Her church was raided and swastikas placed in various parts. All this has happened within the course of the last two months following a report from an independent committee that pointed out that Australia was free of this type of activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any doubt that all members of this honourable House would condemn those activities. I say publicly, as I have said on many occasions-and I do not recant--

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. Somebody on the other side of the House keeps saying a particular name. I take offence to it. Why blame somebody for this? The honourable member is only stirring up this trouble. I would like him not to use that name. He is just stirring up trouble.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—You are trying to promote a racist debate. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
—Order! Honourable members on my right are not assisting the Chair.

—I am told by the Leader of the National Party of Australia that I am trying to promote a racist debate. Let me quote to the Leader of the National Party not my view-because I have been very careful to be more than generous to the honourable gentlemen opposite-but the words of the Reverend Dorothy McMahon, who was not trying to promote a racist debate but was a victim of these activities. What did she say? She said that there is a rise in racist views. She continued:

ANSWER.PARA: Anyone who has travelled round the inner-west of this city has seen a rising number of incidents where ordinary Asians on a bus are abused in the most obscene and horrible way.

She goes on to say-and I think this ought to be borne in mind by all who want to partake in this debate in some sensible and rational way-that although she does not believe, as I do not believe, that the Leader of the Opposition is in any way racist, what he has done has been to open up an issue. She rightly points out that when he says that we have to lower the Asian intake, he is dealing with race issues, not immigration issues. I do not believe, as I have said publicly, that the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party are racists. But I do believe that when we see this sort of evidence, which has no place in Australian society, it is time to stop and think and reflect. What is occurring is not the mounting of a racist debate. But what they have done, by the kinds of statements that have been made about Asian immigration and about Australian citizens of Asian origin, is open up an issue in such a way that some lunatic groups with xenophobic racist traditions in this society now believe that they can act with freedom and that their racist attitudes can assume a veneer of respectability. This Opposition, in seeking and chasing votes, has abandoned its own philosophies and its own traditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications Support advise the House whether an ordinary Australian would be allowed aboard an international carrier bound for an overseas destination with an expired passport?

—To the best of my knowledge it is not a matter of my responsibility. The Leader of the National Party will recall that when he presents himself for departure at international airports he submits his documents to a member of the Australian Customs Service, not to a member of the Department of Transport and Communications.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of claims that the Government has been less than forthcoming about the details of his agreement with the New Zealand Agriculture Minister on free and fair trade in dairy products? Can the Minister advise the House of the truth of such claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of politically inspired nonsense circulated by National Party members and candidates about what is being proposed in relation to dairy trade between Australia and New Zealand. Last night in a general omnibus Bill on primary industry matters, both the Deputy Leader of the National Party and the honourable member for Wannon claimed that there was no knowledge of these documents. It culminated yesterday in the House when the Deputy Leader and the honourable member for Wannon, whose local Liberal Party is under pressure from the National Party for the next Victorian election, called upon me to table an exchange of letters I had with my New Zealand counterpart, Colin Moyle, on the dairy issue. Far be it from me to say that Mr Saunders, who is President of the United Dairyfarmers of Victoria and has been twice rejected for Liberal pre-selection, now has National Party pre-selection in the upper House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the answer given a moment ago by the Minister for Transport and Communications Support, I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Customs--
—I am the Minister for Customs.
—I ask a question of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business.
—He is a very proper Minister.

—He is a very proper Minister, as the Prime Minister says. Will the Minister advise the House whether an ordinary Australian presenting an expired passport to an international carrier when that person was travelling to an overseas destination would be permitted to board the aircraft for that destination?

—So far as the Australian Customs Service is concerned, when Mr Keating's passport was presented to the Customs officer at barrier control, it was drawn to his attention that the passport had expired. He was then referred to an officer of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and he was allowed to proceed on the basis that his identity was not in doubt. It is quite correct that there are some internal procedures, which we are all familiar with internationally, where airlines, even more than Customs authorities, often make the determination whether or not they will take out the ticket voucher and allow people to go on. As far asCustoms is concerned, there is no doubt-- Mr Howard-Did you have a look at that? That is what your Department issued. Did he have another valid passport issued?

—He went with a valid visa which covered the relevant period and, as far as Customs was concerned, providing it was satisfied of his identity as an Australian citizen he had a perfect right to travel.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I ask: Is the Minister aware of comments concerning higher education places made by the honourable member for Mackellar in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August, who said that `the extra 3,500 to 4,000 places promised in the Budget did little more than make up for cuts announced in the May economic statement'? Can the Minister inform the House whether that statement is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting for some time for a substantial contribution to the debate on higher education from the Opposition spokesman. There used to be a time when he would number his Press statements, but I now see he has given up that practice. No doubt he is embarrassed by the scant contribution he has made to this debate over the last year or so. Over the last couple of days there has been some rather uncharacteristic exertion on his part. He offered a comment on Budget night and then produced a more fulsome statement yesterday. However, in many respects he has got many of the Government's details absolutely wrong, and I will mention those in a moment.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps if he had applied himself a bit more energetically to his shadow responsibilities rather than running around with a squalid little attempt to try to embarrass the Treasurer, then he might have known more about what the Government has said on this, probably the most historic statement on higher education in the country's history. On the night of the Budget he said that the 3,500 to 4,000 places would only compensate for the cuts we made in May. Point No. 1 is that we made no cuts in May. Point No. 2 is that it is not 3,500 to 4,000 places but 40,000 places over the next three years.

He then went on to say in his more fulsome statement yesterday that it would cost someone who had completed a doctorate of philosophy something in the order of $14,400 as a result of the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, quite ignoring the fact that we made it very clear that PhD students and masters students will be exempt from the consequences of the higher education contribution scheme. In fact, 15,000 free places will be made available, which will be allocated by the institutions in order to support a mere 7,000 or 8,000 students who are currently undertaking PhDs and masters by the research mode.

He went on to talk about the disincentive effects of the higher education contribution scheme, quite ignoring the fact that we are removing the one up front charge that currently exists, the administration charge. Of course, there will be no compulsory requirement to pay any up front charge. The honourable member talked about our scheme being one which involves disincentives, quite ignoring his own incongruous and incomprehensible policy, which would require students to pay up to $10,000 a year if they were not fortunate enough to get one of the limited places that would be made available. Of course, the people from the more underprivileged backgrounds would be the ones confronted with this $10,000 a year charge and, therefore, quite clearly would be prevented from entering the higher education system at all. We all know that this shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mackellar, is about to re-enter the revolving door of the Leader of the Opposition and will be circulated off the front bench, of course. At least when that happens there might be some opportunity of getting a sensible debate on these important matters.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Mackellar moving forthwith a motion of censure of the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Treasurer be censured for his failure to produce a current passport during his recent visit to Japan and for failing to observe the rules which are followed by all other Australians.

Yesterday I had information which I had considered for some little time. This information-I thought it was fairly reliable information-indicated to me that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on an official visit to Japan during July had appeared at the airport without valid travel documents. I was not certain from the information whether the Treasurer had a valid and current visa or whether he had a valid and current passport. This is a serious matter because the Treasurer, after all, has a record of not following the rules that other Australians are supposed to follow. It will be recalled that this is the same person who, some time ago, in filling in a travel allowance claim for this Parliament, put down on the form an uninhabited dwelling as his principal place of residence-certainly a place where his family did not live and by any ordinary definition was not his principal place of residence. There was not a single observer in the whole of Australia who believed that that travel claim was valid.

The Government, instead of requiring that the Treasurer withdraw that claim, tried to change the rules to obfuscate, to shift on sand, and to tough it out. That, in fact, is what it did. The Treasurer was supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Cabinet colleagues. Against the wishes of most honourable members opposite he persisted with that claim which nobody believed was a fair claim. That controversy went on for some time. It was then brought to my attention that there could be a case against the Treasurer that he had failed to put in a tax return on time. A letter came into my possession which, if it were correct, would have been very damaging to the Treasurer. I did what I believed was the correct thing. I wrote to the Treasurer asking whether this document was a fake. I thought it was only fair to to ask him on a confidential basis. I wanted to ask him whether this was true before I raised it publicly. If indeed it were not true and if it had been proved not to be true, I would not have raised it at all. That is the decent way to do things.

I also recall that when I was shadow Minister for health I adopted exactly the same principle when I approached the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) on a matter which was potentially embarrassing for him to assure myself that the facts were correct before I raised it in the House. I might say, given the attack on me by the Treasurer last night and again today relating to a medical incident within his own family, that of course when I was Minister for Health I had dozens of allegations that Ministers in the Government were adopting double standards by recommending Medicare free hospital beds to everybody else, putting them into the queue. I had many such allegations made to me and stories brought to my attention but in no case did I use any of those without reference to the person concerned. In this case, as the Treasurer well knows, this matter was not raised by me and there were many such allegations brought to my attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was.
—Show me the public record.
—I know you were ringing the hospitals.

—The Minister should show me the records of my ringing the hospitals. In all cases I have acted honourably in these matters. Therefore when I had the information yesterday which I believed was most likely to be true I wrote to the Treasurer at lunch time and asked whether he could by 6 o'clock show me evidence that this was clearly not true and, if so, the matter would not be raised publicly. Throughout the afternoon yesterday, when I tried to contact the Treasurer's senior private secretary he was not available. At a quarter to six I made an attempt to get through to the senior private secretary and the Treasurer. I was told that they did not want to respond or know about it. I therefore believed that I had a duty to raise the matter. The results of what has happened here clearly justify entirely my inquiries and certainly justify my raising this matter in the House. Last night there was an attempt by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and the Treasurer to obscure this whole matter by turning it into a direct attack on me and to skate over the facts of the matter so as to leave the House in some doubt as to what had actually occurred. Last night the Leader of the House said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have had an opportunity to discuss this matter briefly with the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He has pointed out to me that he entered Japan on a perfectly valid basis. He had a visa that was current for Japan.
The Treasurer uttered but one sentence relating to the actual matter before indulging in his typical abuse. He said:
. . . I did have entirely valid entry documents to enter Japan.

The question is: Did he have entirely valid entry documents to enter Japan when, as he has admitted, his passport was out of date? Is a visa valid if it is not attached to a valid passport? When the Treasurer turned up at the airport did he, like everybody else, go to the Qantas desk? Qantas staff members usually ask, `Where are you going? Let us have a look at your ticket'. They want to know whether one has a passport and a valid document for entry into that country. The airlines have to worry about that first before the passenger gets to the customs and immigration desk. If an ordinary Joe Blow gets to a country and is not admitted, he is shuffled back on the same airline and the airline has to meet the cost. In the case of some countries there is also a fine on the airline for depositing people who do not have valid entry documents.

It has been suggested by the Treasurer and other Ministers that Australians can leave Australia without an up to date passport. Indeed, on a radio program in Sydney this morning the interviewer said that it had happened to him. But the question with regard to passports really is: Is it satisfactory for everybody-ordinary citizens-to turn up at the airport wanting to go overseas without a currently valid passport? Is that satisfactory? This is very much like the situation of putting in one's tax returns. We remember the notorious answer that the Prime Minister gave to this House when it was found that the Treasurer, for two successive years, had not put his tax return in on time. The Prime Minister said, `It is not an important matter'. Yet taxpayers in Australia know that if one does not put in one's tax return on time one is likely to be subjected to a fine and extra tax. That is what happens. However, in the case of the Treasurer, it did not seem to matter. The Prime Minister said that it was not a very important matter. We therefore come to this point: Is it suggested that it does not really matter much if Australian citizens, wanting to go overseas, turn up at the airport without a current passport? What will happen if this is encouraged? Should the people in our overseas Foreign Affairs and Trade posts, whose job it is to look after our interests abroad, be spending time dealing with expired passports and revalidating them overseas, as happened in this case?

All I can say is that we have to ask exactly what happened at the airport, because it is not absolutely clear. What did Qantas say about this? Did Qantas question whether the passport was up to date? Did Qantas pick up the fact that the visa had expired? Was there in fact a current visa? The Treasurer said that there was, although one questions the exact detail of what he said because he was very careful with his wording last night. Last night he said very carefully:
. . . I did have entirely valid entry documents to enter Japan.

Did Qantas pick up the fact that the Treasurer did not have a current passport? Did Qantas pick up the fact that the visa might have been invalid without a vehicle on which to be attached? Surely, with Qantas, the policy for ordinary Australians is that the passport has to be valid at the time of check-in. That is the question. Will Qantas let any ordinary Australian go overseas without a valid passport? I ask honourable members what would happen if they fronted up to the Qantas barrier with a passport that was out of date. Would they get on the plane? That is the real question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas runs us now, do they?

—The Treasurer has asked whether Qantas runs us now. The Treasurer must be suggesting that it is perfectly all right for Qantas and also Customs and immigration control at Sydney Airport to let people through willy-nilly without a passport. Is that what the Treasurer is suggesting? Is that what the Government is suggesting?
—What are you suggesting?

—I am suggesting to the honourable member for Prospect that there are certain rules that Australians, by and large, are expected to observe. They include being totally honest about one's travel claims. They include putting in one's tax returns on time. They include having an up to date passport when one travels overseas. All I can say about this is that if these rules do not apply to all Australians equally, if it is a question of some people being able to ignore them because they are so busy or so high and mighty, democracy in Australia is at a very low point.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one thing about this country that is very important: the rule of law applies to everybody. The rule of law is interpreted in various ways and there are certain aspects of conduct with regard to the law which mean that if the laws are not universally observed by everybody, and people agree to do that, society becomes totally unmanageable. I think it is incumbent on those who aspire to leadership of this country to set an example in these matters.

In this case obviously the passport should have been in order. If this had been the first time that something of this kind had come to people's attention, of course, it would be considered a relatively trivial matter. Anybody can make a mistake. The trouble is that the Treasurer does not give a damn. That is what is at the heart of this matter. The Treasurer treats ordinary people and the way they have to do things with absolute contempt. He treats the members of this Parliament with contempt. He treats with contempt the rules that they have to follow in regard to their travel allowances. He treats with contempt a member of parliament who asks, in private, a legitimate question in the public interest. The Treasurer treats with contempt a member of parliament who says that he will not raise the matter publicly if he gets a satisfactory answer and that he will not go to the press behind the Treasurer's back or anything like that. That person is attacked in this House for doing the decent thing because what he brings up is uncomfortable for the Treasurer.

When I was the Treasurer's opposite number in this House, he refused time and time again to do his duty in this chamber on Bills. He brought in 800 pages of tax legislation but he hardly ever came in at the end of the debate to sum up and answer queries. He treated the Parliament with contempt when he brought in the explanatory memorandum when the debate on the capital gains tax was concluding. If any honourable member dares to question him, even in private, he will come in here and try to destroy the reputation of that person and attack him personally. In the debate on this matter last night the Treasurer raised something about his own family which I, five years ago, determinately did not raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you did it underhand, that is why.

—I did not do it in an underhand fashion. There is no way that I could have raised that matter without going to the Treasurer. There were other suggestions that Labor Party members were adopting double standards when they said that getting in the Medicare queue was good enough for everybody else, but when they ensured that they were ahead of the queue by having private insurance. Of course, there were dozens of such allegations. No doubt there were dozens of such cases. But I would not raise, and have not raised, any of those matters publicly before going to the person concerned. In those cases and in this case I did the right thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I am simply not prepared as a representative of an electorate of the Australian people and a member of the House of Representatives in this new Parliament House to bow to the arrogance of somebody who believes he is beyond question. I say again: if this matter had been the first such case and; if the Treasurer over a period had behaved in a way that indicated he had respect for the way in which ordinary Australians had to operate and the various rules they had to follow the matter would not have been pursued or, if it had been pursued, it would not have mattered. The Treasurer quite rightly could have come into the House and said `This is a trivial matter. Don't bother me with it. I was extremely busy and my staff made a mistake'. As I said before, anybody can make a mistake but, fundamentally, the Treasurer does not give a damn. It is time that we called a halt to this kind of behaviour. It is time that the House demanded of the Treasurer exactly the same courtesies as it gets from most other Ministers. These are the kinds of courtesies that members of the backbench of the Australian Labor Party would like to see from the Treasurer in their own Caucus room.

Certainly, when we look to the future and to whether there is any possibility whatsoever of the current Treasurer succeeding the Prime Minister, the kinds of questions that we raise are critical to that kind of decision. The standards that people must have in order to retain public confidence are the sorts of standards that this Treasurer has consistently broken. Therefore, we move a motion of censure of the Treasurer for his failure to travel without a current passport; for his failure to do what every ordinary Australian ought to do. We do this not because it represents a single incident but because it forms part of a pattern. It is a pattern which is not acceptable to the vast bulk of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unbelievable that upon the presentation of a national Budget, particularly one with such dimensions and aggregates, and important as it is to remove from the landscape of Australia this massive Budget imbalance, to produce a strong surplus, to see strong investment, to see a continuing massive structural change in the Australian economy, the only thing that can be raised by the Opposition is whether my passport was valid to the date when I left on a trip abroad. That is the weighty question here.
—Was it valid?
—I have already said what the position was.
—Are you telling the truth?
—The Opposition was heard in relative silence, Mr Deputy Speaker. I expect the same courtesy to be extended to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A censure motion is one of the most important motions to be moved in the House. The Treasurer has the right to defend himself and should be heard in silence.

—This is the best that the Opposition can do. Why are Opposition members taking this course today? It is because they are embarrassed by their seamy race policy, which they know is to be debated. They want to blur the next day's newspaper reports because while I was going to Japan to try to promote this country, to improve relations between our countries and to give the Japanese a better understanding of our economy-and us a better understanding of theirs-the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was saying to those people, `We might like your business, but we don't like you because of the colour of your skin and the way your face is'. That is what this fuss is all about. While I was in Japan to try to improve Australia's position, those opposite were saying, `We will have your money and your business, but we don't like you-we don't like your genetic makeup, and we will restrict the number of people like you who come to this country'. Note that distinction between the attitude of this Government and the play on race which is going on within the Opposition. That is why those opposite are worried about this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) interjects in this debate. He came into this country as a yellow fever risk and got off prosecution because of a technicality in the law which would have disqualified him as a member of parliament. He was wandering around Brisbane as a yellow fever risk against the wishes of the Commonwealth health authorities, and he has the hide to interject about my passport date. What an unbelievably terrible government those in the Opposition would make. One can imagine people's rights being swept away one after the other as the Opposition's mad, manic, fascist views extended right through the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has been running around with his papers, but he is a nobody in Australian public life. He was supposed to be one of the comers in the Liberal Party. He was a failure as Minister for Health. When he was shadow Treasurer, it was like taking candy off kids. He did not understand even the structure of the debate. The Leader of the Opposition correctly put him to the back bench at the time. The honourable member for Mackellar is back on the front bench now. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) said, the honourable member is not even involved in the education debate. He has always put himself up as one of the coming people in the coalition. Not only does he not have a future; he does not even have a past. His past is in Ash Street in the former Liberal Party headquarters in Sydney, where he was president, where all this seamy race politics and cynicism began, and where they were taught in the old Askin school of Australian politics. He stands up here making a pretentious, unctuous stand: `I raise this matter about the Treasurer's passport in the public interest'. It is unbelievable. `I did the decent thing', he said. The unctuous pontificating behaviour of the man! This is the person who, as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) said, was running around with private details of his daughter's hospital treatment-this fellow, the member for Mackellar. The reason he did not raise my son's hospitalisation was that basically the information he got did not suit him. But he rang the hospital; I was told about it. He is a snide, underhand little man. He gets around the corridors; he says, `Hello, Paul, how are you?', smiling in corridors and at the airport. He is a Uriah Heep. He is one of these sanctimonious, obsequious people like Uriah Heep. He tugs his forelock, but comes in here with his horns out. He is a nasty, dirty little character, and that is the fact.

The honourable member for Mackellar sends me a threatening letter and I am supposed to say, `Oh, Jim Carlton has sent me a letter. Get a reply back'. My staff said, `He's ringing again'. I said, `The dog may bark, but the caravan moves on. Ignore him. Don't worry about him'. He had to raise this matter in the public interest; we know that. He is honourable, but if one gets caught with someone else's letter one gets a fine which carries a criminal penal sanction which disqualifies one as a member of parliament. He handled the stolen material addressed to me from the Australian Taxation Office. That will go against him and the Leader of the Opposition all their lives. They handled stolen material and were happy to handle it. Yet the honourable member for Mackellar stands up in this place and says how honourable and decent he is. He would not know what decency was.

This is a matter that a decent person would regard basically as a minor clerical issue, but not the honourable member for Mackellar. He can see none of the big picture, none of the stuff about the economy, none of the change, none of the history, none of the magnitude, none of the prospects-no, he is on about whether, of all things, I had a valid passport when I left Australia. There is no requirement in law to have such a thing. This is a free country. He keeps saying that, but does not understand what it is. He thinks that there is a wall or a barrier around this country and that people are only given the right to leave. That happens behind the Iron Curtain, but not in this country. People have the right to leave this country. The passport is merely an identification of the person concerned and that is all. The mere presence of a visa is to say that the Japanese authorities or the authorities in any other country have identified the person and permitted entry. There is no question about the passport needing to be valid. It is that the visa is valid because the consular officer has identified the person and said that the person is free to travel to that country. That is the issue.

The only interest Qantas Airways Ltd has is that the people who board its aircraft are not imprisoned on it and can deplane in the country of destination. That is all. In this case Qantas looked only for my Japanese visa, which was totally valid and intact. When I said that my passport date had expired, the officer at Sydney said, `That is no problem. You can have it revalidated in Japan. The only thing you need is a visa, which you have'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that, or did they state that?
—They said that.
—I asked whether you said it?

—Here is old `Yellow Fever', wandering around with a bad dose of yellow fever or potentially so. He has a rush of yellow fever to the brain or something. Here is the Opposition-talk about a bunch of indecent, incompetent, mediocrities! We have the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) continually raising points of order. He is always talking about fairness, but he will not let people make their arguments without his getting up on a point of order. He knows that these are all personal matters, but if anyone raises a personal matter about him he goes berserk. Opposition members should understand that, if they want to make this par for the course, we will always join them on these things. We will join issue, sir. I cannot get the right tone; but the honourable member will know what I mean.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that I have done nothing wrong whatsoever. The problem is-and I say this advisedly-that there is a practice in the Department of Foreign Affairs whereby members of the Diplomatic Service have a five-year diplomatic passport, staff of Ministers have a passport to the end of the parliamentary period, but Ministers get three and four months validation, which is a foolish way to behave in terms of their passports. I have had eight validations of this passport in five years. The fact that this was some weeks out of date but to be validated a day or two later in Tokyo is of no significance as to its validity because it merely is to identify me as who I am. That should not be a problem with the officers in Sydney, and it was not. That is why they so advised me. There is no problem here; no problem whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Double standards.

—There are no double standards. It has been implied that some favour was done for me. The honourable member for Mackellar said that Qantas did me some favour. It did not, it just looked at my Japanese entry visa. The fact is that no favours were done for me by Qantas, the Australian immigration authorities in Australia, our authorities in Tokyo or the Japanese authorities in Tokyo. It was a visit entirely free of any intervention by any of these people. I had no special treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: How many people in this chamber, as members of parliament, have had people ringing up saying they have lost their passport or it is invalid and they have to travel abroad the next day because someone is ill or has died? How many times over 20 years would that have happened? Dozens. What happens if somebody loses a passport in a hotel room in Singapore? Can he not come back to Australia? Would the authorities say to the Leader of the Opposition, `Sorry, Mr Howard, you have lost your passport in Singapore so you will have to stay there'.

Little John thinks he is on to an issue. The Leader of the Opposition has become the most diminutive figure in Australian public life. He has stuck to no principle; he has no political character and no personal character. He is into the unseemly business of race. While I was running around in Japan-and, I might say, all day every day and every evening-trying to promote this country and to learn about the situation, he was saying, `We don't think we will have people from Asia in our country because they have yellow skin and we do not like the shape of their eyes. We will cut our intake of those people. It is all right, you can build your hotels here, we will still see those of you who have a bit of money, but you cannot come here because you have the wrong genetic makeup'.

This debate has been brought on today because the Opposition is all about checking on people, having a look at people to see what their makeup is. The Opposition wants to see what their antecedents are and whether they are fit and proper persons. All this is happening while the Government is trying to integrate Australia and the Australian economy into Asia. While representatives of the Government are in Tokyo trying to further integrate the Australian economy and the Australian people with those of the Asian region, members of the Opposition are down here doing the most disastrous, damaging thing that can be done to us as a European nation in Asia. They are putting the bar on us in the eyes of these people because they think we are going to have a racist policy under this Opposition. That is why the honourable member for Mackellar and all the rest of those opposite have raised the matter under debate. They have no policies; they have no structure. The worst thing is that they do not even have any common decency. That is why they remain on the Opposition benches. They keep laughing, but they keep coming back in opposition. The honourable member for Mackellar may wonder why he has been relegated to such an ordinary place in public life. The answer is that he is just a very ordinary little bloke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we have just heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) describe himself. How did he approach this motion of censure? He approached it by saying it was unbelievable. He said it was unbelievable that he should be censured. Why? Because he has just brought down a Budget, and if one brings down a Budget in this House, if one is the Treasurer of this country, one should not be censured. It does not matter, he would tell us, what he does; as long as he is here to bring down the Budget we should be talking about the Budget and not his conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: What was his conduct like today? What was his conduct like last night? Did we see the characteristics we would expect of a Treasurer or anybody of responsibility in a government? Did we see frankness? Did we see directness? Did we see a candid treatment of the issues? He was like a greased rat in a trap. Look at the words he used last night when he came into the chamber. They are just quintessential Keating. He said, after the honourable member for Mackeller (Mr Carlton) had raised this matter, perfectly properly and in neutral terms:
. . . I did have entirely valid entry documents to enter Japan.

One should take note of those words. He did not say, as he has been forced to say today, that his passport had expired. No, he did not say that. Honourable members will remember that when he was asked questions about this today he tried to slide through without being forced to make the admission. Why, we even heard him discourse on Japanese law. It is interesting that he should seek to do that in answer to a question that had nothing to do with Japanese law. What happened after the debate last night? He had people from his office brief the media. How did they do that? Again, with that frankness, with that directness, with that sincerity, and with that common decency for which he is the byword in this country. Michelle Grattan had this to say:
But a spokesman for Mr Keating said that no Australian or Japanese rule or regulation had been breached, and Mr Keating had not been treated differently from any other citizen.
In the Sun, Charles Happell said that a spokesman said on behalf of Mr Keating:
He broke no rule of law in either Japan or Australia and he received no preferential treatment either.

There are a lot of ordinary Australians here today, not members of parliament, and I guess a few of them have travelled outside this country, as most members here have. Does anybody in this House believe, does anybody in the gallery believe, does anybody outside the Parliament believe that if an ordinary Australian comes along and presents himself or herself to Qantas and says, `Look, my passport has expired but I have got a visa', Qantas will let that person on the plane? Everybody knows that that would not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Do I hear a few yeses? We heard the Treasurer say that, as well. How did the Treasurer deal with it today? He said he had done no wrong, and of course he engaged in his usual campaign of abuse. I will come back to that. He said, `Look, I was treated like any other Australian. I am just an ordinary fellow. I have a good understanding of common decency'. Why, the man is of course known for his common decency. He is known for his lack of arrogance, for his direct, open and easy relationship with the Australian people and his colleagues. He is known by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a person who is just sitting in the background waiting to help out, not trying to elbow him to one side.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us now see what the airlines do in the case of an ordinary citizen. It is very easy to find out. The airlines will tell us, because the airlines have laid down a set of procedures and these are applied rigidly to people who seek to leave the country. I suppose the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) may have looked at the travel information manual. If he has not, he might do so before he speaks. But he will not because it will not help him. The travel information manual is a joint publication put out by 14 International Air Transport Association airlines, including Qantas Airways Ltd. This is what the instructions say must be done. I refer first of all to what is said about passports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us the law.

—I hear the intervention, `That is not law'. The honourable member is right. I am not saying it is the law. What I said, if the honourable member had listened to me, was that the Treasurer claimed he was treated like anybody else, but the truth of the matter is that we all know he got special and privileged treatment. He has repeated again and again in this House the statement that he was treated just like anybody else. We know he was not telling the truth. Does anybody believe that that was the truth? The instructions read:

SPEECH.PARA: Passports: Check any passport as to expiry date.
The next item states:
Visas: Check any visa as to expiry date. Validity . . . Note: All visas in an expired passport are generally for that reason invalid.

Honourable members opposite cannot tell me that if John Citizen had turned up and said, `Look, I am going to Tokyo and I want to get on this flight' and Qantas had said, `Well, look, sir, your passport has expired', Qantas would have let him on board. Of course not. Do they think that Qantas would have had embassy officials waiting at the other end? Of course not. Let me go on with this because it gets even better. Everybody knows that these directions are followed by the airlines, because we have all travelled on airlines and had these things checked. It says:
Additional information: An unexpired visa in an expired passport may be used provided the passenger also carries a second valid passport which must be officially bound with the expired one.

Was the Treasurer carrying a second valid passport? He was not. Therefore, when he comes into this House and says that he was not treated differently from anybody else, that is not the truth. He knows it is not the truth. The Leader of the House knows it is not the truth and every honourable member on the Government side knows it is not the truth. Every person in the public gallery and anyone in this country who has travelled knows that it is not the truth.

The Treasurer says, `True it is I have come in here but why can't I come in here and deliberately misrepresent the position? Why couldn't I come in here last night and say that I was travelling on perfectly valid travel documents? Why can't I come in here today and seek to evade the issue?'. It was a perfectly simple question for an honest man to answer. What would an honest man have said? He would have said, `Yes, I went down there. I was a government official. I was travelling on highly important business and I asked to be given preferential treatment and I expected that I would get it. Yes, I had an expired passport'. That is what a lot of people would do. That is what an honest Minister would do. He would say, `Yes, that is what happened'. But did this man say that? No. Why? Because it fits in with the pattern of conduct of arrogance and deception.

Do honourable members remember what happened when the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) raised the taxation issue some time ago. Perhaps that is the reason why the Treasurer feels so strongly about the honourable member. The Treasurer came into this House and told us that in respect of the late lodgment of his taxation return he had been treated no differently from any other Australian. Do honourable members remember that? Did we believe it at the time? Did anybody in this country believe it? No. And what do we get? We get the same old record. The Treasurer knows that out in the electorate the Australian people believe him to be arrogant, removed, vain and pretentious. He loves the Australian people so much that he travels around behind tinted windows. If the Treasurer is the open, honest and decent Aussie that he says he is, why does he do that? His name is now a by-word for arrogance and parliamentary deceit. His remarks were not casual; they were not a slip of the tongue, but deliberate. The man was revealed at his best today. He was revealed with all those characteristics that he has sought to submerge because he wants to become respectable. He wants the people of Australia to forget that he gave a new notion, a new feeling, a new intensity to gutter politics. It is as though he inverted gutter politics himself as it has come back to us today.

Let me pick up some of the choicest things the Treasurer said, leaving aside his colossal arrogance. He engaged in a series of racist smears against the Leader of the Opposition. He said that we are engaging in racism and that the Leader of the Opposition is a racist. This is something, by the way, which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), when answering a dorothy dix question, specifically disavowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—The Treasurer intervenes by saying that he did not say that. This is what the Treasurer said and this is what the Hansard record shows that he said of the Leader of the Opposition, `We like your money but we do not like your genetic makeup'. If that is not a racist smear, what is it? Did the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs say that? No, he did not. What did the Treasurer then do? He went on to talk about the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). Why? Because that is consistent with the man. Does he address an issue like this honestly and directly and say, `Sure that is what I did. I used the special privileges of my office because I was going on a very important mission. I wanted to get on that plane and they could fix it up at the other end'. That is what the Leader of the House would be doing. That is what the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) would be doing. He could say, `Okay, I will not get on the plane'. But he says, `No, I was treated just like anybody else. I am just an ordinary little digger trying to do my best around here. I just got on the plane and Qantas treated me nicely and decently'. Sure, and pigs have wings!

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to come back to a couple of other things which sum up beautifully this man. In his attack on the honourable member for Deakin he said that he had got off on a technicality. This was a gross and outrageous misrepresentation of the truth but, be that as it may, that is all part and parcel of the man. Of the honourable member for Mackellar he said, `You are a nasty, dirty little character'. Did anyone so unconsciously describe himself as the way in which he addressed the honourable member? The Treasurer got it in one. He has got himself squarely. At these times the Treasurer becomes a shade emotional when his integrity is challenged-as it should be because everybody in this House knows what his integrity is like-and he goes straight back to the gutter, straight back to type. Gutter politics, hell. Sewer politics, yes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we have moved for censure of the Treasurer for his failure to produce a current passport on his recent visit to Japan and his failure to observe the rules which are followed by all other Australians and, I might add, his deliberate deceit of this House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is just about the pits for an opposition. This is the sort of issue which a party in normal circumstances-and the Opposition is not-having come across it would probably not choose to raise, but if it did it would give it to a back bencher, have it run on the adjournment and it would appear in Column 8 or the like of the Sydney Morning Herald, and that would be the end of the matter because it is a silly little piece of nonsense from the Opposition. The Opposition has gained one thing from it, something which I very much regret. Because we treat members of the Opposition reasonably well on censure motions, the Opposition has gained approximately one extra hour in which to place pressure on its back benchers who are now in a state of revolt on the issue of the motion that we will move on racism. It is a clear-cut motion. This motion has provided the Opposition with an extra hour to deal with its back bench in that regard. That, it must be said, is a substantial political gain. That is all it has gained from it. What the Opposition has not gained is a tarnishing of the reputation of the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members had sat and listened-as I had to-to the two speeches which were put forward in the moving of this motion, they would have found that it was not really an attack on the Treasurer; it was a litany of personal grievances: `I have been terribly treated by this man in our debates'. There was the question of whether there had been use of the national health system in an improper fashion and the fact that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) was found out on that. There was the fact that members of the Opposition did not like the way they were responded to on the question of the Treasurer's taxation return. That grievance has come out. There has been muling and puling from the other side of the House, which says more about its own sense of self-confidence and personal self-worth than it says about the sorts of issues it has chosen to raise in this place.

Let me put one or two things on the record on this because the Treasurer does not need a defence but in these circumstances he deserves one. The first concerns this piece of nonsense that nobody leaving this country ever, until the Treasurer came along, travelled with an out-of-date passport. Nobody ever does that! The suggestion that the Treasurer was specially treated is nonsense. A reasonable checking with the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, as we have done, reveals that as a matter of convenience regularly people travel overseas without up to date passports. But there is a difference between the Treasurer's situation and that of all other citizens. The difference applies not only to the Treasurer but to all Cabinet Ministers. A non-Cabinet Minister citizen of this country has a passport valid for five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten years now.

—The passport is valid for 10 years, is it? If one is a member of the Treasurer's staff one has a passport valid for the life of the Parliament. If one is a Cabinet Minister one will not. That is the difference. The Treasurer is not in the same position, nor is any other Cabinet Minister, as other people in the Australian community.
—Well, fix it. You have had five years to fix it. How long do you need?

—I thank the honourable member for his advice. We will look at that. The Opposition could have dropped us a letter on the matter and said, `This is obviously a problem, Mr Treasurer. Perhaps you ought to get the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to look at the situation to ensure that Ministers get diplomatic passports for the life of the Parliament'. That would be a helpful suggestion but that is not why the Opposition chose to raise it in this place. It tried to suggest that the Treasurer had been treated differently from any other Australian. On the matter of his passport, he is treated differently: he has a passport different from that of other Australians. He has a passport which has had to be revalidated eight times in the last five years. No other person in this country is in this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion was made again here today that somehow the Treasurer entered Japan illegally. I would have thought that that was a matter for the Japanese to determine, and of course it is. They determined that there was no problem with that. It is fine as far as they are concerned. He had a valid visa for entry to Japan. It was a matter of the least concern for the Japanese that his passport happened to be a few weeks out of date on issue. A note has just been passed to me from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs so I return to an earlier point: about 400 people a year travel overseas with expired passports. So the Treasurer in this instance is in pretty good company. He has 400 of his fellow Australians in the same position and I bet those 400 Australians are not the Australians that `Clarence Darrow' thinks of as average Australians. There is not a house in his electorate worth less than $500,000. And he comes in here accusing the Treasurer of wandering around behind tinted windows! As he goes through the leafy glades of Sydney's North Shore he is intimately in contact with the average Australian! There was no illegality; it was simply a question of oversight.

The censure motion process has been deeply degraded by the Opposition over the years and this instance has probably brought it to its lowest ebb. An attack on a personal matter such as this would normally be in a situation in which it could be reasonably said that a personal benefit was involved. What personal benefit was involved here? What personal gain or loss would the Treasurer have sustained if a Customs official had decided that he would not extend to the Treasurer what is extended to 400 Australians each year? If the Customs official had decided to treat him discriminately and to say, `No, I have dealt with it in a certain way for 400 Australians but I would not deal with it for you in that way', what would the Treasurer have stood to lose? He would have lost the opportunity to defend Australia's national interest in Japan. He would have gained the opportunity to spend another three or four days with his children while his passport was being fixed up. I have no doubt in my mind what people around this place would consider to be the gain and benefit in that situation. The Treasurer was on an important national task and this bunch of clowns opposite, this-as Arthur Calwell described them-gibbering array of pathological exhibits--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw. I suggest he does not do it again or we will both play the game.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor, when taking a point of order, may state his point of order but the only game we will play if he continues that behaviour will be a game outside the chamber. The honourable member has taken offence at what the Minister has said. I do not necessarily think the words were unparliamentary but it may help the debate if the Minister would withdraw them.
—I withdraw `pack of clowns' and leave in place `gibbering array of pathological exhibits'.
—Smart Alec.

—The honourable member for O'Connor is good on gibbering. I have had occasion to mention that in the past in the Parliament. He gibbers away on the front bench and we all get to know what monkey business means in the Western Australian Liberal Party.
—Order! The Minister might come back to the matter before the Chair.

—The Treasurer was treated like any other Australian. He was engaged on an important national task. What sort of Opposition is it that in the middle of important national debates, particularly on the Budget, would choose to attempt to detract from the process of debate by drawing attention to a totally irrelevant occurrence which in any circumstances any reasonable person looking at it would describe as a totally irrelevant, trivial occurrence? That Opposition members cannot see that whereas every other person in this country can says a great deal about them and the state which they have reached. It is understandable that when the Morgan poll was produced yesterday, after the change of line on immigration had been sold in the Party as an election winner, and it was revealed that the public had seen the Liberal Party as increasingly extremist and therefore untrustworthy, the desire, albeit misplaced, to seek a distraction became overwhelming. The ridiculous, trivial pieces of pomposity which have been inflicted on this Parliament now in two debates are the way in which that agony has been expressed in this place. Fortunately, we do not have to tolerate that at any great length in this Parliament and I will not inflict this debate any more on honourable members. I move:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 1, Government Business, being called on forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) acknowledges the historic action of the Holt Government, with bipartisan support from the Australian Labor Party, in initiating the dismantling of the White Australia Policy;

(2) recognises that since 1973, successive Labor and Liberal/National Party Governments have, with bipartisan support, pursued a racially non-discriminatory immigration policy to the overwhelming national, and international, benefit of Australia; and

(3) gives its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.

One of the great and rare distinctions of Australian political leadership in the last generation has been its bipartisan rejection of race as a factor in immigration policy. This has been a triumph of compassion over prejudice, of reason over fear, and of statesmanship over politics. Twenty-two years ago my Party, the Australian Labor Party, disowned its own historic white Australia policy, and the Government led by Harold Holt, to its everlasting credit and honour, abolished the white Australia policy and began to dismantle the administrative machinery of discrimination.

This motion is before this House today because that great and rare distinction has been put in jeopardy by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)-the inheritor of the role, but not the mantle, of Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Malcolm Fraser. I say this most sincerely to the Leader of the Opposition: this motion has not been brought forward in any attempt to drive him into the ground. It is not, because if he would retract his position then, as far as this side of the House is concerned, what has happened would be regarded as an aberration and would be forgotten. We would be pleased and proud to re-embrace once again an unqualified bipartisanship on this important issue.
Let us look at the statements of the Leader of the Opposition. On 1 August, in regard to Asian immigration, he said:
I do believe that if in the eyes of some in the community it-
Asian immigration-
is too great, it would be in our immediate term interest and supportive of social cohesion if it were slowed down a little, so that the capacity of the community to absorb was greater.
On 12 August the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) said that the figures showed that there were too many Asians coming into the country. On 9 August Senator Stone said:
Asian immigration has to be slowed. It is no use dancing around the bushes.

On 15 August, he also said that it will require a reduction in the excessively high proportion of immigrants from Asia. Those statements remain unretracted. The position of the Leader of the Opposition on 17 August was as follows:
I do not intend to alter one inch the stand that I have taken . . . I do not intend to alter my position on this issue.

The paragraph shuffling in the Party meeting last Monday has not changed anything. If, according to the Leader of the Opposition, in the eyes of some in the community Asian immigration is too great, he believes it would be in our immediate term interest and supportive of social cohesion if it were slowed down a little. The Leader of the Opposition maintains that position and, as I say, the paragraph shuffling of last Monday enables him to maintain that position. That has broken the tradition. It has broken the practice of the past and the Leader of the Opposition knows it, his colleagues know it, every commentator in the community knows it and, significantly, every Asian leader knows it.

He has not only broken the traditions of his predecessors but also unfortunately he has broken his own strongly asserted position in this House. Almost four years ago to this very day, on 23 August 1984, the Leader of the Opposition spoke on this issue and he pleaded eloquently for bipartisanship. On 23 August 1984 he advised that just two weeks previously he had successfully moved, with an overwhelming majority of the New South Wales convention of the Liberal Party, a motion on this issue. The Hansard shows that, speaking of that motion, he said:

It recalled amongst other things, that past coalition government policies were built upon a non-discriminatory approach to immigration and a level of intake and a pace of change. During that debate, which was reported fairly extensively by the media, I expressly rejected the proposition that the Liberal Party should take a stand against Asian immigration. I supported the policies of the former coalition Government which were humanitarian and liberal in the true sense of the word. We were prepared to take, with the Labor Party's generous support, people from war-torn parts of South East Asia.
Importantly he said:
We were prepared to persuade people around Australia to accept that policy.

In the course of his contribution-an eloquent contribution-he referred properly to the need to avoid any suggestion of racism. Those were eloquent words of the Leader of the Opposition in his then capacity in this House nearly four years ago to this day. He said that he and those around him were prepared to persuade the people of Australia. Implicitly in his statement he recognised the unfortunate truth; that is, that there is prejudice in this country on this issue. No sensible person can deny that. But he said then that the task of leadership was to persuade the people of Australia. But now, rather than leading, rather than-in his own words-persuading people around Australia to accept the principled and the unqualified position of his predecessors against any suggestion or possibility of discrimination, and instead of accepting that responsibility of leadership, he has unfortunately become the follower of the lowest common denominator.

Let me make it clear-and I want the Leader of the Opposition to know this-I do not accuse him of racism or of being a racist. In a sense, sadly, I make the more serious charge, I make the more damning indictment, of cynical opportunism, in a cynical grab for votes. His polling shows that there is this prejudice in the community and he has unleashed within his coalition and within the wider community the most malevolent, the most hurtful, the most damaging and the most uncohesive forces. Far from `one Australia' he has guaranteed a divided Australia. Far from guaranteeing one Australia, he has guaranteed a divided Australia; a hurtfully divided Australia.

One of the most disquieting aspects of the Liberals' new confected policy on immigration is their slipshod and deceptive use of the English language. When the Liberals initiated the breach of bipartisanship, their language, for all its ugliness, was clear cut. No-one could doubt that the Leader of the Opposition meant what he said when he explicitly called for a slowdown in Asian immigration. Nobody could doubt the meaning of the Leader of the National Party of Australia when he said that there were too many Asians coming into Australia. Senator Stone was clearly understood when he said that the excessively high proportion of immigrants from Asia should be reduced. But now the Opposition is operating under what I referred to as the policy by code word. Now the Opposition refers to changes in the composition of the immigration flow `to protect social cohesion'. Let me make it crystal clear that we in the Government repudiate the Opposition's position. We repudiate it on moral grounds and we repudiate it on grounds of this nation's economic self-interest. This is one of those occasions when moral and economic interest coincide.

Let me deal briefly with the moral issue. I can do it in terms of some of the recent language that has come from the Leader of the Opposition and others. Honourable members will recall that honourable members opposite in talking recently about a great Australian referred to the fact that he was an atheist. Presumably, they were implying for themselves, as they are properly and legitimately entitled to do, that they embraced the virtues of the Christian position. If there is one fundamental aspect of the Christian position, it is the belief and faith in the fatherhood of God. There is one thing which follows as a matter of logic and faith from that position; that is the belief in the brotherhood of man. Any suggestion of antagonism or discrimination on the grounds of race repudiates and is repugnant to that fundamental position. Let me say, for those who do not in any formal sense embrace the Christian position but who are driven by the compulsion of compassionate humanism, that belief in the brotherhood of man is just as fundamental.

To make the point of the morality of the issue, let me ask every member of this House to think of those 350,000 Asian born Australians together with their Australian born sons and daughters. I just ask honourable members to think of them. I have been in close contact in the last three weeks with representatives of community organisations. I am saddened beyond measure by the acute anguish and fear that has been engendered in the community following the statements of the Leader of the Opposition. Today we heard my colleague the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) give further evidence, eloquently, of that. If the Leader of the Opposition doubts that his remarks have had any adverse impact on these people I say to him: talk to these kids in their schools; talk to those who have received hate letters in the mail over the last three weeks; talk to the people whose homes and cars have been attacked; talk to those who have been forced to read disgusting graffiti about themselves; and talk to those proud Asian Australians who have been here for many generations and who now feel they are seen as some sort of threat to the social cohesion of the country of which they are proud.
Like all members of this House, today I received a communication from the Uniting Church in Australia. I will read it. I knew nothing about its preparation. The letter stated:

The national Assembly of the Uniting Church in Australia is strongly opposed to the use of race or country of origin as a criterion in the selection of migrants to Australia. We believe it is ethically unacceptable to use such criteria.
The offence and pain caused to Australians of Asian origin by the debate of the past month is very serious.

On behalf of the Assembly of the Uniting Church in Australia, I urge you to take a strongly moral and principled stand on the issue and to support the motion to be introduced today by Mr Hawke in support of an absolutely non-racial policy.
That letter is signed by John P. Brown, Acting General Secretary of the Uniting Church in Australia.

I turn quickly to the economic implications of what has happened.
