Honourable members will know that, following the period when we were in economic recession at the beginning of the 1980s, we have turned increasingly to seek enmeshment of the Australian economy in that of the world's most dynamic and economically fastest growing region. It is clear that to do anything to turn our backs on or to prejudice our relations with that region would be against the economic interests of this country.

It is critical that we keep in mind the extent of Australia's economic ties with Asia. Five out of the top ten export markets of this country are in Asia. Half of our national annual exports are now sold to Asian countries. Some $17 billion per year-the national income equivalent of $1,000 for every Australian man, woman and child-goes in exports to Asia. India, China and Hong Kong have been the three fastest growing of our major export markets over the last five years. Japan is our largest export market. Our exports to China and Hong Kong have leaped by over 300 per cent in the last years. In the area of foreign investment, which we know is critical to this country, Asian investment in the Australian economy is worth around $35 billion. It is now similar to that from the United Kingdom and twice that from the rest of the European Economic Community. Asia is critical to the future of our fastest growing industry, tourism. One in four of our international tourists now comes from Asia.

Let me refer to some of the early signs that already make apparent the damage that has been done by what has been initiated by the Leader of the Opposition. Professor Helen Hughes, a regional economic specialist and a member of the Fitzgerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, has suggested that Australia could already have lost billions of dollars in contracts in South East Asia. We are aware of the comments of Mr Lee Kuan Yew. This is confirmed by a cable received only yesterday from our High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur which suggests that the money we could lose as a result of the debate could run into billions of dollars. Our important business migration program is being put at risk because three out of four business migrants in 1987-88 came from Asia, bringing three-quarters of a billion dollars into this country with them. The cable from Kuala Lumpur emphasised that if it is believed that racism is resurgent in Australia, intending migrants will take themselves and their money elsewhere. I will quote from the cable. It stated:
They don't read the fine print in political statements but act on the basis of an impression of the overall situation.

Those are the clear signs of the damage that has already been wreaked upon this country by the statements of the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the National Party and Senator Stone. The Leader of the Opposition and those supporting him have underrated, indeed insulted, the decency and intelligence of the Australian people. The Leader of the Opposition has repudiated one of the proud traditions of the Australian Liberal Party. In the process, I believe that he is rending the fabric of the Liberal Party. That is a matter for the Liberal Party, but the Leader of the Opposition is not going to rend the fabric of this great Australian society. That is a matter for me and for the Australian Parliament.

The remarks by the Leader of the Opposition and of his colleagues remain unretracted and publicly unrepudiated. This motion provides the opportunity for repudiation and retraction. The motion asserts that this Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, speaking on behalf of the people of Australia, repudiates explicitly, and by any implicit process of paragraph shuffling, the concept or suggestion that discrimination against any race has or will have any place in the immigration policies or the domestic policies of this great Australian nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much welcome the opportunity which the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gives me to speak about this issue, to put into proper concept remarks I have made, to repeat the policy adopted by the coalition earlier this week and also to take issue with some of the cant and hypocrisy that has emanated from the Australian Labor Party (ALP) on this issue. I begin by stating a number of facts which have in no way been qualified by what I have said or my Party or the National Party have endorsed as policy. We remain unalterably committed to an immigration policy that will bring immigrants from all around the world. We remain unalterably opposed to any return to a white Australia policy. We are unequivocally committed to total equality of treatment of all Australians, irrespective of their background, nationality, origin, race, ethnicity, religion or political beliefs. That remains central to the policy we have adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are asserting, and what I will assert during this debate in proposing an amendment to the Prime Minister's motion, is that no self-respecting nation can settle for less than our declaration-and I use the words of the editorial in the Australian today which says, when quoting from our policy:
` . . . it must be the role of the elected govt . . . to make the final and absolute decisions on who will or will not be granted entry to Australia on a temporary or permanent basis.

I say to members of the Labor Party: Do any of you challenge that proposition? Do any of those members challenge the proposition that it is the elected government of this country that ultimately makes a decision on who will enter this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —Red herring.

—The Prime Minister says that it is a red herring, but on 23 September last year, when the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, launched the inquiry under Dr Stephen FitzGerald at the Australian National University, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The review is to be undertaken within the context of this Government's commitment to the principle of non-discrimination in respect of national or ethnic origin, race, sex and religion.
But importantly he went on in the same paragraph to say:
However, the Australian Government retains the right to determine who shall enter and remain in Australia and that right will not be up for reassessment.

They were the words of Mick Young. Was that just a piece of empty sophistry, or was he doing the unpardonable and entering a caveat on the ultimate right of any sovereign nation-a right which the Prime Minister asserted in 1977 when he was being less than statesmanlike in relation to the boat people who were arriving in Australia, a problem that was being grappled with by the Government at that time, a Liberal-National Party government? The Prime Minister was not running around in his then capacity preaching acceptance of our policy; rather, he was running around Australia taking political advantage of a difficult situation in the middle of an election campaign. The Prime Minister does not come to this debate with quite the high standing morality that he presented during his address. The Prime Minister does not do that any more than do many of his colleagues. I wonder whether everything he said in this debate is shared by his colleagues.

I want to go through the words I have used over the past couple of weeks and I want to read them to the House because it is important that they be put down and understood. This matter first arose in the context of an interview on the Channel 10 program Face to Face. This is what I said on 31 July, and I would like the House to listen to this very carefully:

I do not see Asian immigration as such is a problem. I mean I would never go back to a white Australia policy, that would be crazy. I do however think that the pace of change brought about by the migrant intake is an issue that any government has got to keep in mind and from time to time we've got to take account of the community's capacity to absorb it . . . I don't primarily see it as a vote winning exercise. I primarily see it as something that is important to the national unity of Australia and to our sense of identity as Australians.
Then on 1 August I said:

I would never want to see Asian immigration stopped because I think that would be politically and socially and emotionally stupid. We have moved on from the days of the white Australian policy, but I do think it is legitimate for any government to worry about the capacity of the community to absorb change and there is some concern about the pace of change involved in the present level of Asian migration. I think any government is entitled to take that into account and it ought not to be accused of being racist.

The Prime Minister did not bother to read out those words. The words that he read out I did say, and I do not deny that I said them because they are on the record. I shall not pretend that I did not say them. But what I was saying then, and I repeat it in this House now, is that any government has a right to take into account the pressures on society brought about by migration and the changes involved in that. I have said that before and will not retreat from saying it.

I find it astonishing that anybody can seriously claim that that is anything other than a reflection of the view held by many people in the Australian community who cannot by any sense of the imagination or any sense of the word be accused of being racist. I know that there are ugly racists in this country, and I deplore as much as anybody else examples of that used by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) during Question Time. But I do not think that it contributes greatly to the debate for him to arrange dorothy dixers on this subject. I will defend my right to contribute to an objective debate on this issue, irrespective of the tactics that are being used by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on this issue.

Nothing I have said in this debate has been anti-Asian. I was a member of the government which proudly brought to this country an enormous number of Indo-Chinese refugees. We had a moral obligation to bring those people to this country-a moral obligation that was not felt by a former Labor Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, or by a former Labor Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Clyde Cameron, or by many other people in the Australian Labor Party. They did not feel under any moral obligation to bring those people to Australia, but we did. We were prepared to display that moral leadership at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we supported you.
—Of course we did.

—We did not get much support from the present Prime Minister, at that time the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) was an outstanding exception to many of the contributions made at that time from his side of politics. He interjects rightly. I have read the Hansard record of the debate and he displayed a farsightedness and willingness to help that was not exhibited by a lot of other people on his side of the Parliament at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come to the motion moved by the Prime Minister. It is essentially in three parts. The first part of the motion recalls the abandonment of the white Australia policy on the initiative of the Holt Government and with the support of the Australian Labor Party. We totally endorse that and have no problems with it. The second part of the motion invites this House to pronounce a general benediction on the conduct of immigration policy over the last five years. We are not prepared to do that because we think immigration policy over the last five years has been hopelessly bungled by a succession of Labor immigration Ministers.

The third part of the motion-this is the crucial part-invites us to disavow our policy. It invites us to say that a government does not have a sovereign right to determine who should enter this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not say that.

—It does. The Prime Minister may choose to say it does not, but I refer to the words of Mick Young, who was one of the Labor Party's own Ministers. Can people in the Labor Party explain to me how it is that, although they say they are in favour of a non-discriminatory policy, Mr Young said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Australian Government retains the right to determine who shall enter and remain in Australia and that right will not be up for re-assessment.

What our policy says is that we will administer the immigration program according to a number of principles. One of those principles is the non-discriminatory selection of people irrespective of considerations of nationality, religion, ethnic background or political belief. But it then also provides-I make no bones about this and no apology for it-that it must be the role of the elected Government to make the final and absolute decision on who will or will not be granted entry to Australia on a temporary basis. I borrow again the words of the editorial in the Australian today:

There can be no reasonable objection to the proposition that `any government must reserve the right from time to time to vary and alter policy, including adjustments to the size and composition of the immigration program in response to changing requirements, be they social, economic, political or humanitarian.

The Prime Minister attempts to exaggerate deliberately the claimed damage to our reputation in South East Asia caused by the debate that has gone on over the past two or three weeks. I say particularly to members of the Labor Party from Queensland that the anti-Japanese foreign investment policy of Wayne Goss in Queensland has done more to damage our reputation in Japan than anything I have said over the past two or three weeks. We have a completely open and liberal foreign investment policy and we will not be adopting any foreign investment policy which is clothed as a non-discriminatory prohibition but is nakedly directed towards the prejudice that has developed in Queensland to Japanese investment. The editorial goes on to say:

Australia should not allow itself to be bluffed into surrendering its national sovereignty by reports that some of our neighbours to the north, few of whom are models of racial tolerance, will take economic reprisals against us if we follow an immigration policy designed to preserve our cultural and political traditions and our social cohesion.
I do not believe there is anything racist, anything neanderthal, in those statements, anything that is against Australia's interests.

We cannot support the motion moved by the Prime Minister, for the reasons I have given. We have proposed an amendment, and that amendment will acknowledge the historic action of the Holt Government, with bipartisan support, to end the white Australia policy. It will confirm a total commitment to equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians, regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin, within the framework of a just and tolerant society. It will condemn the Hawke Government's maladministration of immigration policy over the last five years, and it will confirm the fundamental principles of our immigration policy.

The Prime Minister's moving of this motion today has been a totally political exercise. Our credentials on immigration cannot seriously be challenged. Nothing I have said over the past two or three weeks has been designed in any way to foster hostility towards any section of the Australian community, but I will never ever abandon the sovereign right of this country to decide who will be a permanent citizen of this nation. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: this House:
(1) acknowledges the historic action of the Holt Government, with bipartisan support from the Australian Labor Party, in initiating the dismantling of the White Australia policy;

(2) confirms a total commitment to equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin within the framework of a just and tolerant society;
(3) condemns the Hawke's Government's maladministration of immigration policy over the past five years which has lead to public disquiet as evidenced by the findings of the FitzGerald Committee;

(4) confirms that it is the very essence of national sovereignty that only the democratically elected government has the right to determine both the overall and the specific composition of our migrant intake;

(5) confirms, without qualification, that it must be the role of the elected government, acting on behalf of and with the support of the whole community, to make the final and absolute decisions on who will or will not be granted entry to Australia on a temporary or permanent basis;

(6) confirms that this means that any government must reserve the right from time to time to vary and alter policy, including adjustments to the size and composition of the immigration program in response to changing requirements, be they social, economic, political or humanitarian;
(7) confirms that established principles of any immigration policy will always be subject to this overriding right;

(8) confirms that migrants accepted for permanent settlement in Australia must share the Australian people's basic values and commitments and be able to make a positive contribution to national well-being and advancement;
(9) expresses its support for One Australia and welcomes all those who share that vision and are ready to contribute to it; and
(10) confirms that:
(a) no person other than an Australian citizen, or a permanent resident of the Australian community, has a basic right to enter Australia;

(b) migrant entry criteria should be developed on the basis of the economic and social benefit to the Australian community for people other than those admitted for family reunion or as refugees. As a general principle, Australia should not admit for settlement people who would represent an economic burden to Australia through inordinate claims on welfare, health or other resources, or who would endanger the community by criminal or other anti-social activities, or whose entry would be to their own detriment;

(c) the capacity of the Australian people to accept and absorb change must always be a major factor in immigration policy. The size and composition of our immigration policy should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community;

(d) in selecting between one individual and another immigration policy will not discriminate against applicants on the basis of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, gender or religion;

(e) applicants should be considered for immigration as individuals or individual family units, not as community groups. An exception will be refugees in designated refugee situations, although even in such circumstances, the criteria for selection will be related to the characteristics of individual applicants;

(f) the standard for eligibility and suitability of migrants should reflect Australia social mores and Australian law. Poly-gamous unions will not be accepted, nor the entry of child finance/es. The concept of ``immediate family'' for eligibility purpose will be derived from the Australian norm, that is, the unit consisting of husband, wife, dependent children and aged parents;

(g) migrants will be expected to respect the institutions and principles which are basic to Australian society, including parliamentary democracy, the rule of law and equality before the law, freedom of the individual, freedom of speech, freedom of association, freedom of assembly, freedom of the press, freedom of religion, equality for women, universal education. Reciprocally, Australia will be committed to facilitating equal opportunity for participation of migrants in society;

(h) immigration to Australia should be for permanent settlement, although there should be no barrier preventing the departure of people wishing to leave. The guest-worker immigration flow, until recently popular in the industrialised countries of Western Europe, will not be adopted for Australia;

(i) citizenship is the ultimate expression of an individual's commitment to Australia and its future and requires respect for Australia's institutions and values. Migration to Australia should lead to Australian citizenship;
(j) while migrants will have the same rights as other Australian residents to choose their place of residence individually or collectively, enclave settlement will not be encouraged; and

(k) policies governing entry and settlement should be based on the premise that migrants want to integrate into the Australian society. Migrants will be given every opportunity, consistent with this premise, to preserve and disseminate their culture heritage.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At no stage has the central issue in this debate been the right of a sovereign nation to determine the composition of and the numbers contained in its immigration policy. That is not in issue, and in the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) there is a specific reference to the sovereign right to determine the composition of our immigration intake. The central issue of this debate is whether or not, in making that determination, we adopt racist standards and say, `Well, yes, we want to have a non-discriminatory policy, and you can go through the tests and pass those tests'. But at the end of the day the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) reserves the right to say that because we are concerned about our interpretation of social cohesion and the need to maintain some balance within the Australian economy, we will discriminate against one group of people on the basis of their race and origin. That is the issue. That is the heart of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say this to the Leader of the Opposition: like the Prime Minister, I feel a profound sense of sadness that on one further occasion in this Parliament the Leader of the Opposition has been given the opportunity to repudiate the track down which he has taken his Party and the reversal of policy that has been involved in that, and yet again for the narrowest of political ambitions he prefers to appeal to the historic xenophobic attitudes that have always existed in Australian society.

If we look at the verbiage of the Opposition's policy, there is no argument about the sovereign rights of the nation and the terminology used is politically neutral. But the problem in the Opposition parties, the problem in Australia, and the problem that thousands of decent Australians of Asian origin are worried about is the fact that there has been no lack of clarity in the position taken by those two leading members of the coalition, Senator Stone and, of course, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). Senator Stone was quite explicit: Australian immigration has to be slowed; it is no use beating around the bush. What sort of response did that get from the Leader of the National Party? It got full support. Was it some invention by the Prime Minister when Senator Baden Teague, the chairman of the committee which deals with these issues in the Party, called upon the Leader of the Opposition to repudiate that statement? On ABC radio on 12 August he said that he could only conclude that there was not enough strength in the coalition leadership to discipline Senator Stone.

Was it some sort of invention by the Prime Minister or members on this side of the House when that distinguished former Minister, Senator Peter Baume, said-he was perfectly candid about it-that John Stone was supposed to have said in the Melbourne Herald that Asian immigration had to be slowed. What did he go on to say? He said, `That is a racist immigration policy. Let us slow it, if we want to, on the basis of merit or some test you apply to all migrants, but let us not look at the colour of people's skin and determine whether or not we admit them to this country. John Stone made that statement. I would like the Leader of the Opposition to say, ``That is not the way we are going to go. We are not going to apply racist tests. We are not going to have a racial policy''. After all, if the basis is someone's race today, it could be their religion tomorrow'. That is the view that comes out of a senior and distinguished member of the Liberal Party and former Ministers for Immigration. They know the problem.

When we talk about social cohesion and the question of balancing numbers, what are we looking at in terms of percentages? In 1976 the number of Asian immigrants represented 1.1 per cent of the total population. In 1981 it was 1.8 per cent. In 1986 it was 2.6 per cent. If the present intake continues, by the year 2025 it will be 7 per cent. Is that a matter of concern? Is that the basis upon which the Leader of the Opposition is prepared to cast a shadow in which some of the lunatic racist groups in this community can operate? Asian immigrants will represent 7 per cent in the year 2025. What are we talking about? I say to the Leader of the Opposition, who believes that immigration policy can be driven by polls and that it is about social cohesion: It never has been and the honourable member himself, when he was in a more principled mode, rejected that concept entirely, as the Prime Minister indicated to the House.

There are two constants in the history of Australian immigration. The first is that the last group to arrive is always the subject of considerable abuse and admonition. This has always been the case. We now talk about our Anglo-Celtic heritage. Honourable members should read what was said about the Irish by the colonial legislators of this country. They were referred to as drunkards, as being of the wrong religion, as having too many children, as being anti-British and as making very poor servants. That is what was said. The Opposition would not have needed to conduct a gallup poll amongst the WASP establishment. The elements of that policy lived on in parts of Australia.

It was not until the 1950s that Archbishop Guilford Young said that enough was enough. He told the banks that operated in Tasmania, `If you want our money, you had better employ our people'. It took the intervention of a distinguished Catholic archbishop to end that level of discrimination that still ran through Australia until the 1950s. Now we talk about our Anglo-Celtic heritage. We should look at the history of the period after the war. In order to avoid the terms of derogation used against those who were coming out of Europe, Arthur Calwell had to coin the term `new Australian'. It lasted only so long, until it became a term of abuse.

Let us look at the polls at that time. We should never forget that never once was a poll conducted in Australia in which people of Italian or Greek origin could manage a 50 per cent approval rating. That is the history of the polls. In 1948 only 26 per cent of the population favoured immigration from Greece. We should look at this building and consider what it owes to the traditions of Italian architecture. Italian immigration has never managed to get more than 21 per cent approval. Social cohesion! After the war the Jewish people were coming out of Dachau and Belsen, victims of the holocaust. I have heard the Leader of the Opposition speak eloquently about that issue. When there was a poll--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that I do not believe it?

—The problem is that the Leader of the Opposition does believe it. I do not have any doubt about the fact that he believes it. I am saying that he is talking about social cohesion and I am asking him: if he had been the Minister for Immigration in 1947, what would he have done with the poll finding which said that only 37 per cent approval--
—You know damn well. Don't you imply otherwise.

—The Leader of the Opposition says that I know. He is the man who, with historic insight, now says that if he had been there in 1947-the advice given to the Minister at the time was that nine out of 10 Australians did not want Jews in Australia-it would have been different then; it would have been different for the Italians and the Greeks, if only he had been Prime Minister then. Now we are looking at the latest category; we are looking at the last group. What does the Leader of the Opposition say? He talks about social cohesion. He looks at the polls that have come out of the right wing think-tanks. That is what motivates him, and everybody knows it. The people in his Party know it. Distinguished ex-Ministers for Immigration know it. The real problem is that deep in his heart he knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of this debate is that we are not talking about perceptions of Asian immigration. The real issue is that we are talking about our perceptions of Australian society. We are talking about a policy which was nurtured carefully and was brought to fruition by a once great Liberal Party. It was developed and expanded by the Labor Party. Therefore, on the basis of the narrowest and meanest political assessment that has ever been made in the history of the Commonwealth, this Leader of the Opposition wants to reserve to himself, under pressure of an immigration policy driven by John Stone and the Leader of the National Party, the right to say that whatever is the latest poll that comes out will be the determinant of our immigration composition.

It is a tragedy for Australia that a resolution in these terms cannot now carry the uniform approval of this House. I say with all sincerity that I was hoping that the Leader of the Opposition would use this opportunity to endorse a principle and a philosophy which is as much the property of his Party as it is of ours. But, if he cannot do that, then the best thing he can do for his Party, the most honourable thing he can do for his Party, is to resign. I say to the honourable member for Kooyong: if you want to do something for your Party and for the future of Australia and if you want to do something for those thousands of decent young Australians of Asian origin who, when they get on trams and buses have to face the racist muck that is now being pasted on billboards and tram stops, for God's sake, take him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the tone of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) appalling. They are not interested in trying to bring unanimity into this country. They are not interested in trying to generate the mood of one Australia. They are interested in trying to promote difference. They are trying to generate the emotive overtones which any thinking Australian has once the very tenor of `racist' is introduced into the debate. In the absolutely appalling contribution by the Immigration Minister a moment ago we began to see the genesis for his sacking last Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Prime Minister and his Minister were sincere this debate could easily have been held on Tuesday: if they wished, it could have been held on Monday. Why is it introduced today? Because they think it will be a bit of smart political gimmickry. It is not introduced in some genuine presentation of what they believe is a good opportunity to talk about the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. The report was handed down on a commission provided by the Hawke Government. The report, properly, needs to be examined and considered by the Parliament and by the Government. It was not peculiarly because of that report but certainly it was in association with the consideration of the recommendations of that report and in association with the preparation of our total re-examination of our policies that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has been making his comments on immigration in the last few weeks. His amendment to the motion by the Prime Minister this afternoon ensures that instead of concentrating attention on the narrow confines of the racial bigotry that the Prime Minister and the Immigration Minister are trying to promote, it is broadened to the whole embrace of what an immigration policy should be all about.

The content of the motion shows that we are seeking to ensure not only that there is no racial bigotry but also that there is an equality of treatment of all people of whatever race, whatever their origins, whatever their language, in Australia throughout whatever period they might want to live in this country. Let no-one mistake the fact that the Prime Minister, when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, said some appalling things when we were in government and he sought to facilitate the Vietnamese boat people coming to Australia. Those views were certainly endorsed by members such as the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman).

Immigration is not a narrow, racial debate. Immigration should be discussed in the breadth of sympathy and understanding, of recognising the need for growth and development in this country and generating opportunities for newcomers to be totally at one with all other Australians. It is on that basis that we have tried to make sure that the people of Australia understand that we are concerned about the directions in which the Australian Labor Party's present immigration policy has taken Australia. We are concerned not just on the basis of the recommendations of Dr FitzGerald. Concern was expressed in submissions that came from a range of people: some were presented to the FitzGerald Commission and others were made separately. I want to talk a little about them in a moment.

Our amendment asks members of the Labor Party to ensure that they accept that in selecting between one individual and another immigration policy will not discriminate against applicants on the basis of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, gender or religion. So much for all this poppycock from the Minister, who a few moments ago suggested that we were going to move towards discriminating against race or religion. The policy that we have endorsed, which is reflected in the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition and which I second, has specifically stated in it that there will be no discrimination against applicants--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said on television.

—I will come to that in a moment. I said exactly the same as the honourable member's colleague, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), said a few weeks before. We need to look at the balance of people coming into Australia to ensure that people come here who the Government says in our national interest should be given priority, and that they are capable of being given priority. I want to pick up the very statement that was issued by the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, now the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), back in 1983. What he said has very many similarities to the expression of view I have just mentioned which is contained in our amendment to the motion which we are considering this afternoon. Hansard of 18 May 1983 on page 662 shows that the then Immigration Minister in his ministerial statement said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has reaffirmed the nine principles underlying migration policy . . . The Australian Government alone decides who can enter Australia.

That is our point: we must ensure that the Australian Government has the ultimate responsibility to say who should come into Australia. That is not contained in the third part of the Government's motion. The genesis of the change to bipartisan immigration policy was that statement of the then Minister. Let me continue with another quote because it is very material in considering where immigration has got to. The then Immigration Minister continued:
The Government intends to restructure the points system to eliminate its more discriminatory features.

The reality of that was the consequence that has been examined by the FitzGerald Committee. The restructuring of the points system was a simple way to say that the Government was going to change the immigration mix, it was going to change the proportions of people who came to Australia, and so it has done. So there has been the FitzGerald criticism and there has been the proper concern in the Australian community. On page 664 the Minister continued:
I will look for alternatives to the recruitment of skilled workers overseas, based on manpower planning.

The Government has established an immigration policy based on manpower planning. The overriding factor is that the Australian Government alone decides who can enter Australia. We have a far more sympathetic approach to immigration than that. We have said that in selecting between one individual and another, immigration policy will not discriminate against applicants on the basis of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, gender or religion. We have also gone on to confirm a total commitment to equal treatment and equal opportunity to all Australians regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin, but in the framework of a just and tolerant society.

All this nonsense about our introducing some draconian measures to stop people from trying to teach their children their familial language, from trying to practise the religion of which their forebears were members, is absolute nonsense. The structure of our amendments sets down proper qualifications on the exercise of a government's sovereignty. It sets down in sympathetic and understanding manner principles of immigration policy which are designed to ensure the sovereignty of a coalition government and a concern to try to develop one Australia. The whole of the nonsense about the emphasis that the Government seeks to place on racism flows from what it believes is a politically opportunistic way to try to embarrass members of the coalition. The former Immigration Minister, Mick Young, at the launch of the review of Australia's immigration policy, the launch of the FitzGerald Committee, in Melbourne on 23 September 1987 said:

The review is to be undertaken within the context of this Government's commitment to the principles of non-discrimination . . . However, the Australian Government retains the right to determine who shall enter and remain in Australia and that right will not be up for reassessment.
In response to such a policy the honourable member for Calwell, quite properly, in his assessment of what was happening in immigration policy, in an AM interview on 18 January 1988, said:

There is a problem in the balance of the immigration program, that is in practical terms as distinct from in theory, the program is not working out in terms of its balance . . . What I'm saying is that in the last few years there are insufficient numbers of people coming from some other areas.

The honourable member for Calwell was endorsing exactly the concerns that Dr FitzGerald has expressed. He expressed exactly the same concerns that we have expressed. We want to try to ensure that there is one Australia.

We all know that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who is sitting at the table, was sacked following the release of the immigration report, which is very critical of the way in which migration has been administered under the Hawke Government. The Government has had five Ministers in five years in this extraordinarily sensitive area. It has had junior Ministers. It has had Ministers like the one at the table, who was an absolute failure as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and who was then put into Immigration. What sensitivity that shows! On page 99 of his report, Dr FitzGerald described the administration of immigration in the following way:

A labyrinth of rules and requirements that confuse and bewilder. A creator of uncertainty, dependence, frustration and anger. A mass of ill-fitting, unintegrated parts that resent change, that react rather than anticipate, that sink inexorably into inertia.

I wonder what the Committee said in the unexpurgated version. We all need to remember that there was an earlier FitzGerald report, the report that was subject to the scrutiny of the Prime Minister-a scrutiny that we are told led to some changes. We do not know what the changes were. But we certainly know that the Prime Minister did not think very much of the original language. We need to remember that when looking at the whole question of selection, Dr FitzGerald said:
Neither quotas nor queuing are the answers for Australia.
However, he said:
. . . the Committee concluded that a numerical system for rating applicants was the most appropriate system for Australia.
If such a test is an effective method of selection, and we are already using one, then why change it? The answer is-
this is the FitzGerald conclusion-
that the current test has not proved to be effective either in rationing or in selection. The system has broken down and its continuation is untenable.

The reality is that there is a concern on both sides of the House about the consequences of the administration of the Labor Party's immigration policy. Indeed, as the FitzGerald report says on page 66 with respect to race:
The real test is the test of social acceptance. Ten years of substantial immigration from Asia suggest very strongly that it is working.

It needs to be remembered that most of those 10 years were under the direction and control of the Liberal and National parties. We all know that the imbalance between skilled migrants and family reunions was commented on adversely in the FitzGerald report. We know something of the submission which was made by Graeme Hugo, a reader in geography at Flinders University of South Australia, who talked about the deskilling of the occupational profile. We also know that in this debate this afternoon we have prepared and presented an amendment which is comprehensive, which deals sympathetically with areas of race, which deals sympathetically with all discrimination and which provides for equality of treatment. But what we need to understand is that this Government is seeking to promote not harmony but disunity. Even in its analysis of what is happening in trade with Asia, this Government is seeking to suggest that because we on this side of the House have picked up the comments and criticisms in the community and in the FitzGerald report, we are in some way prejudicing our trade with countries whose own immigration policies are far more racially selective than any that have ever been adopted by coalition governments. We need to remember that the Japan-Australian trade agreement was negotiated by a government from this side of the House. We need to remember that this side of the House did not generate the antagonisms with Indonesia which have led to a deterioration in relations with that country over the last five years. We need to remember that members on this side of the House do not want to restore the white Australia policy which a coalition government ended. What we seek to do is to make sure that within Australia there is a development of unity, a maintenance of one Australia within which all Australians regard their pride in their country and their nation as the most important aspect of their citizenship and their whole belief.
It is worth quoting the following editorial in this morning's Australian:

The immigration policy adopted . . . by the Federal Coalition embodies a commitment to Australia's national integrity and traditions. It contains no suggestion of racial prejudice and declares its dedication to `equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians, regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin within the framework of a just, tolerant society'.

The motion that was submitted today is a purely political device. It needs to be opposed because it gives away Australia's sovereignty. The second part of the motion seeks to pretend that the FitzGerald comments on the Government's immigration policy are nonsense. It seeks to endorse the policy of the man sitting at the table who was sacked a week ago because of his immigration policy. I urge honourable members to support the amendment which has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have participated in many debates in this House since I became a member in 1969. However, I have participated in none with more regret than this one. In March 1970 I asked my maiden question in this House. It was about racism. The following day I made my maiden speech. It was about racism. If I were asked what single issue motivated me to become involved in politics, I would say that it was my hatred of prejudice, be it racial, religious or national.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to work out why I feel like that. As a young boy, not quite 10 years of age, on my first day at boarding school I found out what blind irrational hatred can be like. I was attacked not once, but three times, with the phrase, `You dirty bloody Jew!'. I have never forgotten that feeling and I never will. I have never forgotten what it feels like to be hated for no other reason than that I had been born different from most of my fellow Australians.

There are many people in this House who think they know what it is like to be taunted in such a way. They do not. They have no idea; and with all the best will in the world, they can never know. They may be able to intellectualise about it, but they can never know deep down the hurt and the humiliation. I discovered very early in life that those who can hurl such epithets around about one group of people can do it about any other group. Today it is Jews, tomorrow it is Catholics, and then it is the Italians, the Lebanese, the Indians and the Asians. It is their way of feeling superior. It establishes their place in the pecking order. It is a scapegoat for their own failures and inadequacies. I do not suggest that the majority, or even the minority, will necessarily do anything violent about it. They do not have to. Probably the overwhelming majority can see nothing wrong or hurtful in what they are doing. But it is there. They are humiliating every single person whom they discriminate against because of his religion, nationality, race, colour of skin or origins.

There is nothing one can do about the way one is born, and that is what makes racism so cruel and so stupid. I had thought naively that, in the near 20 years that I had been in this House, as a nation we had become a more tolerant society. I was wrong. We are as bigoted, as racially intolerant, as we ever were. I apologise to the members of the Asian community for the appalling behaviour of some of my fellow Australians during the past few weeks. Frankly, I am ashamed.

We are facing a crisis in this country over the present debate about immigration, and for that I am afraid we can thank the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). That may seem a harsh judgment, but make no mistake about it-he is the man most responsible. And that is depressing, because only a short while ago he made one of the best speeches ever made in this House against racism. But now, a short 18 months or so later, the community is divided because he has chosen to make race an issue in the immigration debate. He may twist, turn and dissemble as much as he likes, but he knows, or he ought to know, that people perceive that he is the person advocating introducing race as an issue in determining our immigration policy. All the good work that has been done before is worth nothing. We are now back to the 1890s. I have no doubt that the polls taken recently on the question of Asian immigration fairly accurately reflect the community's views. Seventy-seven per cent or 82 per cent is probably pretty close to the community's view about Asian immigration; but that does not make those members of the community right. It is simply a sad reflection on people's deep seated prejudices. It shows that we, the politicians on both sides, have failed to build a more tolerant society.

One great redeeming feature about this Parliament is that over the years, particularly since World War II, governments of both political persuasions have recognised that a harmonious society with an enormous immigration program could be developed only if the people from the over 100 different nations who immigrated to Australia could be welcomed to this country without the racial and religious tensions that have occurred in other societies. Any politician with half a brain was aware that the opportunities were available to score political points by exploiting the deep seated resentments present in our community against the newcomers. How many times have each of us sat in our offices and listened to people complain that the reason they were not getting a fair go was because the migrants were getting it all? How often have we heard a person denied a pension, a housing loan or a job complain bitterly that the Government should look after decent Aussies-Australian Australians, as Professor Blainey so quaintly puts it-before it gives everything to the wogs, the dagos, the Jews, the slopes, or whatever derogatory word was in vogue at the time to describe the latest wave of immigrants. It just goes to show how close to the surface is the resentment, the jealousy, the prejudice against anyone who is different.

Nothing has changed. Throughout the ages the unscrupulous politicians have always been aware of people's deep seated fears and hatreds of those who are different and they have set out to exploit those fears for their own political advantage. It is not difficult to do; it just requires a total lack of conscience. The worst example is still fresh in our memories: six million people lie dead as a testimony to just how hatreds can be whipped up into a frenzy in a very short time. Once we go down the path of allowing one group of people to be the scapegoats for our troubles, the way we are now allowing the Asians to be the scapegoats, some unscrupulous politicians or someone seeking to grab a headline will realise how easy it is to exploit people's fears and will choose another target. It cannot happen? That is what the Jews of Europe believed in the 1930s.

The Leader of the Opposition has been quite incensed by some politicians' reactions to his new policy of one Australia. I find it extraordinary that he can appear to be genuinely amazed that people continue to state that his policy is racist. He says on the one hand that there will be no discrimination and on the other that there will be a cutback in Asian immigration. He says that there will be a cutback because of community concern about the level of Asian immigration.

I have listened to him on half a dozen occasions and, no matter how generous I try to be, that policy can be interpreted in no other way than that it is racially discriminatory. He is not saying, as I thought he might be, that the requirements for entry might be altered so that, although the policy would not be discriminatory, the net result might be to decrease the number of Asian migrants. Not at all. That is not what he is saying. He says, quite clearly, that the Asian intake will be cut back because members of the community want it to be cut back. They do not like Asians, or they do not like that many Asians. Whichever way one looks at it, that can be described only as discriminatory.

Let us assume for a moment that we, the politicians, believe him when he says that his policy is non-discriminatory. We can be sure of one thing: members of the community do not believe him. They believe without a doubt that John Howard is against Asian immigration. And the evidence is that they support him overwhelmingly. To my great disappointment, I suspect that is precisely what he intended. If he has his way within his own Party, that is precisely what the next election will be fought about. His argument is that there is community concern about Asian immigration and, therefore, it must be reduced. His guide for that is the public opinion polls. Does that mean that from now on we will have government by public opinion poll? Anyone examining the polls in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s would have discovered that the country was fairly evenly divided on any immigration and quite strongly opposed to Greeks, Italians and Jews. Only four years ago all the major polls were showing that 60 per cent of Australians wanted a reduction of all immigration.

Although public opinion polls were not taken in Australia before World War II, I wonder, when the conservative Government under Joe Lyons agreed, at the Evian conference, to accept 12,000 Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany, just what the result of an opinion poll would have been at the time? If governments in the past had been solely guided by public opinion, it is unlikely that we would have had a fraction of the immigrants we have had during the post-war period. We certainly would have been restricted to British, Irish and northern European immigrants. It is only because all the political parties represented in this Parliament have recognised that the only way an immigration policy can be implemented is through a bipartisan approach that we have been able to bring millions of people to Australia from over 100 countries without any significant tensions.

What would have happened if in the immediate post-war period the Liberal-Country Party Opposition had opposed the Labor Government's initiative? The immigration program would have collapsed. What would have happened in the 23 years between 1949 and 1972 if the Labor Opposition had chosen to exploit immigration as an issue, particularly in 1966 when Harold Holt finally made the breakthrough and brought an end to the White Australia policy? At the time the Labor Party, under Arthur Calwell, was in a very unpopular position over its stance on the Vietnam War. It would have been easy to have taken the popular route and whip up anti-Asian sentiment to win votes. The Labor Party quite rightly chose not to do so. What about in more recent times when the Fraser Government courageously decided to take refugees from Vietnam? It was only the other day when the boat people were landing in Darwin and opposition was at fever pitch. Sure, there were mutterings in the trade union movement and the Labor Party could easily have exploited the racist feelings that were widespread at the time. It chose not to do so.

It is interesting that members of the Liberal Party and its coalition partners, who have a proud record of tolerance on the question of non-European immigration, should be in such desperate political trouble that they now seek to exploit the latent racism prevalent in our society. It is fairly obvious that a large number of Liberals, to their credit, are appalled at what is happening. I compliment those who have spoken out against this new policy.

The Leader of the Opposition appears injured that people have, as he puts it, misinterpreted his policy. What other interpretation can be placed on it? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, `I don't think John Howard is a racist. What he is is an opportunist. He is a person who is prepared to exploit racism to advance his political fortunes. He is saying, ``Look, don't blame me, I'm not a racist, but unfortunately a lot of my fellow Australians are. I'm not only not going to attack them, I'm going to go along with their prejudices and, in so doing, pick up their votes''.' The old saying, `All that is required for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing', was never more applicable than at this stage in Australia's history. It is not good enough for John Howard to imply that he cannot help it if his fellow Australians are racist. What he ought to be saying is, `Look, you are wrong, and whether 80 per cent of you believe it or 99 per cent of you are opposed to Asian immigration, I will show you where you are wrong'.

We should all be stumping the country, not advocating more or less Asian immigration but non-discrimination in our immigration policy. By not taking that position, the Leader of the Opposition and the coalition have aligned themselves with the racists and they have made racism respectable. Look at the people they have got lined up beside them-the despicable Ron Casey and Bruce Ruxton. These are people who are now setting the agenda in the immigration debate. The Leader of the Opposition said that because of community concern there should be a cutback in Asian immigration. What does that mean? What size cut is he proposing? What will satisfy the anti-Asians? Will 5,000 less satisfy them, or 10,000 less, or maybe 20,000 less? What percentage of migrants will pacify those who do not want any-25 per cent, 20 per cent, 15 per cent, 10 per cent or 5 per cent?

Why does the Leader of the Opposition not realise the sort of mindless debate we are embarking upon once we start getting into the numbers and statistics game? Does he really think that if we allow 20,000 Asians per year to come to Australia instead of 40,000 it will satisfy the people who do not like Asians? Certainly any Australian has a right to question how many immigrants we should take into this country. But once that question has been settled to further analyse the figures in terms of race or nationality will involve the nation in a never ending brawl that will only increase tensions in this country. Unfortunately, I am running out of time. Finally, in a sense we have all failed because we have failed completely to understand what creates prejudice. We have failed to educate people. We ought to have started in the schools to make people understand why they fear something that is different. I mentioned in my question to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-this is something that I want to take up in this Party and the Parliament in the future-that we will not legislate against it; we will not even reason with people. We can only start on a long program of education to abolish prejudice in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by saying that I find this debate distasteful. The fact is that I feel that I am a reluctant participant. This is not because I am unable to support my Party's policy; I certainly can. I have listened to speakers so I am talking from the heart more than from the mind. Regrettably in my view, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sought to place a mortgage on tolerance, understanding, humanitarianism and compassion-as if they were all attached to that side of the House. That is not the case. I know that behind the motion that has been introduced into this Parliament, there is not the feeling that we should evoke a spirit of comradeship to all in this nation but to play politics. That is the root of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not even sure what I will say today because I feel rather deeply about this issue. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) suffered the sorts of hatred and indignity that I have never had to suffer. I commenced my political career 27 years ago by getting myself censured by the endorsing body of the State executive of the Liberal Party of Australia for being critical of my Party's then immigration policy. I ought to say that I was more critical of my political opponent's immigration policy because when I first stood for Parliament I had supporting me students with faces painted black, to make a point. My political opponent was Dr J. F. Cairns. He was standing on a platform that contained within it the maintenance of the white Australia policy. It is very interesting to reflect upon-I do so very warmly because of the contest of the time-the fact that the current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) was Dr Cairns's campaign manager.

The nature of the campaign that was conducted, other than on that issue, was one that we have reflected on with warmth from time to time. Thirteen years ago, accompanied interestingly enough by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), I visited Indo-China in the last days of the war in Cambodia. Indeed, in Phnom Penh we had to be air lifted out to Saigon and I saw the slaughter, the pillage and the destruction being wrought on a scale that I had never experienced. I will not dwell on that, for the relevance of it is solely that, at that time, I came back and privately sought to persuade the government of the day-which dare I remind honourable members was a Labor government-to be humane and understanding and to take in people who were seeking to get out over the border through Thailand. The then Prime Minister wanted nothing of it. I saw the ignomitny of embassy officials receiving cables to go out and grab little Vietnamese waifs and put them most reluctantly, on a plane but with a fanfare of publicity to show that the Government was going to make a token gesture.

Where was the warmth, compassion, tolerance and understanding at that time? I participated in the Cabinet discussions to take in Indo-Chinese refugees. I cannot help but say that I did not receive well the remarks of the Prime Minister when he stood here today and commenced with the statement that the feature of political leadership on immigration in this country has been a triumph of, among other things, compassion. When I, with the then immigration Minister, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), was traversing this nation in 1977 trying to tell the populace that we did not just have a duty but that we were abundantly bound to take these people who were coming to our shores, I heard the words of the present Prime Minister on compassion when he said, `Of course we should have compassion but people who are coming in this way are not the only people in the world who have rights to our compassion. Any sovereign country has the right to determine how it will exercise its compassion'. That was a nice bit of manipulative compassion-how it will exercise its compassion and how it will increase its population. I feel a touch of distaste listening to some who wish to claim the mortgage in this arena.

The Prime Minister then said that this side of politics had broken with the tradition of bipartisanship. I do not know where his notions of bipartisanship were in 1977 when he said, `Obviously, there are people all around the world who have a strong case for entry into this country'. Successive governments have said we have an obligation, but we also have an obligation to people who are already here. In the past a number of people have questioned immigration programs in this country. At the time they were not branded as racist because they questioned these things. The honourable member for Robertson made some very moving remarks in his speech. I do not agree with his criticism. But again, one cannot rewrite history in this place. It is all on the record. Honourable members opposite should not tell me that when we changed the white Australia policy in 1966-67 the Labor Party could have played on that issue but chose not to because it would divide the nation. They should get their facts right. The platform of the party was changed around 1963 or 1964. They would not have been able to embark on that criticism.

Oh, they had their spokesmen. On this question of selectivity, when I came into this Parliament a few years after the last campaign-better organised by the Minister who was campaign manager for Jim Cairns-the Labor Party had a spokesman. He is the current clown of Australian political commentary. He provides comments for 30 pieces of silver at any time at the drop of a hat. If one rings him to get him on radio to make a political comment one goes through his agent. His name is Frederick Michael Daly and 99.9 per cent of the time he denigrates my side of politics. He was the Labor Party's immigration spokesperson after I came into the Parliament. He is a believer in the white Australia policy. Honourable members should not tell me that they are the only ones who can propagate a view founded, in the words of the Prime Minister, on the brotherhood of mankind. I have just seen honourable members opposite at work. I have experienced their operations. I know that within the document that was produced by the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies it is suggested that the current migration policy is a shambles. I wish we had more time today but we are too far down the line to discuss the elements of that report. Honourable members opposite know that they have got the wrong immigration program. They know that, regrettably, they have been bringing in too many unskilled and old people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—The Minister says `nonsense' but two days before the FitzGerald report came out in June this year his Government changed the points system to allocate more points for skill. The aim of an immigration policy was to give some economic development to this nation. However, by bringing in the unskilled, the Government did not do that. By bringing in the old instead of the young, the Government has in no way contributed to slowing down that element of the ageing of the Australian population. I could quote Dr Theophanous; I could quote a whole host of people. Frankly, I will end as I began-I do not care about the clock-by saying that I find this debate distasteful. I have said publicly that I will not belong to a party that engages in racism. I do not want my Party or my country to be branded as international pariahs and those people who would seek to do it are wrong. I find much to criticise in the Government's immigration program. I find it extraordinary that as the Government propagates itself as the best administrator of immigration, it is doing it in the week in which its own Immigration Minister has been sacked. So whether it is the high ground or the low ground the Government chooses, it too has a lot to answer for in regard to what is transpiring here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Duffy) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The fallacy of a Budget strategy which relies heavily on the continued high level of mineral and commodity prices yet makes it increasingly difficult to produce them.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Leader of the National Party of Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget has been framed against the background of a world economy which has performed dramatically better than most people expected at the time of the October share market crash last year. Therein lies one of the great strengths of this year's Budget, but also, ironically, its great and looming weakness. This Budget's success is almost utterly dependent on strong world economic growth and maintenance of the recent rise in Australia's commodity prices. If these turn sour, the Budget strategy and the optimism of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will both be in tatters.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I do not propose to indulge in criticism of the Budget for its own sake. The reality is that the economic debate in Australia has changed enormously in recent years. There is now much wider acceptance right across the political spectrum of the simple fact that Australia is directly affected by the world economy and that our economic policies must respond to the judgments of others about our economic performance. Some economic policy differences between the Government and the Opposition have narrowed. In many respects we no longer argue about the direction of change but, rather, the pace, the methodology and, importantly, who should be the beneficiaries of that change.

Today's debate is concerned less and less with annual budgets and more about the nature and extent of structural change. We all want a more prosperous nation and rising living standards. We differ about how this can best be achieved. This changed debate is partly a direct product of the world-wide loss of faith by governments of all political persuasions in government intervention, government controls and state enterprise as solutions to economic problems. We are witnessing at the moment throughout the world greater acceptance of market-driven free enterprise solutions than at any time since World War II.

There are features of this Budget that I welcome. I welcome the additional rent assistance for low income families, although the initial increase will not be available for 10 months. Skyrocketing rents, particularly in major cities, are a huge problem for Australia's poor. The increased financial support for employment development amongst Aborigines is a sensible, practical way of reducing Aboriginal disadvantage. The Liberal and National parties have repeatedly said that the way to help Aborigines is not through divisive concepts such as treaties, which are the opposite of our `One Australia' message, but by directly addressing the cause of Aboriginal disadvantage.

The Treasurer's optimistic growth, inflation and current account deficit forecasts are all in themselves welcome. I hope that his optimism is vindicated. The Treasurer's commitment to bringing our inflation rate into line with that of our trading partners is long overdue, but nonetheless welcome. Policy differences between the Government and the Opposition on some economic issues may have narrowed. However, one great fundamental difference does, and always will, remain. This Government believes that the future wealth and prosperity of Australia can only be the product of bargains struck between the Government and powerful interest groups in our community. By contrast, we on this side of the House believe that greater national prosperity can only result from the efforts and achievements of individual men and women given the right incentives to work harder, excel and achieve.

Three valid and objective criticisms can be made of the Budget. First, the surplus is much more the product of high taxation than of reduced spending. Secondly, as I have already said, the Budget's success is almost utterly dependent on strong world growth and a maintenance of the recent recovery in Australia's commodity prices. Thirdly, the Budget is virtually silent on structural economic reform. Whatever happened to the bold declaration by the Treasurer in May that the next big item on the reform agenda was transformation of our labour markets?

This week the Treasurer has truly retained his crown as the highest taxing Treasurer in our peacetime history. He will collect $47.6 billion in tax from individuals over the coming 12 months, which is $5.7 billion more than last year. The average income earner will need $56 a week by way of tax cut on 1 July next year just to restore his real income to the level it was when Labor came to power in March 1983. Labor's tax system has forced more and more ordinary taxpayers into the top marginal tax bracket. That rate now applies at only 1.4 times average weekly earnings. The Treasurer predicts that our inflation rate will be 4.5 per cent next year. He does not boast that in the same year all of us will pay 14 per cent more in taxation or three times his predicted inflation rate.

The Treasurer has promised some relief from his high taxes on 1 July next year, but I say now to the Australian people that there is no way that the tax cut that the Treasurer will inevitably want to give for political reasons, on the eve of the next election, can possibly make up for the disastrous slump in living standards we have experienced over the last five years. The timing of the tax cuts has nothing to do with economics and everything to do with politics. Tax cuts now financed by cuts in government spending would ease the pressure for wage rises, allowing a lower wage outcome, producing lower inflation and interest rates and greater international competitiveness. Labor's call for more sacrifices now is a smokescreen to delay the tax cuts until closer to the next election.

While the Budget has some positive features, some of which I have acknowledged, it betrays once again the Olympian detachment of the Government, particularly the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), from the aspirations and concerns of ordinary Australian families. This Government is out of touch with the growing economic and social malaise in Australia. Outside Canberra it is very plain to see what is happening to our society. People are becoming more insecure as they feel less and less in control of their lives. The pace of change in our society is accelerating. Traditional values and family unity are under attack. Families are coming under great stress. Personal bankruptcies are spiralling, poverty is on the rise and income inequalities are sharpening. Family allowances are now worth 41 per cent less and the dependent spouse rebate 32 per cent less than was the case five years ago. Home loan repayments now average $666 a month, which is about 27 per cent of the median family income, compared with just over 19 per cent in March 1983. About 700,000 households are below the poverty line, including about 40,000 families with children. It is estimated that 40,000 Australians are permanently homeless, with another 60,000 on the verge of being homeless. The stress on families trying to cope is showing up in the divorce statistics, homelessness, the proliferation of drugs and the rise in related criminal activities. These trends are worsened in the case of young people who are locked out of the labour market.

Australians today want greater capacity to control their own lives and how they earn and spend their incomes. They want more accountable governments which interfere less with individual privacy and family rights. They want greater security in the streets and more support for the family unit. They want greater equality of opportunity, irrespective of background. Our approach to economic and social policy rests on the twin pillars of individual freedom and a strong family unit. In every policy area, be it taxation, industrial relations or indeed anywhere else, our goal is that people rather than governments or institutions are best able to make decisions about their own future.

Lower taxation is a fundamental prerequisite of a more productive, incentive-driven economy. The Treasurer is way out of touch with his claim that Australians do not want tax relief now. He should tell that to the great mass of taxpayers in the $19,500 to $35,000 tax bracket. Labor's smash and grab raid on superannuation in the May statement was the ultimate exercise in cynicism. It will do nothing to boost national savings at a time when we continue to rely on foreign savings to the tune of at least 3 per cent of our gross domestic product. The employer tax on superannuation contributions will divert private savings from investment to fund public consumption. So much for Labor's desire to promote savings and investment.

For more than two years we have advocated a lower, two-rate personal tax scale. At the 1987 election we advocated scales of 25 per cent and 38 per cent. The Government said it could not be done. I predict now that this approach will be virtually adopted by the Government in 12 months time. Our approach would emphasise assistance to families, particularly those on middle and lower incomes. Australia's tax system must take account of the fact that it costs more to raise children. A tax policy which does not recognise this central fact is a tax policy without a social vision. A family-based taxation system will ease financial pressures on families and keep more of those families together.

We will also reform taxes which stifle business enterprise and initiative. Our policy is to keep the corporate tax rate in line with the top personal tax rate. We will abolish Labor's capital gains tax. This tax discourages longer term savings and investment, which are so desperately needed if Australia is to reduce its dependence on foreign capital. Shorter term gains will, however, be taxable on a sliding scale over five years. After five years there will be no tax on capital gains. We will also abolish Labor's fringe benefits tax, but where a non-cash benefit is clearly and deliberately provided as a substitute for cash remuneration, that benefit will be taxed as income in the hands of the recipient, as it should be.

Last Tuesday the Treasurer once again failed to acknowledge the overwhelming importance of Australia more efficiently using its physical, human and financial resources. In other words, he will not face the need to lift Australia's productivity. It is indisputable that an increase in Australia's rate of productivity growth will hasten the stabilisation and, in time, the reduction of our foreign debt. Labor is turning its back on a wide variety of measures which could raise productivity on a sustainable long term basis by removing restrictive work practices, increasing competition, raising investment, improving utilisation of the existing capital stock and facilitating structural change.

Labor is preventing an objective and bipartisan debate on the merits of privatisation of public business enterprises. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister were converted to privatisation after the last election. Now they have been forced by their Party's left wing to dismiss privatisation as not part of the `main game'. But is not improved enterprise efficiency and accountability part of the main game? Is not giving enterprise employees a real stake in their workplace and its future part of the main game? Surely it is. Using the proceeds of asset sales to reduce debt is also part of the main game. We have a clear and comprehensive program of privatisation that will give benefits to consumers, taxpayers and enterprise employees. Our proposals will give public enterprise employees the opportunity and incentive to buy shares in their own enterprises. Employees will be offered shares in their own enterprises at a discount.

Efficient and competitive transport and communications are vital to industry competitiveness, particularly for export growth. Labor has squibbed every major test on this front. If shipping costs alone were reduced by 50 per cent, the gains to the economy as a whole would be in excess of $700m a year. Our policy, released recently, directly addresses this issue.
