We will monitor progress by local shipping companies and the relevant unions in reducing manning levels on Australian ships to levels comparable to those of our trading partners. If we do not receive employer and union cooperation, we will introduce foreign competition on coastal shipping routes, but only as a last resort.

In telecommunications, we see many opportunities for potential competition to spur Telecom Australia to lift its game. Under a coalition government, Telecom will be responsible for the basic telecommunications network but will be required to compete on normal commercial terms in the provision of the first home telephone, small business systems, data transmission, information systems and maintenance functions. Deregulation of these services will open up existing possibilities for new and existing small businesses and independent contractors.

The labour market must be reformed if Australia is to become a genuinely competitive, outward looking economy. Our inflation rate remains nearly double that of our major trading partners, labour productivity is woeful and youth unemployment is still far too high. Labor's recent experiment with the second tier wage approach was a recognition that wage increases which are not based on productivity are unsustainable and provide no incentive to better workplace performance. The new wages system is a retrograde step. Wages could grow by more than 7 per cent in 1988-89, with little productivity offset.

Our new industrial relations policy provides a more flexible framework for industrial relations at the enterprise level. Our policy promotes voluntary enterprise level agreements between workers and their employers. These agreements will be available to enterprises of any size and could cover work practices, introduction of new technology and management methods and other ways to improve enterprise productivity and profitability. We will also act to protect the rights of the individual in the workplace; we will outlaw closed shops and abolish the power to grant preference to trade union members. We will enact compulsory secret ballots before strike action to ensure that workers are not intimidated by union bosses into unnecessary strikes. We will legislate to ensure that there are effective sanctions for those who fail to comply with the decisions and orders of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Labor's proposed graduate tax is a classic Labor mixture of higher taxes and further centralisation of power in Canberra. We are committed to providing young people with greater choice in higher education. The Liberal and National parties will open up universities and colleges of advanced education to the 20,000 or more students who are currently locked out by Labor's policy. The coalition policy is to provide free places by awarding scholarships to the nation's best applicants and also to allow institutions to accept additional applicants on a mutually acceptable basis. In this context a Liberal Government will provide greater autonomy to higher education institutions, reduce government regulation, and encourage universities and colleges to develop new sources of revenue to supplement government funds. Institutions will be encouraged to become more flexible and creative.

Labor's nationalised health system should be renamed Medimess. Health costs are rising, quality of service is declining and hospital waiting lists are lengthening. Throwing further money at the symptoms will not cure the problem. The Liberal and National parties will restore choice in the health area and cut costs in the delivery of health services. There will be a much greater role for private health insurance funds within a climate of greater competition. In addition, there will be restoration of a proper balance between private and public hospitals. We will end the Labor Party's ideologically motivated neglect of private hospitals, which provide real competition in price and service for our ailing public hospitals.

The Liberal and National parties will provide Australians with the choice of home ownership. Home ownership is becoming a privilege limited to the well-off in our community. There are over 79,000 applicants waiting for assistance under Federal and State home purchase assistance programs. Our priority is to help people to get into their own homes rather than make them forever dependent on the state, and that is the centrepoint of our new housing policy. Our goal is to eliminate the twin barriers to home ownership for low income families, namely, the need for a deposit to secure a home loan and the inability to afford mortgage repayments because of high interest rates.

The first home owners scheme has assisted many first home buyers. The scheme will be improved and better targeted. As a first step the coalition will eliminate the deposit gap for low income first home buyers. We will encourage home lenders to provide a loan of 100 per cent of the fair valuation of an eligible purchaser's first home by having the Commonwealth meet the cost of mortgage insurance. The assistance will be means tested and subject to maximum borrowing limits.

While the Government indulges in an orgy of self-congratulation over the size of the Budget surplus, Australians will see nothing in this Budget which will make one bit of difference to their real take home pay. Just as Australia remains firmly in the hands of overseas financial markets, so ordinary Australians will continue to feel alienated and powerless in their personal lives. The taxation and industrial relations policies I have briefly outlined tonight will provide greater incentives for individual productivity and investment. We will give all employees the opportunity to acquire a real financial stake in their enterprise and thereby promote greater identification with the fortunes of their work place. Our policies of active income support will promote a greater unity by ensuring that welfare dependants are not excluded from meaningful work opportunities.

The Labor Party is increasingly being constrained by its ideological blinkers and vested union interests from implementing policies which are in the interests of the entire Australian community. The Liberal and National parties have frequently dictated the economic agenda for the past few years. The Labor Party has reluctantly adopted, as it well knows, many of our economic policies under the pressure of external economic shocks. Members of the Labor Party know that as well as we do. Time and time again policies that they once derided have been adopted under the pressure of external economic circumstances. Time and time again the Labor Party has said to us, `It can't be done', but twelve months later it has turned around and done it, claiming such initiatives as its own. I would say to the Labor Party that we are only too happy to go on providing the intellectual lead in the economic debate, and we will go on providing it in the labour market area as we have provided it in so many other areas.

The reality is that the Labor Party has reached the limits of its policy flexibility now. We have already released policies for industrial relations, housing, transport, aviation, communications and privatisation. Other policies will be released shortly. Our policies are pitched squarely at decent hardworking Australians who want to believe in their government again and who want the government to believe in them as well. We believe in our fellow Australians, in their wish to work hard, to save more and to make this a better country for all. That is why our policies seek to return power and decision making to people, and that is the essence of what one Australia is all about.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hollis) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—Earlier today the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) accused me of quoting from his response to last year's Budget. Apparently I did, but I am in pretty good company because so did the Sydney Morning Herald. The Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August this year quoted from a Press statement of the honourable member for Mackellar from 12 months ago. One can only conclude that either the honourable member for Mackellar gave that newspaper his last year's Press statement or else there have been so few of his Press statements that the media have been forced to recycle them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned at about 5.45 this evening we had just had a contribution from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). He said when he started that he was not too sure of what he was going to say. At various stages during his contribution he attacked the policy, which he obviously found abhorrent and which he referred to as the white Australia policy, and he attacked some people in the Australian Labor Party. One can only conclude that in that obviously genuine contribution by the honourable member for Kooyong he was supporting, at least in his heart, the motion and not the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: After 5 1/2 years the Liberal-National Party coalition still cannot come up with policies to match those of this Government and win the confidence of the Australian people. In what can only be described as a desperate, mistaken belief based on some sort of polling, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has thrown out decades of bipartisanship on migration. His failure to evolve economic policies has led him down a path on migration that is certain to lead to the economic destruction of this country. I do not consider that that is an overstatement. Our Asian neighbours will well remember the disgraceful white Australia policy referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition earlier tonight-a policy that was based on ignorance and prejudice. That policy of European racial superiority soiled our international image for decades and it held back Australia's trade within our region.
Personal Explanation

The future of this country-it seems the majority of those opposite do not understand this-lies in our ability to trade, and it is the Asia-Pacific region which is the biggest growth area for trade in the world. With our geographic location we must have firm but friendly relations with all our neighbours. Honourable members opposite have to understand that we cannot just tow this country away and put it somewhere else. We are where we are. As Australia is looking more to its regional neighbours for trade, economic, defence and other ties, Asian migrants will be a huge asset in this country.

The Opposition's policy is putting at risk billions of dollars worth of trade and the economic future and well-being of generations of Australians to come. It has taken years to convince our neighbours that we are not prejudiced against them. The motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) calls upon this House to recognise that the racially non-discriminatory immigration policy pursued by successive governments has been to the overwhelming national and international benefit of Australia-a policy now thrown away in a desperate attempt to gain votes. Appealing to the prejudices of some people to gain votes is an indication of the desperate position that has been reached in the Opposition.

It is not an exaggeration to say that we are very fortunate to be located in the world's fastest growing economic region-the Asian-Pacific region. All of the information shows that trans-Pacific trade now exceeds the historic focus of international trade on the Atlantic. According to a report of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade issued on 3 August, Asia has been the most dynamic exporting region in the world since 1980. Therefore, our economic future is closely linked to that of our Asian neighbours. Our ability to expand and broaden our economic linkages with our neighbours will be a significant factor in determining our country's economic and social prosperity.

The western Pacific region is already of major significance to Australia's trade. I think it is well worth some of those opposite thinking about the significance of that. In 1987, putting aside New Zealand, 49.4 per cent of the total exports of this country were directed to the western Pacific region and 36.9 per cent of our imports were from that region. In the agricultural sector Japan and Taiwan accounted for more than $70m of our lamb exports. Our sixth largest market for milk and cream dairy products was all the Asian countries. Japan and China accounted for $900m worth of our wool exports. Maybe it is worth the National Party having a think about the fact that Australian farmers appreciate the importance of this market, even if the Opposition does not.

I turn to the area of vital mineral exports. Japan, China and the Republic of Korea were our three major markets for iron ore. Japan and the Republic of Korea were our major markets for zinc ore. Japan, the Republic of Korea and Taiwan accounted for more than $3 billion of our coal exports. Again, I am sure that the mining industry does not have to have explained to it the crucial importance of the Asian markets for its products. The Asian-Pacific region is also important in the growing export market for services, accounting for 33 per cent of our total exports in 1987. Tourism, education and health services all offer considerable export growth potential in the region.

The region contains countries at varied stages of economic development and industrial sophistication. One of the challenges, as well as one of the opportunities, that this creates for Australia is through the investment flows both in and out of this country. An important element of the Government's strategy in the development of our links with the region has been to promote that two-way investment. The exchange of investment missions to Japan, for example, is a most important way for Australian industry, firstly, to secure access to the Japanese market and, secondly, to secure access to technologies and skills for use within Australian operations, allowing it to increase its international competitiveness. Australia's role in this area must be to have a non-racially discriminatory approach to migration.

It is all very well for those opposite to come in here this afternoon and move amendments, attempt to change a paragraph here and there and come in with all the weasel words. But there is no doubt as to the perception Asia has of the proposition being put forward by the other side. It is not a figment of our imagination to suggest that this current debate on immigration policy, begun by the Leader of the Opposition-that is where it started-will harm Australia's standing and image in the region and internationally. This afternoon we had contributions from this side of the House by the Prime Minister and other speakers which were based more on the moral aspects of this debate. I have attempted to outline some of the more hard-nosed aspects of it because I think the other areas were so well covered today.

I would particularly like to pay tribute to my friend and colleague the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), who was able to spell out to the House this afternoon something which we can talk about but which not many of us have suffered. Leaving aside the hard economic facts that have been put forward tonight-and it is about time the Opposition started to think about them-the Opposition ought to go away and think about what the honourable member for Robertson said.

I come back to the point that, no matter how honourable members opposite move amendments or change paragraphs, the perception of what they are on about exists now in Asia. They should not make any mistake about that. The Prime Minister of Singapore, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, has already said that Australia is being damaged by this debate. The debate has been widely reported in the region's media. Headlines have been featured. Examples of those headlines are as follows: in the Times of India, `Australians hostile to Asian Influx'; in the Indian Express, `Aliens row revived in Australia'; in the Far Eastern Economic Review, `A wolf in white clothing'; and in the Kuala Lumpur Star, `Racist thinking will only make it hard for Aussies'. Just as Asian immigrants in Australia know what it is all about, so do those people in the region.

The debate has set back the image of a multicultural tolerant society which both parties have striven to develop in this country. The white Australia bogy has been revived by the Opposition. When we look at the reaction in the region in which we are living, we should also look at the Times of India, which began a lead story on this issue in this way:
White Australia's drive to build a more multi-racial society still faces strong opposition from a large section of the community.
That strong opposition, unfortunately, is coming from within this Parliament as a result of this debate which was started by the Leader of the Opposition.

Let us make no mistake about the question of business migration. If it is believed, as a result of what is being said on the other side and out in the community by many people now, that Australia is a racist society, those people are not going to come here. They will not come here, for the sorts of reasons that were put forward this afternoon by the honourable member for Robertson. They will not come to this country if they perceive this country as being prejudiced and as returning to what the honourable member for Kooyong talked about, namely, a policy based on ignorance and prejudice. We do not want it again and they do not want it again.

We should not delude ourselves that Australia is the only place that business migrants will be looking to. Other countries such as Canada are actively wooing these people, conscious of the benefits that such immigration can bring to the country. They are not being divided by the debate which is going on in this country at the moment. It was unnecessary. It should never have started. Those opposite will regret it for a long while.

In summary, the reservations and misgivings that the Opposition's statements on immigration have created seriously threaten our ability to participate in the massive economic growth of the western Pacific region. Not only is the Opposition seen to be reverting to an offensive white Australia policy but in so doing our vital trade investment and other economic interests will be seriously threatened-and so they should be if people see that this country is going back to previous policies. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition became very emotional about the white Australia policy, and justifiably so. That seems to be the direction in which the parties opposite are heading again. As I said, it is no good coming in here today and trying to move amendments, change paragraphs and shift words because that perception of what they are on about has gone too far in the region that we are part of, in the region that is absolutely significant to us. Remember the two quotes I made earlier `A wolf in white clothing' from the Far Eastern Economic Review and `Racist thinking will make it hard for Aussies' in the Kuala Lumpur Star. The Opposition parties have made the situation pretty tough. It is not too late to back off from their position but it is about time some people opposite had a very long, hard think about this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Opposition is concerned-and for many years it has been the case-the white Australia policy is dead and buried. To have repetition of it and constant referral to it from the Government side does nothing to bring about the effects that the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) claimed he was seeking to achieve. The Minister and other Government speakers in this debate have sought deliberately to create divisions. They have constantly spoken about the re-emergence of the white Australia policy. Nothing could be further from the truth and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, knows that.

SPEECH.PARA: Migrants coming to Australia, under our policy, will be chosen as individuals and they will not be chosen in any way on the grounds of race, religion or ethnic origin. That is a fact and that is in our policy. We have said that as a government we will reserve the right from time to time to vary and alter the policy, including adjustments to the size and composition of the immigration program, in response to changing requirements, be they social, economic, political or humanitarian.

Our comments are made responsibly for the future direction of migration and population growth of this nation. None of our comments as presented by the Australian Labor Party relates to people living in Australia. Our policy says clearly that we are proud of the individuals that have come to Australia whether they have been here for five years, for 40 years or were born here-they are equal Australians. The Australian Labor Party in some of its programs seeks to perpetuate differences. We will not tolerate that. People will all be first class Australians; there will be no second class Australians. The direction of our policy will be to focus more fully on generating public confidence in a program that has lost public confidence due to the poor administration and explanations offered by the Australian Labor Party.

After five years of confusion the Government has the community in confusion. There have been five Immigration Ministers in five years, a confused Government, a confused Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a series of confused Ministers-three in the last eight months. Does that inspire confidence and the sense of continuity, application and sensitivity that have been displayed by people such as the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), who worked constantly year after year at the job. Millions of Australians have on their citizenship certificates the signatures of Liberal and National Party Ministers. They know the compassion and thought that goes into the development of immigration programs delivered by our governments.

Let us deal with some of the confusion the Government has created. Firstly, it erected an inquiry into the future of immigration. The Prime Minister did not like the results and tried to fiddle with them. The most significant document in this area was brought into this Parliament in the last stages in the old Parliament House and dumped on the table. The Opposition was given 10 minutes to respond at that time. No wonder people are confused. The Government is not prepared to let the Australian people talk about immigration except in the Government's terms. We believe that the national interest is involved and that the Australian people ought to have a say. They should participate in a sensible debate, not the sort of debate that is going on here raised by the Government tonight, not the sort of debate in which constant divisions are being perpetuated by speeches by Government Ministers. What do we find now? Further confusion from the Labor Party: a whole series of more inquiries going on by Caucus committees and subcommittees of this and that all over the countryside. At some time the Australian people will find out what the Labor Party has in mind for an immigration program that has flagged and been confused for five years.

Our proposition is that there shall be no racial characteristics in the selection of individuals. There will be no religious characteristics in the selection of individuals, and ethnic origin will not be looked at either. What has the Australian Labor Party been doing in the last five years apart from having five Immigration Ministers, three of them in the last eight months. The FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies makes it very clear. I will not quote from the FitzGerald report but that Committee of distinguished Australians, who were each chosen to sit on that Committee by the Government's Minister, was acceptable to the Government: it was hardly a Liberal Party group. I do not reflect on the political attitudes of its members-I do not know them-but the Committee was not selected by a Liberal government. It was the Labor Party's own committee. Paragraph after paragraph of its report condemns the administration, application and relevance of the immigration programs of this Government, and to some extent those of previous governments.

Our policy is to have a five-year program so that there is continuity in the system so local and State governments and private enterprise know where they are going, so that they understand what immigration policies mean to the future of this nation. We want an intelligent and measured debate, not the sort of debate that has been brought on by the Prime Minister to get the Treasurer (Mr Keating) off the box tonight. It was brought on by the Prime Minister in a way that I believe is not in the best interests of Australia, because the divisive attitudes and comments from the Government continue. What has the Government done? No wonder people are confused. There are now 750,000 illegal immigrants in Australia. The enforcement group within the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will take a year to find illegal immigrants. There have been overruns of massive proportions in the immigration programs.

The Government's programs and points score system have not been able to control the applicants in the style that is best suited to the needs of Australia. The unskilled proportion of the program has jumped from 17 per cent to 50 per cent. The Minister has been asked 24 times to go on the program A Current Affair to explain the Government's immigration policy. He has refused on all of those occasions. Why?

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister?

—The temporary Minister. The fourth Minister is going and the fifth Minister is coming in. It is not the role of government to create that sort of confusion. Let me quote just briefly from a summary from FitzGerald, which I think summarises the situation. FitzGerald says this:

SPEECH.PARA: So what people seem to be saying is that they will continue to go along with immigration if it can be `their kind' of immigration. Their kind is often in conflict with someone else's. But it is their kind, and the common ground of their kind, which is important at this time to government.

The Government has a role to find the way ahead in an immigration program that is in the best interests of the whole of Australia. This concerns all citizens-those who have been here for five years or 40 years and those who were born here. Government should be concerned with gathering together citizens in the best interests of the whole nation.

What has the Government done? It has appointed more committees. How can there be confidence in what the Government is about? FitzGerald has mentioned the need for confidence in the Government's program. Let me refer to the way in which the Government operates its program. The Government has in fact listed nine principles in the current immigration handbook in regard to the way in which the program will be administered. In the second chapter, principle No. 1 states:
It is fundamental to national sovereignty that the Australian Government alone should determine who will be admitted to Australia.

Is the motion that is before us tonight seeking to take away the basic principle of national sovereignty? I believe that it is. If the Government says that it is committed to absolutely no discrimination, it should run its programs in that way and be judged by the community. Do not put up motions in the House. It should live by that principle-or is it going to remove it now?

The Opposition's policy makes it perfectly clear that we accept that responsibility. We are happy to be judged by the Australian community and international community in terms of the programs that we will run in selecting people on their individual merits, for their skills, knowledge and the contribution that they can make to Australia. The continuation of family reunions, the refugee program-the whole gamut of our program-is designed to give greater emphasis to job creating migrants who can benefit this nation in terms of their own future and the future of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut the Asian family reunion.
—The Minister is raving about family reunions. I say to the Minister that the traditional family reunion of spouse, children and aged parents stands unviolated in our policy and it will continue.
—You will cut the Asian family reunion, that is what you will do.
—I do not know what the occupant of the chair is doing, but he seems to be allowing the Minister to rave his head off any time he wants to.
—Order! The Minister will remain silent.

—I would like to tell the Minister that family reunions as a proportion of the program will decline. But in an enlarged program of additional migrants, who will be skilled, knowledgeable, educated and employment creating, the number of family reunion migrants will fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Where does the Government see its responsibility to the Australian people? It has chosen not to exercise its responsibility. On the other hand, we will make sure that individuals are chosen on the basis of the suitability of the contribution they can make to Australia. We will increase Australia's immigration program with the sort of individuals that I have described, and they will not be selected on race. However, government must have the prerogative to act in the national interest. It should be able to reserve its right to say that immigration must be under the control of an Australian government. That proposition covers all the principles and aspects of our program. Now the Government is saying that it is drawing back from exercising its sovereign right. The Australian people believe that the Government has not been exercising that right for a long time. The Government has not explained, it has not educated, and it has not tried to take people along in its thinking.

Let me explain one of the ramifications of ad hoc decisions that have been taken by the Government. The decision by Minister West suddenly to change the composition of the refugee program has left stranded in Indo-China thousands of close relatives of people who are now Australian citizens. The Government is not concerned about that; nor has it explained. Instead, it is going to put an additional tax on those refugee families to re-sponsor their relatives. That is adhockery and selectivity if ever I have seen it. In the Australian Labor Party's 1983 policy, Mick Young talks about slowing down trans-Tasman immigration. In Thailand, Mick Young also talked about the quota for that country. Talk about selectivity and a hidden agenda! Put it up front and take responsibility for your actions. The Government stands to be judged by the Australian people. It should have no secret agendas. The Government should have a program for which it takes control and is seen to be responsible to the whole Australian community. It is time that the Government did so. It is time that it was honest, as our policy is honest, on the role of government in the immigration programs of the Australian nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have been an impressive speech if it had not been backed up by such appalling nonsense in terms of policy. If the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who is the Opposition spokesman on immigration, believed what he said, he would have no problem in supporting the Government's motion. The third part of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: gives its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.

What the motion says is this: if we think that too many people are coming in under the family migration program, we should say so. It is perfectly legitimate under the framework of this motion to have that view. If we think that there are not enough people coming in under the proposal to admit business migrants, we should say so. It is perfectly permissible within the framework of this item to do so and to be consistent about it. This item does not invite one jot, tittle or element of agreement with Government immigration policy except in one area alone, and that is: whatever one decides, whether one takes the view that migrants should be more oriented to business, whether one thinks that we need more families of migrants in this country, whatever view one has on that, the one thing that one must not do-and this ought to be common ground between us-is to make the issue of race or ethnic origin a criterion. That is all. We are not asking the Opposition to agree to anything but that. This is a very, very simple proposition.

We acknowledge that there is ample area for legitimate debate. However, sometimes we feel that the Opposition, given other lines that it is running, may not be aware of some of the consequences of the positions that it adopts. But it is to be expected that there will be disagreement between us on those sorts of issues. But there ought to be no disagreement between us on the issue of race.

I had a curious sense of deja vu when I read the Opposition's amendment to the motion. I tried to recollect when I last saw three-page amendments with confusing wording on difficult issues put before the House of Representatives. I am afraid that I was taken back into my own history to occasions when the Australian Labor Party could not agree on anything. Our common tactic when we were in a state of total confusion-and I must confess that although this was a long time ago, there have been occasions on which we have been in a state of total confusion-was to produce a three-page document, at least half of which was totally meaningless.

I am very glad to see that the noble tradition of confused and divided oppositions is carried on by our predecessors in that role. Let me warn them that, whilst they remain in that condition, that is exactly where they will be. Over the last decade or so we have been far more clear cut, but for those of us who are history minded there are some pleasant features of this document, taking us back to our childhood. The confusion comes when we actually get down to where the document refers to the issue of race. Every effort is made to establish euphemisms, but we get the guts of the policy when the document states:
. . . confirms that this means that any government must reserve the right from time to time to vary and alter policy, including adjustments to the size and composition of the immigration program-
no problems there-
in response to changing requirements-
that is fine; no problems with anyone who holds that view in supporting our motion-
be they social, economic, political or humanitarian.

There are no problems with `economic, political or humanitarian'. But what does `social' mean? Quite clearly, what we mean by `social' in this particular framework is race. That is what we mean by `social'. That is the word that makes these two motions effectively incompatible because it is covering the Liberal Party's position.

Occasionally we have the privilege in this place to sit and listen to genuinely great speeches. They happen once every few years-not very often. When they occur they are likely to occur on either side of the House. We cannot guarantee which side of the House they are going to come from. When they occur they are not likely to be attacks by one individual on the opposite party or a policy of the opposite party but words or speeches used to change the opinion inside the ranks of one's own party. Dissent on individual policy items is natural in politics. That is pretty easy. We have disagreements in the Labour Party, we vote on them at conferences, and there are winners and losers. We have fights in Caucus. That is part of the warp and woof of politics. We live with it, and the public must be expected to live with that too. That is not the problem. There will be plenty of dissidents and many who would like to take their position on the floor of this House. But every now then a leader of a party or a person in a leading position or a member of a party on the back bench will recognise that there is something going seriously wrong inside the party. It may have nothing to do with the words or with specific policies, but it has something to do with the heart and soul of the party. That is the point at which leadership is exercised. That is the point when somebody stands up and blows the whistle, turns to the back bench, or if he is on the back bench turns to the front bench, and says, `Listen, take hold of yourselves. What you are doing has serious implications.'

There was one speech in my memory, and it is possibly the best of the speeches I have heard in this place, where that was done. It was made by John Howard in this place and I think he was Deputy Leader of the Opposition at that time. The words he said ought to ring like bells through this debate. In fact, they are Banquo's ghost at the feast, basically. He accurately stated:
During that debate-
that is the Liberal Party conference-

which was reported extensively by the media, I expressly rejected the proposition that the Liberal Party should take a stand against Asian immigration. I supported the policies of the former coalition Government which were humanitarian and liberal in the true sense of the word. We were prepared to take, with the Labor Party's generous support, people from war-torn parts of South East Asia. We were prepared to persuade people around Australia to accept that policy. We were prepared to preach tolerance and liberalism.

That has been quoted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this chamber, but there are other parts of that speech that are worthy of quoting. The Leader of the Opposition reveals that he understands that code words and the like can enter into a political debate and that, when they do, then stands must be taken. He quotes with authority a letter written to him by a Jewish friend of his who he says has high connections in the Labor Party. The letter states:

It is very important that all of us on both sides of the political fence do everything we possibly can over the next few months to make sure that racism does not in any way intrude into the election campaign. I will do my best within the Labor Party, and many of my friends are going to do the same within the Labor Party, to bring that about, and I ask you to try to do the same within your Party.

That letter was quoted with approval. That was what the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition believed he was doing. He was not messing about with code words or euphemisms; he was saying: `I know what is wrong and I know how to deal with it and I promise on a stack of bibles, or whatever, that I will'. That is what he said when that proposition was presented. There were no ifs, buts, by your leaves or anything else. He knew, when people in his Party were running code words, that that immigration debate had got out of hand at that point. He knew exactly what it meant and he promised in this Parliament, turning to speak to his Party as much as he turned to us, that he would be seen in the ranks of the people who would not permit this to develop.

What a sorry state we are in now where we see absolutely every political tactic, every tendency, every policy orientation repudiated by the Leader of the Opposition in his sophistry here today. It is a depressing sight, because there are not often opportunities when people on both sides of this House can render serious damage to the national interest, and most members of parliament, particularly leaders, evade doing that. On this occasion a Leader of the Opposition has openly gone out and touted for business.

When the debate took place in 1984 the dogs were baying and they were off and running. It was out in the open, and what was attempting to be done was to calm them. This particular initiative of the Leader of the Opposition-however he may back and fill on it now-came out of the cold, clear blue sky. He walked back into political debate in this country touting that sinister element of our politics that he had so correctly identified four years before, seeking to exploit it politically. I believe he will find politics in this country far more complex than he would believe. It is simply not enough to go by the odd opinion poll. Opinion is much more complex. People are capable of holding seemingly contradictory views in their minds at the same time. Unfortunately, we on this side of the House found that out about the Communist Party Dissolution Bill. Members of the Labour Party agreed in the end with Dr Evatt that that was an absolutely execrable offence against the civil liberties of our population; but after Doc Evatt took that stand on civil liberties the people never trusted him again in this country to deal with the issue of communism. They never trusted him again-unjustifiably, but that was nevertheless the case.

It may well be that there is concern amongst some elements of the community about issues related to Asian migration to this country, but those elements in the community are just as capable of at the same time standing up and, when they see their views put into starkest context by their political leadership, believing their political leadership extremist. It is no accident that those who run these issues in other countries, however well they might be regarded as individuals, are seen as being on the extreme of politics and eccentric, and Enoch Powell has to be the classic case. Enoch Powell is not the Leader of the British Conservative Party, Enoch Powell does not speak for the British Conservative Party. Enoch Powell speaks for himself and he gets a degree of support, but those who support him do not necessarily vote Conservative in the final analysis, nor would they necessarily vote for him if he was leader of the Conservative Party.

We on this side of the House see the Leader of the Opposition as opportunist. I am sure not that that is how the public sees him on this issue. That is the analysis of the political cognoscenti. That is what we do in this hothouse here when we analyse each others policy stances: `You are a man of principle; you are an opportunist'. These things do not necessarily pay the same way in Pereoa. Members of the public are more likely to see a Leader of the Opposition who is a political extremist. When they see political extremists leading the Opposition it gets 25 per cent approval ratings and those people become unelectable.

The Liberal Party of Australia has created, through this debate, a leader who is now unelectable and who cannot ever be trusted by the population, whether or not it agrees with his emphasis, with the sacred trust of prime ministership of this country. Politically, he is finished. The Liberal Party will have to work out how to get rid of him. Part of the process of this will be to come back to his old personality, where the leader of the Liberal Party, like the leader of the Labor Party, must ensure that the sort of spirit and sentiment that can occasionally go abroad within the community is contained. There is a national interest and there is a moral principle to be served in ensuring that that spirit is contained. The good people of this country, no matter whether they like it or not, will allow themselves to be contained on this issue when properly led and will reject those who do not seek to provide them with that sort of leadership which in this area and in this period this country so desperately needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, in a very real sense, a nation of immigrants. It is therefore right that immigration should be high on our list of priorities for public debate. Tonight we have had a motion brought forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We have had speeches with great sincerity on that motion. I instance two from the other side: that given by the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) and that given by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding). I reject the criticisms but I accept the sincerity and passion that they felt for the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: In extraordinary contrast stands the Prime Minister. His hallmark in politics is hypocrisy, but tonight was a shining, luminous and incandescent exercise in political insincerity. What did he do? He came into this chamber and moved a motion. He said, `This is not an attempt to drive the Leader of the Opposition into the ground.' He said that everything would be forgotten if we agreed to the motion. He then went on to say that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was not a racist but something worse. He said that he was a person who would use racism for political purposes. The Prime Minister, of course, is a man who is so far devoid of political principle that he cannot see when he is saying two things at the one time, each of which is in direct conflict with the other. He was talking about reconciliation but what was the real message? It was that this is a political exercise of the first water and the purpose of that political exercise was to use the immigration debate for partisan political purposes. Nothing else. There was no other motive behind this motion. It does not matter that honourable members have made speeches of great sincerity. It does not matter that honourable members on the Labor side and on our side have feelings of deep sincerity and strong emotion about the subject and that we are wedded to the notion of freedom, of dignity, and of a fair go for all. This was a shabby, dirty political exercise.

I am sorry to say that the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) was an accomplice. I listened with some astonishment to him say that what had happened was certain to lead to the economic destruction of this country. The Minister for Trade Negotiations has come in here and said that. Political hyperbole is one thing insincerity is another, and hypocrisy is a third. What do honourable members say about that kind of statement? Nobody believes it and we all know why it was made. He was playing the ventriloquist's doll to the Prime Minister.

The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in the course of a disingenuous speech gave unctuous advice to the Opposition about how we should conduct ourselves. We are the people who have stood for equality, freedom, decency and non-discrimination in this country. It was a Liberal-National government that swept away the white Australia policy. We all know the Prime Minister's suspect record when it comes to the boat people. What did the Minister for Defence, the Leader of the House, say? He said that we were presented with opportunities for serious damage to the national interest. Who has sought to damage the national interest tonight? It is this Government with its extraordinary, inflammatory, dangerous, inaccurate and misleading statements, as made not by the honourable member for Robertson. I have said what I have said about the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

I will now move on and ask these questions: Are there questions that cannot be asked in this society? Are there issues that cannot be addressed? Are there words that we must not speak? Is there not something which is distinctive about the Australian character, the Australian values and the Australian traditions? Do we not want to talk about them? Do we not want to ask ourselves how to shape the future? What is the best way for us all, for those who come here, and for those who are here? Are these not questions that we, as a people and as a parliament, must ask ourselves? Of course they are. Consider Australian humour. We all know we are Australian. This is an Australian House. Debate here has a particularly Australian characteristic and everybody knows it. We will not find it anywhere else in the world. We will not find the kind of rough and tumble, sometimes gutter type debate that we get here. It is direct, robust, amusing, cynical; it is particularly Australian.

It is like that time during the war-I recall reading about it. Many years ago an Australian officer, during the Second World War, was in Crete. His British counterpart came to him and said, `I suppose, my good man, you've got men in those mountains'. The officer replied, `Yes, but there are more mountains than men'. That was a laconic Australian gallows humour type approach to life and death. It is something which is marked in this country, which has a tradition and a history of great value and great wealth. These are the things that we should ask ourselves. What about our values, our traditions and our future? If we are to be a great nation we must ask ourselves these questions.

I am not talking about any group, but I put this to honourable members: should we, as a nation, represent people who, however admirable they may be, in many ways reject our institutions and laws? I am not talking about a group; I am putting the question, which means very simply this: there are questions that must be asked. I have said to the Minister and to all honourable members that I am not talking about any group. I am simply saying: just as we ask ourselves what our values are, we should ask ourselves whether there are people that we would always welcome here. If people who did not respect our laws wanted to come to this country would we not ask ourselves the questions: Is this right? Is this good? Is this for the purposes of building Australia? I go back to the proposition that was put in this debate, which was very simply this: we are a sovereign country and we have the right to determine who should come to this country, not simply in terms of numbers but for the future benefit of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not on the colour of their skin.

—My friend, I am colour blind! All my life I have rejected any notion of racism, as does the party for which I stand. What do we have here tonight? Let me return to what has been said by the Prime Minister. He claimed that our policy should be repudiated on moral grounds. I noticed when I listened to the speech by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that he did not in any way attack that policy. Is the Labor view of not asking certain questions a moral view? Are there questions that we must never ask ourselves? Are we, as a society, to be frightened to ask certain questions? Of course, if we ask difficult, contentious questions they can cause difficulty and contention. However, we have to ask ourselves this question: Are there certain things that are off the record of public debate?
—No.

—That question has been immediately answered for me by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. He said no, and I agree with him. He has therefore answered and affirmed our case. Let me conclude on the point at which I started. The Government, through the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, and the paltry support given by the Leader of the House, has sought to portray us to this country as somehow guilty of divisions and divisiveness. What is the motion about? What are honourable members opposite about? I am not referring to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in the sincere things he said, or the honourable member for Robertson, who recalled many things-he could have added that dreadful tragedy when, back in 1938 at Evian the world turned its back on Jewish migrants. We all know the consequence of that.
—Your father made a great speech in this House at that time.

—My father? I am sure he did. I thank the honourable member. What do we have? On the one hand we have sincerity; on the other hand we have the empty expedient of a political huckster. That is what the Prime Minister is when he comes in here and moves that motion, with the support of the Minister for Trade Negotiations, and makes the extraordinary, fantastic proposal that we are going to bring about the economic ruin of this country by raising a question for national debate. What are they seeking to do? They are the people who are fuelling the debate that they so decry. They are the people who would put at risk our future. They are driven by the basest and, I must say, the most corrupt of political motives-political exploitation of what they believe to be a perceived advantage because of differences of opinion honestly held in the Opposition. We, unlike them, decide issues according to our conscience and our views. We are the party of all Australians. We are the party of openness, justice and tolerance. We are the party that swept aside the white Australia policy. We are the party for the future and for decency for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and several other honourable members we have heard raised time and again the suggestion that we are trying to prevent a debate on immigration issues. Of course, we are not. That has been made clear by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and many other Government members. As a result of the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies of course we want to see a public debate on the whole question of the selection criteria, the points system and that sort of thing. However, as the Prime Minister has made clear, as the Minister has made clear and as I and many other members have made clear, any such debate must proceed in the context of a non-discriminatory policy and it must not introduce in any way the question of selection on the basis of race.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, rather than taking up positive suggestions which we proposed when we tabled the FitzGerald report-we asked the Opposition to tell us what it thought about the report and other matters-and having a discussion or a constructive debate about the points system and the selection criteria, what did we have? We had a debate on the issues of race and discrimination. We have had reference to the editorial in the Australian newspaper. Despite the fact that other newspapers attacked the policy of the Leader of the Opposition, he quoted from the Australian. The Australian has been running editorials trying to justify the position of the Leader of the Opposition because it is a paper that simply wants to defend the Opposition, no matter what it does. However, the Australian's position and the rationalisation it gives do not go to the central point, which is the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia. Time and again members of the Opposition have said: `Show us in what way our policy is discriminatory?' Let us read the specific clause which shows that the Opposition is discriminatory. Clause 3 of the Opposition's policy reads:

The capacity of the Australian people to accept and absorb change must always be a main factor in immigration policy. The size and composition of our immigration policy should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community.

While there is, of course, a question about the size of our immigration program, when we start to talk about the composition of that program in racial terms and ask, `Can we absorb people in relation to race? Can we absorb people from the Asian community, the Middle East community or any other community?' and when we question whether we can absorb a particular group on the basis of social cohesiveness, we open a Pandora's box. We create a very dangerous situation. That is a dangerous situation which none of us should have opened for debate in this House. Unfortunately, it was opened up by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and Senator Stone and taken up by the Leader of the Opposition. It was even put in the Opposition policy. That was notwithstanding the debate. That was notwithstanding appeals by the Prime Minister and other people to the effect that the Opposition should not put that clause in its policy. That clause clearly is discriminatory. Who is to judge as to whether a particular group will be able to be absorbed into the Australian community? Who is to make that sort of judgment? On what criteria and according to what basis will that decision be made? What country in the world uses that criteria? If there are such countries, obviously they are using racist immigration policies, which we reject. Therefore, for the Leader of the Opposition to get up and say, `Our policy is non-discriminatory, irrespective of the fact that some of my comments have been misunderstood' is rubbish. That clause in the policy has a racist connotation. It is not possible to talk about judging the capacity of a community to absorb people in terms of the racial composition of any group. If we do that, we are really opening the Pandora's box and creating a very dangerous precedent indeed.

As I said, we can discuss all kinds of things in the area of immigration. We will be having discussions. We will be debating the FitzGerald report and so on, but this issue is fundamental and it should never have been raised. The points made by the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), by the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Prime Minister and many other honourable members about what we do when we raise racist criteria of this kind are very valid points. The Opposition's policy contains another objectionable clause. That clause states:
The standard for eligibility and suitability of migrants should reflect Australian social mores and Australian law.

What does that mean? Does that mean that everyone who comes to this country will have to fit into a particular cultural pattern or a particular racial pattern? Is that what is being said? If so, it is a disgraceful performance when set against what we have been standing for over the last 15 years in a bipartisan approach. We appeal once again to the Opposition to reject these approaches. We appeal to the decent members on the other side to support our motion, which contains within it all one needs to have a reasonable debate on immigration. We appeal to decent Opposition members to vote with us on this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has mismanaged immigration policy in the last five years, and the fact that it has had five Ministers for Immigration is confirmation of that point. It has aroused real concerns in the community-concerns which have been mentioned in the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. Therefore, I support the Opposition's amendments criticising the Government and espousing the Opposition's policy. Though I might have wished for some somewhat different wording in some respects in relation to the Opposition's policy, the coalition's commitment to an immigration policy which does not discriminate against people on the grounds race, colour, ethnicity, religion or culture is one that I can support in this amendment. That principle has been fundamental to the coalition's policy since the days of the Holt-McEwen Government. It has been consistently advocated by me with the support of the Cabinet, and then the shadow Cabinet. I am on record, in this House and elsewhere, as unambiguously and unqualifiedly committing myself to the principle of an immigration policy based on non-discrimination on the grounds of race, or colour, or religion, or culture, or ethnicity.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor has been rightly condemned for its political tactic today, but nevertheless the debate is of such fundamental importance that it raises matters on which every member of this House has to vote as a matter of conscience. I belong to a Party that allows members to vote freely on a matter of conscience, although in my 14 years in this place I have not in fact crossed the floor and voted against my Party. I support the Opposition's amendment, but the Government has made it clear that it will defeat that amendment. I therefore intend to vote with the Government against the Opposition's opposition to the Government's motion. I do that because without for a moment running away from the clear obligation which the government of the day has to undo its mistakes in the last five years and explain to the Australian people exactly what is the nature and direction of its immigration policy and what are the realities governing immigration to this country, nevertheless there is an onus on the Opposition to cooperate with the Government.

I am bound to say, and sad to say, that I am worried about statements made by some Opposition spokesmen recently in that regard. I refer of course particularly to the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) in this House and the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Stone), and to the fact that they have not been rebuked or disowned in a way that would have removed ambiguity. Paragraph (3) of the Government's motion speaks of an unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle of non-discrimination. I have that. It is to me the most fundamental thing in my life, and that is a commitment to equality between human beings regardless of any factor at all. I cannot think of anything more fundamental than that. Despite the fact that this is a highly politically motivated debate, in spite of the fact that I have striven not only to try to make a contribution to keeping my Party liberal but to maintain the tradition in this regard that Holt set so many years ago and Fraser and all those who preceded him as leader of the Party maintained, I find that I cannot equivocate and must therefore support the Government's motion.

I ask those who in our community want a racist policy: in what way do Asians threaten social cohesion? Are they anti-family? In fact, we know that they are not. Are they lacking in individual initiative? In fact, we know that they are renowned for their enterprise. Are they afraid of hard work? In fact, we know that many of their critics are critical of them because they work so hard. Are they opposed to democracy? Most of them are fleeing oppression and cherish and want democracy. Are they opposed to speaking English? Those that do not are anxious to learn-and it is a failure again of this Government that it has cut back on much of the migrant language training programs and many of the means of enabling people to learn the language. It is also cutting back on the essential commitment that it made before the last election to teach Australians a second language, primarily an Asian one, and certainly a world trading language, which would enable us to understand other people's cultures better and therefore make a contribution to our own evolving cultural identity and our trade interests. Are Asians opposed to freedoms? Are they unclean? Of course they are not. The record shows the opposite. Indeed, all the experience shows that they are better settlers than are many people from Caucasian countries and many people from countries whose skin or complexion is nearer to that of the European.

I put it with great feeling that it is important that this is now out in the open. It is important that the fears Australians have about people who are different should be exposed, debated and shown to be, as I know them to be, groundless fears. The next generation of Australians will be as amazed about this debate in this House tonight as we are about the debate that took place about the Jews before World War II and after World War II the East Europeans, the Balts and the Mediterraneans. It is absolutely scandalous that anyone with any understanding of history, with any claim to be civilised and liberal, should espouse or give succour to those who dislike people because of the colour of their skin or any other aspect of their cultural and racial origin.

Let us remember that Australia is in the oceans of the Indian and Pacific region. It needs Asia far more than Asia needs Australia. It is unquestionably true that our future is bound up not only in global trading but in particular with trading with the Asian region. It is an insult to all Australians to assume that they cannot cope with the truth, that they cannot give a fair go, that they cannot be tolerant and that they cannot come to grips with the fact that increasingly our migrants will be from Asia. We are not just a nation of immigrants. We will go on for as long as any of us can foresee to be a nation of immigrants, and we shall need migrants of calibre to commit themselves to this country. Any suggestion that there is no social cohesion because of recent migrants is an implied criticism of them. It is utterly unfounded, especially of refugees, who have nowhere else to go, who are so grateful to be given a chance to make a new start in life, and whose commitment to this country is unparalleled compared to those who think that they can go back from whence they have come.

Australians of Asian extraction must really wonder what has gone wrong with their contribution to the development of this country. There are welfare workers, nurses, doctors, lawyers, garbage men and factory workers of Asian extraction who have done everything that could be asked of them by any country. They must now be wondering what else they have to do to gain acceptance. The role of government, the role of opposition and the role of any parliamentary representative is to lead public opinion as well as reflect it. It is extremely important that the government of the day give the lead and the opposition of the day unequivocally assist in the education of people about the facts of life. It is in the national interest to dispel fears, not to reflect and endorse them and not to have a knee-jerk reaction to them. Where is our vision? Where is our sense of reality?

I have said before and I said again only a few months ago that our chances of getting migrants in large numbers from Europe are clearly limited. The European economies are booming and their birthrates are declining. Those people will not want to come here. The people who need to come here, because of discrimination against them in their countries of origin and because they cannot give their skills where they now are, happen to be in Asia. A generation hence they may be somewhere else. If glasnost does not work, these people may well come from Europe again, but for the time being the reality is, whether it is business migration, skills migration, family reunion or whatever other category we have, the migrants will be largely from Asia.

We should take many more migrants; of course we should. I have just come back from a trip to Europe and a little of Asia and there is no doubt about the fact that people in Europe still want to come to Australia, but not in the numbers they once did. We should be more liberal in admitting people; migrants are a necessity for us. Let us not kid the Australian public that we will draw principally from Europe, because over the next few years we will draw largely from Asia. These people will make a great contribution to our country. Honourable members should look at the figures in the FitzGerald report. They should also look at what Dr Charles Price and Dr Jamie Mackie have produced. They will see that even 40 years hence those of Asian origin will be no more than 7 per cent of the Australian population. Australians must understand that there is nothing to fear. Every contribution that will be made by Australians of Asian origin will be at least as great as that made by any other Australian.

Yesterday I had a call from a former Foreign Minister for Papua New Guinea. Along with some other people in this House, I was a resident of Papua New Guinea and this man is a friend of more than 20 years. He said to me, `What is going on in Australia?' It is a second home to him and his kids are still in boarding schools here. Australia is losing so much friendship in the country which was a pseudo colony and a loyal defender of Australia, even when it thought Australia was not right. We have an evolving Australian cultural identity here which is unique and exciting. What is different is the time and the actual racial mix compared with other countries.

Of course it will be one Australia. I do not care whether honourable members call it multiculturalism or one Australia; it amounts to the same thing. We are committed to the same set of principles and values. There must be equality of opportunity emigrating here and there must be equality of opportunity when people get here. There must be affirmative action programs to give them English language skills and a capacity to settle and compete on equal terms. From my knowledge of history and my three years as Minister for Immigration, I cannot envisage any situation in which any future government of this country will have to say, `We will not take migrants from a particular country or a particular part of the world'. To do so would be racist and discriminatory. It is always open to the sovereign government to say that; there is nothing in this motion which would bind a future government and prevent it from saying that. It is important that we should recognise that when Hitler was running Germany many people were persecuted. Six million people died. If they could have escaped, countries such as Australia should have taken them. The same thing applied when Pol Pot was running Cambodia. There is no conceivable situation that I can think of in which we would ever be justified in saying that a particular people should never be admitted to Australia. Of course, when we process people we do not accept terrorists or divisive people. We examine them on a case by case basis, whether they are refugees or migrants.

I am convinced that we need more migrants. I am convinced that the policies which are essentially non-discriminatory and were bipartisan are important for this country. We can argue about administration and detail, but we should explain to the Australian public the realities of migration, why we need people economically and why we need certain policies to help them make their maximum contribution to Australia. We should disown the kind of rubbish that has been spoken by the National Party leaders in the Senate and in this House and I, for one, will do all I can to make sure that we go on as a country holding our head high and being non-discriminatory. Therefore, I must support the motion before the House tonight.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Howard's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Hawke's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 relates to the forthcoming referendum. It is an amendment to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. That legislation outlines the manner in which referendums are conducted in this country. Under the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act, the Government is responsible for the administration of referendums and is required to conduct referendums in a fair and democratic manner. The Constitution is the No. 1 law in this country; it is the primary law which establishes our Federal parliamentary democracy. In that sense this law, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act, which details the manner in which the Constitution can be changed, assumes a very great importance in the conduct of national affairs. Just as it is important to get our Constitution right and to keep it right, it is also important that the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act be properly drafted to enable the existence of a framework which will ensure the conduct of fair and democratic referendums.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important not only that the rules laid down in this framework be observed but, furthermore, that those rules be seen to be obeyed. I do not think anybody would have any argument with the simple proposition that in the conduct of elections and referendums there ought to be scrutineers to ensure fair play. That is a very simple statement. It is a simple principle but one of fundamental importance. I think honourable members would be interested to know that this Gov- ernment was prepared to run this referendum-if it could get away with it-without scrutineers. The only reason why this issue is before the Parliament before 3 September is that we raised it. Like so many things concerning this referendum, the fact remains that if the Government could get away with it, it would. That is the reality of it.

Members of the Government have been bending over backwards to break the rules, to evade the rules, to load this referendum, to rig the vote and to load the case for a Yes vote on 3 September. I say to the Australian electorate, `Watch out on 3 September because we might be able to fix up this problem, this attempt by the Government, but the reality is that so many attempts have already got through the net'. So many attempts to load this referendum in favour of the Yes case have already succeeded. There is a long list of them, starting with the Constitutional Commission, which cost $6m of taxpayers' money. And what for? It was to soften up the electorate for Labor's agenda for constitutional reform.

I move to the timing of this year's referendum. Why did the Government pick 1988? It was because it thought, so cynically, that in 1988 people were more likely to vote for something that in other years they would not vote for. Why did the Government pick 10 May to announce the referendum changes? It was because that was the day after the new Parliament House was opened. That has been a central theme of this Government for the referendums. It is part of the brainwashing tactic and strategy that it has employed. It is a theme which simply says, `We have gone from an old Parliament to a new Parliament. We have an old Constitution. How about going to a new Constitution?'. That was the theme which was declared to be biased to the Yes vote, not by the Opposition but by the High Court of Australia.

Why are we having this referendum on 3 September? `Why the rush?', one might ask. Very simply, it is because we had the Budget on Tuesday night. The Government deliberately calculated 3 September because it knew that in those two critical weeks leading up to 3 September we would see media concentration on the Budget instead of on the very important referendums. Why was the debate in this Parliament just three months ago gagged? What sort of commentary is it on this Government that on proposals to change our Constitution, Australia's number one law, it has the gall to gag and guillotine debate to prevent elected members of the Parliament from speaking on our Constitution?

The reality is that this Government has bent over backwards to load up this referendum for the Yes vote. As I said, one does not have to take the word of the Opposition. We are asked for facts. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) accuses us of distortions. There was no distortion when on a Friday afternoon the decision of a High Court judge was handed down which said that expenditure authorised by the first law officer of the Commonwealth was illegal. It says a lot about this Government that it was prepared to act illegally to change the Constitution to suit itself.

The questions are biased. Gary Morgan, one of Australia's top pollsters, looked at the questions and described them as blatantly biased, clearly loaded to obtain a Yes vote. The reality is that there are not four simple changes as one would expect, as one would assume from the question; there are 33 changes to the Constitution. The last thing that this Government wants is for people to know what is contained in those changes. There is a simple explanation for that: all of these propositions, in one form or another, have been put to either the Australian electorate or the Senate and all have been rejected.

Question No. 1 contains a proposal for simultaneous elections. That has not been rejected just once; it has not been rejected just twice; it has been rejected three times by the Australian electorate. Three times it has said, `We do not want more power for Prime Ministers, we do not want more power for Canberra'. Some bright spark in the back room of the Australian Labor Party says, `We know that if we tell people what is in the questions they will vote no'. So what does the Government do? It changes the label. It dresses the questions up as something else. So we have the monstrous distortion from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the Yes case: the government claims it would lead to fewer elections. Not even Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, would back up that statement. He was asked in the Senate whether there was any guarantee of that and he said, `There is no guarantee'. The Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, has taken on the mantle of the Minister for getting the Government re-elected. He was asked, `Is there any guarantee'. The quote is there in Hansard. There are no guarantees. Why are there not guarantees? Very simply, because question No. 1, when we wipe aside the rhetoric and put aside the carrot that is dangling there in front of the electorate, is a grab for more power for Canberra and for Prime Ministers, as it has been on three previous occasions.

I say that, not as a Liberal, not as someone looking for some party political comment on it. Our Constitution is not for the next five, 10 or 20 years. It has to establish the framework of our Federal parliamentary democracy for 50, 100 or 150 years. The Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party might not even be a feature of politics in 150 years time but the power of Prime Ministers will be and if people vote yes to question No. 1 they will give a new and unparalleled power-in fact a blank cheque-to every Prime Minister who succeeds the one we have now. As with most aspects of this referendum campaign, by coincidence or by strategy, the whole question has been loaded to the Yes vote.

Question No. 2 refers to fair and democratic elections. Believe it or not, the phrase `fair and democratic elections' would not even go into the Constitution if by chance people voted for the proposal. Most people think that the questions are the changes. They are not. It is the deliberate strategy of this Government to deceive people about our Constitution. This Bill relating to scrutineers goes to just one aspect of a rigged referendum. It is important that we have rules, as demonstrated by the High Court.
