It was the fact that some rules were put into the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act in 1984 that allowed the High Court to say to this Government, `You are acting illegally'.

The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) was on the front pages of newspapers for a month in relation to yellow fever. He was on every television and radio station in the country. He had committed no offence. And we had the first law officer of the Commonwealth authorising expenditure-this was declared illegal by the High Court-to pursue changes to the Constitution to suit politicians, particularly politicians on the Government side of the House. Yet we hardly heard a whimper about that.

I say to every Australian: the Constitution is the one form of direct democracy we have. It is the one form in which we have a say. Be alert because this Government has set out to con you, to trick you, to deceive you and to mislead you about the changes on 3 September. It does not want you to know that you have voted no to these proposals before so it has drafted them to disguise them.

This Bill to deal with scrutineers has been drafted by the Government. I appreciate the debate that took place in the Senate. I appreciate that the Bill is now being dealt with expeditiously to ensure that these new provisions will be in place so that we can rest assured that on 3 September there will be a facility and an ability to appoint scrutineers to ensure fair play. I appreciate the remarks of the Minister, Senator Ray, who acknowledged the very good work done by the Opposition, in his words, in `polishing up' the legislation to make it workable on this occasion. I particularly pay tribute to Senator Jim Short, who has been instrumental in handling this Bill and trying to right this situation. It is an interim measure, as recognised by the Minister for Home Affairs, to ensure that the situation on 3 September is dealt with. I think it is sensible, as he has proposed, that this matter after 3 September be referred to the appropriate parliamentary committee for further consideration. We need ground rules for the umpire and this Bill in respect of scrutineers at least improves the framework to ensure the conduct of the referendum is not unreasonable and that what we expect to be a principle of democracy, the appointment of scrutineers, can be carried out.

As I said, there are some things that cannot be fixed. I have mentioned the biased questions, the fact that disguised behind the four questions are 33 changes to our Constitution. It is as if there are four labels and each one says `jam' but it is only when one opens the lid of what appears to be jam and has a taste that one realises that it is cyanide; it is not jam at all. Someone put it to me in another way. I was told that it is like going down to the pet shop, buying a talking parrot and getting home to find that the bird does nothing but abuse you.

There is more to it than meets the eye. The questions are not related to changes to the Constitution. The changes are there-they are in the booklet that looks as if it is a bit of propaganda from the Government. But I invite people to go to the back of that booklet. They will see page after page of changes being proposed to our Constitution. They are not the simple questions. Oh, no. That is the carrot dangling in front of us. That is the entrapment. The changes are in fact very complicated. The 33 changes are so complicated that the Government found when it introduced one set of them that they were wrong. We pointed that out to the Government. The Government then brought out a second set, but those changes were no good. Finally we ended up with another set of words courtesy of the Australian Democrats.

There has been no debate. This is a disgrace. One need only point out how our Constitution was framed. The founding fathers spent years going round the country attending conventions and debates and meetings. They spent a lot of time, and basically they got it right. The crowd opposite reckon that they can just waltz into the Parliament. They do not worry about a few amendments here and a few amendments there. Even the constitutional lawyers are now debating what it all means should the proposals come into law. That is an indictment of the capacity of this Government properly to look to constitutional change in this country.

This Bill goes to one issue. Other issues are still on the agenda. I find the ticks and crosses issue virtually beyond belief. We have this Government relying on advice given to it presumably by the same people who said that $3m of taxpayers' money could be spent to sell the Yes case and whose advice was found to be contrary to the law of the land. This Government is told presumably by the same people, `Well, if there are four ticks that will be all right. That is four in the bag for the Yes case. But if there are four crosses, oh, no, they are no good. They are informal'. I see that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), a former Minister, is starting to take some note. It is incredible. This Government says, `Four ticks, that is okay; four crosses, that is not okay'.

When we introduce a Bill we find, all of a sudden, that there are technical difficulties with going along with it. My word there are! There are technical difficulties that there might be a few No votes. That is the technical difficulty. This matter is being negotiated. We are sitting down and doing what we can to facilitate the fair conduct of this referendum. But the reality is that whilst we might get one or two of these things fixed up, we might and should be able as a result of this legislation to ensure that there are scrutineers, the biased questions will still be there on the ballot paper on 3 September. There will not be 33 questions, which is how the Government should have put it. If the Government was being fair dinkum and honest with the electorate there would not be four questions but 33 of them, so that people could examine each and every issue.

This Government is proposing more changes and more words to go into and out of our Constitution than has been the case in all of the successful referendums since 1901. The only time that the Attorney-General really hits the nail on the head is when he says, as he has so publicly on a number of occasions, that this is the most extensive set of reforms ever put forward. He is not joking. There are more words to go in and more words to be taken out than has been the case with all the successful referendums since 1901.

As to the timing of this debate, it was convenient just after the Budget-to stifle debate. Under the Constitution the public should be given six months to read the detail, to go over questions with a fine tooth comb. What does this Government do? It has set a timetable to cut that time from six months to three months. The Government does not want public debate. It does not want people to read the fine print. It wants people to throw the Yes-No pamphlet in the rubbish bin.

The Attorney-General and his advisers are sitting up in the big palace on the hill with their fingers crossed. They are hoping that people will not catch on. They are hoping that on 3 September people who may have just rushed down to the shops and rushed back home to do some other chore with the kids will not have the vaguest idea of what has been put up when they walk into the polling booths. They are hoping that people will look at the questions and say, `Well, they look all right. How could anybody vote against that?' That is the game plan. It is a game plan tainted with illegality, as was declared by the High Court of Australia. It is a game plan tainted with blatant bias, as was stated by an independent observer. It is a game plan calculated to deceive people.
I am confident that in the end the propositions will be rejected. When the Catholic bishops, the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bet you local government gets through. I will give you odds that local government will get through.

—That is very interesting. I am glad that the honourable member is prepared to stand up and be counted. But he will be interested to know that this week the Western Australian Country Shires Association, which represents 107 of the 139 municipalities in Western Australia, dumped the Yes case. Does the honourable member know why? It did so because it was not prepared to go along with something that meant more power for Canberra. The interesting thing about local government is that around this country, from Subiaco across to northern Queensland, from Victoria to Tasmania and South Australia, councillors across this country are finally reading the fine print. They are seeing through the Government's deception. They are saying, `We are not going to be conned'. It is not local government-it is a system of local government. The words `system of local government' do not appear in the question. But that is the change; that is part of the deception.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say to people listening tonight that the Opposition is doing all that it can to ensure that the referendum on 3 September will be conducted as fairly as possible. But the reality is that it is too late for it to be conducted fairly because this Government has set out deliberately to rig the vote. Whilst there may be scrutineers, those blatantly biased questions will still be asked. The whole debate has been tainted with illegality, as has been declared by the High Court. It is no wonder that senior people in the churches have come out and said no. It is no wonder that the Business Council of Australia dumped the Yes case. It is no wonder that chambers of commerce are saying no in spite of the fact that this Government claims that it has support from the business community. It is no wonder that the Law Council of Australia is attacking and criticising the proposition on trial by jury. It is no wonder that the Real Estate Institute of Australia-it ought to be interested in property-is saying no to question No. 4 and the other three questions. It is no wonder that some of Australia's experts on voting systems-people like Malcolm Mackerras, who is a household name, and Professor Rydon, who is an acknowledged authority-are all saying no.

The reality is that the Australian electorate is not prepared to be conned by any government or by any set of politicians. The Constitution sets out the rules of the game for politicians. Fortunately in the past the electorate has said, `We are going to look very carefully at what the politicians want to do with our Constitution'. Members of the electorate are not apathetic. We should not let people on the other side of the House mislead us on that point. It is one of their favourite lines and it is not true. The truth of the matter is that generally in the past referendums have not got through because people do not trust governments and politicians who ask for more power for themselves. That is what the game is about. When we go through this agenda, on each and every occasion the bottom line is more power for Canberra and more power for the politicians at the expense of the people.

I conclude by saying that we have seen this Bill introduced on our initiative. It fixes up one very small part of a referendum campaign that has been rigged, loaded, for the Yes vote. I say to the Australian elector-ate, and this is a very simple finishing point, as it was a very simple starting point: `When it comes to our Constitution, look around you. This is a good country. This is a good democracy. We have got a good Constitution in this country. It has served our country well. People are free in this country. Don't be misled by those who say we must have freedom of religion and trial by jury. We have got those things. We enjoy them every day of the week in this country'. I want to keep this country's constitutional arrangements, its institutions and its parliamentary democracy strong. I commend this Bill to the House, but I say to the Australian electorate: `On 3 September vote no. Write the word `No' in each of the four boxes, otherwise this crowd will try to declare your vote invalid or informal. Vote no four times and vote no to maintain a strong Constitution and a strong democracy'. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) delivered a speech tonight that was typical of the sorts of speeches and presentations we have heard right across this nation in recent weeks coming from the Liberal and National parties. It was based on unsubstantiated comment. In fact, it was nonsense.
—What about the High Court?

—Let us come back to what the honourable member for Flinders has been saying. He has just talked about 33 amendments to the Constitution, but what he should have told the people who are listening to this debate is that there are 33 consequential alterations that automatically must flow legally, and be recommended by an independent commission, given that the six parts of the four questions are carried.
—Do you agree that there are 33 changes?
—There are 33 alterations. No-one has ever denied it.
—Why are they not in the questions?

—Because they are all consequential on the four questions, which have six parts. Let us go on a little further with what the honourable member said. He talked about the ticks and the crosses problem. What he did not bother to say in his speech, and he was not honest about it, was that it was the Liberal Party-I believe through Senator Short, a Liberal member in the other place-which stopped this Government from having an amendment that would have sorted out all the ticks and crosses problems.
—No. Check your facts.

—That is the fact of it. The honourable member then went on and talked about some sort of political motivation. He did not bother to point out that members of the Constitutional Commission have been going around this country for 2 1/2 years, have received some 4,000 submissions, have had over 100 public hearings, and are totally independent. This is not a politician's measure.
—What about Gough Whitlam? Is he independent?

—What about Sir Maurice Byers; Professor Enid Campbell, from the Faculty of Law at Monash University; Sir Rupert Hamer, a former Premier of Victoria; and Professor Leslie Zines, from the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University? Is the honourable member suggesting that these people are not independent? Of course they are, and they have brought to this nation recommendations that I hope will eventually be acted upon. At this point, for very good commonsense reasons, four specific questions, one with three parts, are being put to the people of this country. There is no political motivation in this; there is a need, and I will explain the need. I would have thought the honourable member for Flinders would understand it, but he has two rules. Under one rule he gets up and tries to take credit for some exposure of misuse of funds. Clearly, that was not the decision of the High Court of Australia. It was the wording of the advertisement that was the problem and the wording can be simply changed. It was only in one advertisement. What about the State of Queensland? The National Party Government in Queensland is allocating $800,000 of people's funds-at least that is what it is telling us will be allocated, but it will probably be more than that-to fight this referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are seeing through what the Liberals and Nationals are saying. Why? Because they are changing their position all the time. The honourable member for Flinders talks about local government, but he does not ever tell anybody that on 10 February this year his own leader wrote to the Ryde Municipal Council and stated:
I fully support Council's request that a chapter should be inserted in the Constitution dealing with local government.

The honourable member knows that that has been said. He talks about fine print. He knows that, regardless of what the Constitution might do in terms of change, the referendum question does not take away the power to set up local authorities. What does it do? It simply says that if a State disbands or in any way does away with the local authority and puts in an administrator, then in due course, within a reasonable period, the State must give the people the right to have a local authority. That will be the result and the honourable member knows that will be the result of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.
—The honourable member says that it is not true. Why did Councillor Peter Kyle, the President of the Australian Local Government Association, say the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: Although there was strong support within the Liberal National Coalition parties for the local government question, it appears that a deliberate strategy has been adopted to oppose the package of four questions, regardless of their individual merit. This attitude is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian public.

It is an insult. I have spoken to many local authorities in my own area, and the 23 or so to whom I have spoken support the proposition for recognition of local government. Local government existed before this Parliament, before the Federal Government, and it has asked for decades to be recognised as part of the Constitution.

The Liberals and Nationals have gone around saying that this argument is all about States rights and preserving those rights. It is not; it is about people's rights. It is about the people's right to better government, to fair elections, to local government, to trial by jury. That exists at the Commonwealth level. If a person faces charges and is on indictment under Commonwealth laws on serious matters that could put him in prison for more than a couple of years, yes, he has that choice; but not at a State level. This proposition says that the people have that right. There is the matter of the right to practice one's own religion. A person cannot be discriminated against at a Commonwealth level. Under Commonwealth law a person applying for a job will not find that he faces questions as to what he believes or does not believe or whether he is Presbyterian or Anglican or Catholic, but there is nothing to stop a State from having those types of rules.

The referendum is also about the right to be fairly compensated if government acquire a person's property. This question is important to me personally because just after I entered the State Parliament in 1969 the State Government acquired a large tract of land in the city of Rockhampton. The trouble was that there were houses on it. People had lived in some of those places for 20 and 30 years, but when it came to compensation they got half market value. When we took the issue to the Minister, I was told personally, `they were lucky to get that because there was no legal requirement on the State to give anything'. Those people, some of whom were 50 or 60 years of age, then had to go back into the marketplace and try to raise money to buy a home.

The fact is that the States still have these powers. A State can introduce a law that says it is going to acquire land for a main road and it does not have to pay anybody anything, or it can set a limit. At the moment, under the Constitution the just compensation requirement applies only to the Federal Government, the Commonwealth Government. If the Commonwealth Government acquires land, even from a State, it must give just compensation, but that does not prevail for the States when it comes to ordinary citizens. It is no wonder that these constitutional lawyers, these commissioners, bought down these recommendations.

Of course, there were many other recommendations-no-one has denied that. Those who have read the summaries know that. The Constitutional Commission has recommended these four matters and the Government believes that they are the ones that ought to go to the people at this time. There is good reason for them. It is amazing that on the one hand the Liberals and Nationals have in their party policies such things as the right to trial by jury. They have in their policies the right to fair and just compensation if one's land is acquired by government, but now they are running around this nation opposing these propositions.

We need to change the Constitution in an ongoing way. It was written a long time ago for the circumstances that prevailed around the turn of the century. It is no wonder that people such as Andrew Hay, President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, on 10 May 1988-not too long ago-said:
The extension of the term of the House of Representatives would be of benefit in terms of national economic management.
Eric Mayer, the Managing Director of National Mutual Life Association of A'asia Ltd, speaking on behalf of the Business Council of Australia, said:

A four year term would reduce the frequency of elections which as well as reducing the cost to taxpayers, would also create greater certainty in government policies and planning and boosting business confidence.

I do not know these men's politics but I suggest that they would not be the kind of people who would rush in and join the Labor Party. They are recommending four year terms. Why not? We have had some 22 elections since 1945. The last one cost over $40m. When one looks at four year terms, one sees--

TALK.START.PARA: —This referendum is going to cost $35m. Why can't it wait until the next election?

—There are people who believe they ought to have the right. I understand that. I do not deny the need for spending money to let people voice their opinions. But we have had 22 Federal elections since 1945. If one looks at the other countries, one sees that the vast majority of them have lengthier terms than we have. If one looks at all the States, all, except Queensland, have longer terms than this Parliament.
—Don't bag your own State.

—My State has looked at the question before. I was told that the Liberals were supportive of the proposition that the Queensland parliamentary term be extended to four years. We seem to have two different rules: one that suits the Liberals when they are going around their party branches talking about democracy, and one when they start playing politics on the national platform or the stage. For instance, the Liberals of Queensland argue for one vote one value, yet the Liberals at the national sphere say no. It is no wonder that people are confused and are starting to question what the heck is going on. Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen went to the township of Emerald and told the people at a public meeting that, if the local government proposal went through, they would be governed at a local government level by Rockhampton, almost 200 miles away. That is total nonsense. But that is what she said and because of her standing in the community people are started to believe her.

SPEECH.PARA: It amazes me that there is not the same fairness and consistency coming from the Opposition that we have heard on other issues at this time. Opposition members know what is happening in Queensland for instance. They know that the town of Roma, which is only a few hours drive from Brisbane, had 8,347 voters at the last election. The electorate of Thuringowa which is in Townsville, almost a thousand miles away, has 25,522 electors. It has three times as many electors as Roma yet it is three times the distance from the capital of Brisbane. There ought to be fair and democratic elections based on fair and democratic electorates. But no, whilst the Liberals say they agree with democracy they are not prepared to support this proposition. I am pleased to note that the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), a Liberal member of Parliament, said:
It is the policy of the Liberal Party in Queensland to support the principal of `one vote/one value' and I have no intention of moving away.

What a pity her leader and the honourable member for Flinders did not also support the proposition. It was not so long ago-18 May this year-that the Leader of the Opposition said that the coalition of the Liberal and National parties supported the principal of fair and democratic elections. They may say it but they are not doing anything about it. Angus Innes, the State Leader of the Parliamentary Liberal Party, when talking about the backflip by the Leader of the Opposition after he suddenly opposed the proposal said:
The Federal Coalition does not fully understand the implication of its stand, either nationally or locally.

There is conflict. It is no wonder that people are confused. There is a need for these propositions to be carried and for people to have the same rights at a Commonwealth level as they do at the State and Territorial level. Just as we have the right to trial by jury under section 80 of the Australian Constitution, that ought to flow back through the States. Section 116 on freedom of religion protects people from being discriminated against by a Commonwealth Government or department because of a person's religious beliefs. So too should those powers and protections be there at the State level. In 1970 the Queensland Government attempted to register religions. It tried to tell people what were and were not religions. If it were not for the churches at that time the then Minister in charge, Sir Llew Edwards, would have pushed that issue through. Fortunately, he rethought it and, as a Christian himself, realised the damage and the dangers of it. He therefore walked away from it.

I ask the people of Australia not to listen to the emotional garbage that has come forward from the Opposition on this issue but to think about their own rights. This issue is important to them. It is vitally important that they understand the truth behind the issue. People have asked me, `Why not change the State constitutions to protect people's rights'? That could be done but the Constitution could again be changed by another law. It would not go to referendum; there is no requirement in State constitutions to do that. It would simply be a matter of the next party that had a majority to change the rules again. It is therefore important that it be placed in the Constitution so that it requires a majority of the States and a majority of the people.

Another question also raised with me is whether all Australians will be guaranteed the right to vote. The Constitution does not guarantee the right to vote or that one person's vote will have the same value as another person's. In fact, when the Constitution was first enacted in 1901 only in South Australia and Western Australia could women vote. Since that time we have seen major changes. One vote one value does not exist in the Constitution.

Another question which constantly arises-the honourable member for Flinders tried to raise it again-is whether recognising local government in the Constitution will give more power to Canberra. The opposite is true. Instead of centralising power in one central government, this proposition states that we will recognise legally and constitutionally those 836 local authorities throughout this nation. Regardless of what the States want to do politically-they certainly try to manipulate local governments-they will never be able to disband them forever; the people will have the right. The States try to hamper and hinder local authorities. At the moment the Queensland Government, because of the Queensland Grants Commission, is trying to cut the allocation to my own city of Rockhampton by almost $250,000. The States do those sorts of things. They play politics with the funding. But what is provided here is that they ought not be able to play politics with the structure of local government. They can change the boundaries and determine the number of representatives but the principle would be there. The people would have a right to a local government in their own areas.

Many other issues have been raised by people as I have moved around. For instance, they have asked whether their fundamental rights are protected by common law. I had a debate with Senator Sheil in Biloela. He kept saying that there was no need to have the Constitution changed because all these rights already existed. There is no such thing as a right to vote; a freedom of speech, of the press; a trial by jury; the right to legal representation when standing for trial on a serious charge; the right not to be discriminated against when seeking employment-these situations are not guaranteed by common law. We need to have it guaranteed within the Constitution. I also hear the nonsense being put forward by honourable senators that this will take away the power of the Senate. The only change to the Senate will be that senators will be elected every four years instead of six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the maximum.

—Why not? Surely it is correct that if the Senate takes this Parliament to the people then it ought to face the people's wrath or support. Do honourable members opposite support eight-year terms for senators? That is what Senator Sheil said. He really thinks that they deserve eight years. We do not need that. If people are to have the right to have a say in who is governing them, then we should make sure that we do not end up with a Senate with an eight-year term. A four-year term in which the Senate goes to the people at the same time as the House of Representatives is fair. It does not matter which aspects of the proposals are looked at. Whether it be the fair and just compensation when land is acquired by a State or Territory; whether it be freedom of religion-the right to believe or not to believe; whether it be a right to a trial by jury-one does not have to choose this as the judgments can be made by the judge rather than by one's peers; whether it be the recognition of local government; whether it be four-year terms; or whether it be fair and democratic elections, these issues have come, not from the Labor Party, not from some party political position, but from thousands of submissions, from people across this country, to an independent commission that has now brought down its recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the people of Australia to think through the issues; to try to cast aside the emotionalism that we have heard from the honourable member for Flinders and other honourable members. I ask the people of Australia to realise that the Government is endeavouring to give them rights in so many areas-rights that exist at the Commonwealth level but which do not exist at the State level. This issue is not about taking away States' rights. It is about entrenching and cementing into the Constitution people's rights; the right to fair government, the right to local government, the right to trial by jury, the right to just compensation. These are rights that exist at the Commonwealth level and which should exist at the State and, also, the Territory level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) allows each registered officer of a registered political party to appoint one person to act as a scrutineer during voting at a referendum at each place in Australia where voting is conducted. It also allows scrutineers for counting. Originally, the Bill stated that only one scrutineer for counting would be allowed. However, I believe that now the Government has conceded and will allow a scrutineer for each counting table. This Bill came about because we raised the issue of appointment of scrutineers with the Australian Electoral Commissioner some weeks ago. It was found then that only the Governor-General and State Governors could appoint scrutineers for counting in voting. Obviously, scrutineers are needed on 3 September when people vote. There are four questions in the referendum and we will need a very close validity check on the counting of the votes because many different voting combinations will result. We need also to be able to rotate scrutineers during the 10 hours of polling through the day. Changes were certainly needed.

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect of the counting that the scrutineers will have to check very carefully will be the ticks and crosses-an aspect raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). Of course, we are supposed to write Yes or No in answer to the questions. I would urge the people of Australia to write either of those two words-preferably No, of course. However, we have the action of the Electoral Commissioner who, in probably the most amazing decision ever brought down by the Australian Electoral Commission acting on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department-independent advice it certainly was not-has ruled that certain combinations of ticks and crosses will now be allowed as valid and formal votes. This has never happened before in this history of referendum voting in Australia. For example, four ticks will be regarded as a formal vote, equating to a Yes vote, where as four crosses will be regarded as informal and not as a No vote. The bias that the Government has built in to this referendum via the Electoral Commissioner is almost extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the only bit of bias.

—There is lots of bias, as the honourable member said. It is amazing what the Government is stooping to in a desperate attempt to get these questions through. The decision of the Electoral Commissioner is consistent with the anti-coalition sentiment that seems to emanate from that Office all too frequently. Apparently the Electoral Commissioner claimed only recently that the Liberal and National parties were responsible for the failure of the Government to pass legislation this year to rule out ticks and crosses as formal votes. We heard the previous speaker on the Government's side, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), rehash this wrong argument. It is wrong. The reason the legislation was rejected in the Senate was that it was technically flawed. Ticks and crosses were not mentioned even once in the debate. That was not the consideration at issue. There were other issues of consideration which the Government had put forward in a quite technically flawed way. That legislation in no sense achieved the objectives of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Reform which had ruled on ticks and crosses and made recommendations which the Government ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted that the shadow Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Short, has introduced a Bill into the Senate to overcome this. I hope that the Government will allow that Bill to be introduced in this chamber. The Government is saying that it will not do so because there is the technicality that there may already be a few postal votes in the system which have ticks and crosses on them and that we cannot have two classes of voters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as they ignored the Constitutional Commission.

—Yes, how convenient for the Government to be able to make this ruling. We have independent advice from an eminent Melbourne QC, Mr Goldberg, who has said that both ticks and crosses should not be allowed and that only the words yes or no clearly written in the boxes should be allowed. Commonsense as well as any sort of moral principle would dictate that the Government should do the decent thing and rule in that direction. I urge the Electoral Commissioner to get independent advice and at least come to the party with an unbiased referendum. There is tremendous confusion in society about what is proper and correct in this regard. There is much concern at the Latin American type rigging that we are now seeing creeping into the Australian system. It is very sad indeed. The Government is desperate.
—Typical banana republic.

—As the honourable member said, it is typical of a banana republic. The Government should indeed be embarrassed at what it is doing. As the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) said earlier, this dishonesty does not end there. The four questions do not lead to four simple changes to the Constitution if the people vote Yes. We find that there will actually be 33 changes to the Constitution.
—How many?

—There will be 33 changes. The Australian people should realise that in the 87 years since Federation we have only ever had eight changes to the Constitution. The Government is asking the Australian people to give a blank cheque to make 33 changes on one day. It is almost extraordinary. The Australian people are being conned. They will be out there on 3 September thinking that they are voting for four simple motherhood questions. However, if one reads the detail of the legislation one sees what is proposed. It has been blatantly dishonest from the start. The debate on such an important issue was guillotined in the House when it was first brought in on 10 May, the day after the Queen opened the new Parliament House. Because of that it was off the front pages. We have had only three months to debate it. We know what happened with the identity card and the Bill of Rights; it took six months before the Australian people realised what was being proposed.
—They are supposed to give you six months.

—The Government is supposed to give six months but, of course, it does not want people talking about the issue because they will wake up to what is being proposed. It is absolutely scandalous. Now the Government is going to ask the Australian people to vote barely a week after the Budget has been brought down when, again, it is not an issue in the media. The Government is absolutely desperate that the people do not talk about this issue. We have never seen such a low key campaign on such an important issue from a government before. However, I am encouraged that in the last couple of weeks in this country at least the people are starting to wake up. Their interest in this issue is starting to ignite. I believe that they will be informed enough to return a solid No vote come 3 September. The Government is getting people offside all over Australia. The Government is getting offside those people concerned about the independence of the Senate and those concerned about the rights of the small States. Church groups are starting to wake up to the issue and, I am delighted to say, even local government is starting to wake up to the sham proposal contained in question No. 3.

SPEECH.PARA: The referendum is nothing more or less than a transfer of power. It represents a transfer of more power to Canberra, which is surely the last thing we want in this country. Eventually, of course, it will mean less power for the States. Question No. 1 means that the terms of senators will be reduced from six years to four. The fixed terms of senators will go. It will abolish the rotation of senators-although we are not told that in the question. The second question means that State elections will be run by Canberra on criteria that the Federal Government is not prepared to apply to itself. For example, if it applied the same criteria to itself, Tasmania would be reduced from a representation of 12 senators in Canberra to one senator. That is the sort of deception that is going on.

The third question relating to local government does not give any security of tenure to local government at all. State governments can still dismiss them and need never reappoint them again. It will abolish the forum that local government had. The Government has slashed local government funding drastically over the last five years. It seems to me that if this question is passed and local government is written into the Federal Constitution, regionalism will spring up. I have great concern for what will happen to local government.

The fourth question, of course, is nothing more nor less than the introduction of a Bill of rights by the back door. This will have immense consequences for juries, for people who have their land taken away from them, and particularly, for the rights of people to practice their religion in Australia. It is outrageous. It is a con job. It is a waste of $41m of taxpayers' money. I urge the Australian people to return four no votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Beazley-I require that the question be put without debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a short time in which to make a couple of salient points regarding the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2). I wish to make the point--
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I got to my feet before the honourable member for Gippsland but that honourable member was called.
—I regret that I did not see the honourable member for Reid. I will give him the call immediately after the honourable member for Gippsland has completed his remarks.

—The fact that the Government feels it necessary to introduce this legislation at this late stage in the debate on the referendum questions, when the matter is to be voted on in only nine days' time, should set alarm bells ringing. The intervention by the churches on question No. 4 should send shivers up many spines. However, it should draw attention to the implications of what is happening. So far people generally have been apathetic towards the referendum questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to touch briefly on question No. 3, which seems to relate to the innocuous, even bland recognition of local government in the Federal Constitution. I urge people to consider carefully the implications of inserting into that Constitution the proposal that will be voted upon on 3 September. I say this for two major reasons. The first reason-and let us not kid around-is that local government will not benefit one iota from constitutional recognition. I have yet to find a councillor anywhere in Australia who can instance one single concrete benefit that will flow to ratepayers as the result of constitutional recognition. There are no guarantees as to road funding or general finance. There is no protection against false dismissal or amalgamations. When local government should be directing itself to considering bread and butter issues, as ratepayers demand that it should do, it is self-indulgently spending its time arguing that constitutional recognition will raise the status of local government. It is a political ploy to suggest that this will raise the status of local government, when in fact it will do nothing for that important third tier of government.

Let me put forward the second major reason why the Opposition has grave fears about constitutional recognition-leaving aside the fact that the proper place for such recognition of local government is in State constitutions, as is the case in four out of six States, with Queensland and Tasmania undertaking to provide recognition. One wonders what will be the future makeup and shape of local government in view of the fact that the High Court-a group of unelected judges-will be called upon to define the structure of local government. The key words which should be burned forever into the consciousness of councillors are `to recognise local government'. What is meant by that phrase? We simply do not know, but we do know that the High Court-given the precedents of past decades-is likely to find in favour of centralised power to the Commonwealth, which may well pave the way towards regionalisation.

In arguing for constitutional recognition local government bodies are leading their ratepayers into a legal minefield. Ratepayers should be up in arms because a number of local government bodies throughout Australia are contributing scarce funds to a fighting fund, a central pool, to advertise the `Yes' case. Money is being wasted in that way. That money could go to meeting some of the more immediate concerns of ratepayers. Ratepayers should also be up in arms when they consider who will fund the protracted and expensive High Court litigation. It will be the ratepayers who will fund that litigation. Constitutional lawyers are rubbing their hands with glee at the prospect of an endless series of High Court cases. Local Government bodies that support the constitutional question are at best naive, and at worst recklessly negligent. They are naive because the proposition will confer not a single benefit on ratepayers, and they are recklessly negligent because this has opened a legalistic Pandora's box which may well change the whole face of local government as we know it today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a former Minister for Local Government I would say, without being too boastful, that I have probably had more experience of local government than any other Minister in Australia's history. As honourable members well know, in the years 1972 to 1975 I was associated with the Government which made the first untied grants available to local government. At that time the grants amounted to only $56m. This year local government will receive $700m. It is true that in 1974 we placed before the Australian people a referendum to give local government certain constitutional powers under the Australian Constitution. At that time because local government was suspicious of the actions of the then Whitlam Labor Government, it campaigned against it. The provision was passed in only one State, New South Wales, but 47 per cent of the Australian people supported that constitutional move in regard to local government.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Hawke Labor Government, arising out of the Adelaide Convention, we set up a Committee to investigate constitutional recognition of local government. That Committee was under the co-chairmanship of Doug Lowe, the former Premier of Tasmania, and Greg Percival, a well known liberal member of parliament in the New South Wales upper House. They did a magnificent job and came to me with three propositions. The first was the status quo; the second involved a charter of principles; and the third was full constitutional recognition. They told me at that time that they thought local government would want the charter of principles attached to the Constitution to attain unity of agreement in local government. I told them that it was Labor Party policy that there should be full constitutional recognition, but that we would not press this as a policy as we wanted it to emerge from local government. They sent the matter back to local government and to the States, and right across the nation every local government authority supported full constitutional recognition.

At the Brisbane convention about two years ago, the New South Wales member of parliament I mentioned earlier moved on behalf of the Local Government Association the proposal that is now before the people of Australia. I seconded the proposal on behalf of the Australian Government. Soon after that the Attorney-General suggested to Cabinet that the best way in which constitutional changes could be achieved was to ask a representative body of people throughout the nation to bring forward recommendations from the people. After a lengthy inquiry, the Commission brought down certain recommendations. Four of those recommendations are now before the House. The third recommendation is that local government should be recognised in the Constitution. The question now being asked is what this means in money terms. The truth is that at present local government is not named or recognised in the Constitution. At present if a State wishes to abolish local government, it may do so. Under the new proposals the States will not be interfered with and will have the right to determine the boundaries of the respective local authorities. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has been scaremongering about the basis of regionalism. Regionalism will evolve only if the people at the local government level desire it. That argument is a phoney which I have knocked over.

The next issue relates to the statement by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) that once a State dismissed a local government body, it would not have to be re-elected. Under this new proposal that is completely false. It is true that States will still have the power to dismiss a local government body if they think it is corrupt or doing wrong, but after a certain given time has elapsed they will have to see that that local government body is re-elected. That body must be democratically elected by the people. States will not be able to set up bureaucratic bodies like the Sydney City Council commissioners. That is an undemocratic approach and local government authorities will be able to be elected democratically by the people in the electorate.

In my time I have seen local government change from being a body with a roads, gutters and drains mentality to being one of broad human community services. I have great faith that local government will develop into a form of government that is truly representative of the people and is responsive to the people. In many studies and undertakings we have found that local government is much more responsive than either State governments or the Federal Government. We also find that it is much more economic to carry out services at local government level than at State or Federal level. After all, we are moving into a period in which, if the public dollar must be spent, the Commonwealth, the States and local government together should work in a cooperative and sensible way and, if the dollar can be best spent at local level, we should make sure it is spent there in the interests of the people. If it is the responsibility of the Federal Government to carry out certain tasks, but we wish local government to carry out these tasks, that should be done. I am quite sure that even the States find that they are diverting responsibilities to local government.

In the past local government has been taken too much for granted. Under this amendment to the Constitution, once the recognition comes through-and the amendment will be passed on 3 September-this will change. The Liberal and National parties know that their own people at grass roots level in local government want full constitutional recognition. One only has to look at the people who are making advertisements-for example, Sallyanne Atkinson, the Liberal Lord Mayor of the Brisbane City Council, is seeking full constitutional recognition for local government. Another is Jim Mooney, a member of the Liberal Party from Tasmania, who is openly campaigning for full constitutional recognition. Honourable members all know that at branch level members of the Liberal and National parties will be out there on referendum day handing out how to vote cards and these cards will urge people to vote yes on the third issue of full constitutional recognition for local government. Let us stop this humbug. We know what local government wants. We know that we should support it at all levels and we know that it is in the best interests of the Australian people because local government is the government which is nearest the people and which is the most democratic process.

One of the joys I have had from being a member of the Hawke Government was my involvement in local government. Many of that Government's policies have been free market force policies. However, in local government it has adopted interventionist policies, policies which allow the people at the grass roots to spend in excess of $1 billion of Commonwealth funds each year. The people at the grass roots level should have a better say over how their money is spent. I hope that the people listening to the debate tonight will vote yes on the third issue. In fact, they should consider voting yes on all the other issues as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Opposition has not opposed the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2), which simply allows political parties to appoint scrutineers. Opposition members have spent most of their time in this debate attacking the substance of the four questions in the referendum. There was a suggestion during the debate that the Opposition had first raised this issue. That is wrong and my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has asked me to make that point clear. Senator Ray wrote to the responsible shadow Minister about scrutineers before the Opposition had even raised the issue with him and he provided an invitation to the Opposition to look at the inclusion in the legislation of scrutineers nominated by political parties. It took the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) two weeks to respond, so therefore his statement that the Opposition first raised the matter is completely wrong. Nevertheless, although the Opposition did not raise the issue with us, we appreciate the fact that it has not opposed this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, Opposition members have spent their time attacking the substance of the four referendum questions in a most negative, misleading and disruptive manner. It is interesting to ask why the Opposition is opposing the referendum questions at all. The first question in the referendum relates to four-year terms for the National, State and Territory parliaments. Of all the State governments, Queensland is the only one which has not accepted the fact of four-year terms, so one wonders why the Opposition does not accept that these terms should be a fact for the national Parliament. There have been six elections in the past 12 years. I have been in this Parliament less than 11 years and I have won six elections. I think it is about time that the Opposition faced up to the realities of this question.

Secondly, it would be interesting to know why Opposition members are opposing the second question, which relates to fair and democratic elections. A Yes vote would ensure that the numbers of voters in any seat in the Federal and State parliaments did not exceed 10 per cent of the average number of voters either way. Of course, that applies in the national Parliament and it is interesting to ask why opposition members do not accept it for State parliaments. The answer is clear: the Liberal Party is protecting the interests of the Queensland National Party. The Liberals in Queensland should put this question to the Federal Liberals in this House: Why are they, of all people in Australia, protecting very narrowly and sectionally the interests of the Queensland National Party Government against the interests of their own people in Queensland?
However, to conclude, we are very confident not only that we will pass this Bill in about 15 seconds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to put some money on it?

—Yes, I will put some money on that and I will also put some money on the fact that we will get a Yes vote on the four questions on 3 September. Our victory will hasten the demise of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). There are two issues that will hasten his demise-this one, when the Opposition loses the vote on 3 September, and the issue of migration and the despicable stand that most Opposition members and their leader have taken, as evidenced this afternoon. The fortunes of the Opposition are in decline and when the Government wins on 3 September, it will hasten that process.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Now that the Parliament has taken possession of this great Australian building, it is fitting that I deliver a progress report on the latest costings and progress of work. There are works still being completed at this stage, including office areas in the southern portion of the building and some landscaping. For some considerable time there will also be rectification work for defects, which is normal after completion and occupation of any large project. This will proceed over the next 12 months. All of this type of work is planned to take place with the minimum of disruption to the work of honourable members and senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The revised building budget up until February 1988 now stands at $901.54m, with another $162.63m for non-building items. The total project budget has therefore increased from $1,056.31m at November 1987 prices to $1,064.17m at February 1988 prices. This updating includes $4.52m for the effects of inflation in the three months to February. Additional components to cover costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) include an allowance of $1.77m for the cost of industrial disputes. This compares favourably with the $2.41m, $4.05m and $5.5m announced in the preceding three quarters. The other allowances include $300,000 for the creation of the thirtieth Minister's suite and $650,000 for additional costs of exchange rate variations over a period of two years.

With respect to the decision to cease using rainforest timber on the new Parliament House project, by the end of February 1988 the Authority had received and settled most claims from timber suppliers and furniture manufacturers. The cost at that stage, including all of the settled claims, was approximately $770,000. This needs to be discounted by approximately $150,000, which was the cost already incurred by the Authority due to delays in receipt of timber withheld from the Authority's furniture manufacturers from June 1987. When the decision was taken not to use further rainforest timbers, those supplies were still being withheld. If the decision had not been taken the cost of delivery delays would have continued to increase while the bans remained in place. The Authority has now been reimbursed $620,000 by the Government.

While having had only a short space of time to become accustomed to the size, layout and function of the building, honourable members, including some previous detractors, are with obvious pride becoming the building's greatest protagonists. There are a number of defects, as I mentioned, and probably a number of irritants that will have to be cleared up, I hope over the next several weeks. We would expect that the people responsible-that is, the PHCA in some areas, the Presiding Officers in others, and the Parliament House Executive Wing Branch of my Department-will be attending to those matters over the next several weeks. I am sure that all honourable members and senators agree that the permanent Parliament House is a great example of Australian construction skills.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of the former Prime Minister of Australia, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, and Mrs Fraser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The latest cost blow-out revealed by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) lifts the cost of the new Parliament House from the original estimate of around $300m to $1,064m. And that is not the final bill, either. As we heard the Minister say, there will be the additional cost of getting the gremlins out of the building and overcoming some of the design faults. There is no doubt that that will further blow out the final cost of the building. That is not to say that it is not a magnificent building which should serve the nation for a very long time, but so many of the cost blow-outs were avoidable, and they could certainly have been avoided by a government with a little more intestinal fortitude than the Hawke Government has shown.

SPEECH.PARA: Four out of the five reasons identified by the Minister tonight for the blow-out in costs could have been avoided. For example, the inability of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to resolve the factional differences within his Party and make some hard decisions was resolved at great cost to the taxpayer by appointing three extra Ministers. Not only did the hard pressed taxpayer have to put up another $1m to cover the extra salaries for the Ministers, their staff and extra office expenses, but also there is the extra expense of the fitout of additional ministerial offices in this new Parliament House.

In April of this year the Minister said that an additional $1.42m had been spent on the reinstatement of previously deleted works, including two ministerial suites and the area to house the Australian Protective Services in the southern part of the building. Today we are told that another $300,000 over the budgeted expenditure was required for the creation of the thirtieth Minister's suite. So the cost of the Prime Minister's inability to resolve internal factional differences within the Australian Labor Party is now moving up towards $2m.

But this is not the only example of this Government's failure to have a little intestinal fortitude and take tough decisions and stick with them. The Government has never had the resolve to stand up to industrial blackmail, strikes and disruption, which its so-called friends in the union movement irresponsibly implement. Of course the unions know that the best target is the Government, because this Government has a history of meek compliance with the irresponsible and irrational demands of the unions. In the case of this building, the hard pressed taxpayer has had to pay over a quarter of a million dollars a week extra tax over the past year to pay for industrial disruption on this site alone. The only excuse offered by the Minister tonight is that the loss rate in the last quarter was not as great as it had been in previous quarters. Let me remind the Australian taxpayer that that is not because the Hawke Government decided that it was time to curb the irresponsible actions of unions, their actions in milking the taxpayer, but rather because the work was nearly completed and those irresponsible trade union leaders had moved on to greener pastures.

The third area of cost blow-out which has resulted from this Government's failure to take tough decisions is the continual cost blow-outs arising from the impact of inflation. One of the reasons we have had such a high rate of inflation in this country is that the Government could not resist demands for extravagant spending in its early Budgets. That weakness has led to a sustained period of high inflation in this country-much higher than that of our international competitors. The devastatingly high cost paid by Australians as a result of this Government's highly inflationary policies has been felt by our exporters, who have had to bear the higher costs at home, which of course they could not recover on international markets. Our higher domestic inflation has cost us export sales and has cost the taxpayer dearly on this particular project. The taxpayer is having to find an extra $1 1/2m a month to pay for the cost of inflation in the final construction stages of this building.

That gives some idea of the high cost to the community of inflation. In each of the last four Budgets the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has grossly underestimated the inflation rate. In 1984-85 his Budget estimate of the inflation rate was not only wrong, it was in error by 29 per cent. The Treasurer's record of Budget inflation forecasts is poor, and his estimates have been way off the mark because of his failure to fight inflation first. Why? Because he wants more tax. He wants to reap the benefits of inflation, which pushes wage earners and salary earners into higher tax brackets. Without more tax he cannot pay for the failure of this Government to administer effectively the business of government.

The fourth area in which the Government has caused a cost blow-out relates to its sudden change of mind on the timber to be used in Parliament House. Originally the same timber that has been logged and used in the rest of Australia was to be used in this Parliament House. We are not talking about endangered species; we are talking about properly identified milling timber which happened to come from north Queensland. When some lone voice protested, the Government buckled, at a cost, now revealed, of $770,000. That cost is to be carried by the Australian taxpayers. They are to pay for this Government's failure to complete its contractual obligations. I have identified four of the areas of cost blow-out which stem directly from Government policy. This incompetent, inept and weak Government has added millions of dollars to the cost which the taxpayers must foot for this building.

This is a grand, if somewhat extravagant, building. Given the cost, we all would want it to be in use for a long time into the future. There is a lot more work to do to ensure that it meets the needs of its occupants. Stories of problems with the building abound-not unexpected, I suppose, with a building of this size. I think it was Senator Cooney who was stuck in a lift for three-quarters of an hour yesterday, or the day before, on his way to a division. I just wonder whether that was a convenient excuse or whether he really was stuck.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of my colleagues got stuck in a broom cupboard here.

—Who was it? It may not surprise us. I am sure that Senator George Georges, when voting against the ID card, would have loved the excuse of being stuck in a lift for three-quarters of an hour. Senator Cooney said that when he did get out he took the wrong turn and ended up in a broom cupboard as well. I even heard-I cannot vouch for this-that an attendant got stuck in a stairwell for a weekend when the fire doors locked on him. I did not think that was a very amusing story. We have heard of members being forced to eat in the members' bar because half the dining room was closed because of supposedly unsafe steps.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, the one-minute warning light on the clock which indicates members' speaking time is almost invisible. There are gremlins in the sound system, and so the list goes on. Some of the stories doing the rounds are no doubt exaggerated. Nevertheless, I am sure that someone will catalogue them and they will make very interesting reading for our children who are interested enough to learn of the beginnings of this great Parliament House. Whilst a great deal still has to be done, I condemn the Government for its contribution to the cost blow-out. Nevertheless, I in no way suggest that it is not a great building. Those responsible have done a very good job in getting such a large undertaking operational for this sitting of the Parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Immigration Policy-House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure Inquiry into Telecom: Government Response-Member for Deakin: Extended Family's Parliamentary Service-Referendums: Registered Postal Voters-Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia
