SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I will not be infringing the Standing Orders in relation to reopening a debate if I make a personal explanation concerning the way in which I voted this afternoon on the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As one of several from this side of the House who voted with the Government, I feel it is incumbent upon me to explain why I took the step that I did, having been a member of this House for some 15 years and having never seen fit to do so before.

SPEECH.PARA: I ought to say, firstly, that I regard the question of racial discrimination, particularly in relation to immigration matters, as of such an order that I see this as being a fundamental issue as far as I personally am concerned. Without disparaging those who have crossed the floor before, I do not see it in the same light as policies on airlines or taxation questions-matters that I would characterise as being largely of bricks and mortar in type. I understand that the Government seeks to divide us on matters such as this and I understand the cynicism of the Government when it puts a matter such as this before us.

I wish to make three points in relation to that. Firstly, the Government saw this question as being so important that it gagged the debate. It prevented from speaking in the debate people who were in the position in which I was; they had a serious moral position to state on the matter. Secondly, honourable members on this side of the House enjoy the opportunity to have a free vote. Some on the other side chiack us because of it, but they never cross the floor. Thirdly, on an equally important matter yesterday the Government had an opportunity to show its concern to adopt a principled position. In relation to the motion of the Prime Minister on the question of Aborigines, a largely inconsequential, in my view, amendment could have been accepted. In terms of the Government's own position-only more abundantly provided for it-it was not prepared to accede to that minor amendment in order to ensure that a principled resolution had the support of members of Parliament from both sides. I regard that as a pretty poor show on the Government's part. It put me in an equally difficult position.

I want to say something in relation to the matter that was before us today because, as I have said, it was an important matter to me. I supported the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). I accept the statements made by my colleagues that that amendment, which embodies the policy that we have adopted, is non-racist in effect and application. I accept all of the statements that my colleagues have made that they would not support a racially discriminatory policy in relation to immigration. I accept their bona fides. I voted for the amendment on that basis. But, equally so, when I came to examine the motion moved by the Prime Minister I could not in conscience vote against it.

I want to make several points in relation to this matter because, as I said, I voted for the Opposition's statement. The first point that the Prime Minister made was accepted by the Opposition. That dealt with acknowledging the historic action of the Holt Government, with bipartisan support in initiating the dismantling of the white Australia policy. The second matter related to Labor Party policies which have been pursued and, it is stated, with bipartisan support. I want to make it clear that that was only in relation to a non-discriminatory immigration policy and not in relation to its other policies.

The final point I wish to make is in relation to point (3), which calls for one to give an unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them. I could not in conscience vote against that proposition and I could not be silent on that matter. For that reason, I felt obliged to vote today in favour of the motion. For me it was a very significant step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, was unable to speak on the motion about migration today because of the closure of the debate. I now take the opportunity to place on record the reasons why I voted today for the Government motion on migration. We were asked to approve the proposition that, as to the reasons used for determining immigration intake, `race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them'. To vote against it is clearly to invite the imputation that one may at some time in the future use race or ethnic origin as a selection criterion. The problem about following that course is the perception held by the public of what politicians are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: There are certainly people who are contacting my office suggesting that I should support my Leader (Mr Howard) in keeping Asians out. My protests that he has not adopted a racist attitude do not turn away nor moderate those views. In fact, as I have said elsewhere, the debate from the Opposition's standpoint generally seems to be conducted in an `aura of innocence'. How can we expect to have our Leader introduce the subject of immigration in terms of `Asian', how can we have National Party members of the coalition say that Asian immigration should be reduced, without stirring the question or race within the Australian community? The question therefore has quickly descended from a discussion about the future migrant intake to one about the level of internal racial tolerance.

I need go no further than referring to the burning of Mr Peter Dight's garage and his harassment in Adelaide to illustrate that point. The simple fact is that public opinion is easily led on racial issues and no amount of `inertial guidance' can control the racial missile once it is off the launching pad. The report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies gives us plenty of ammunition to push the Government into remedial action in regard to the immigration policy. However, that report does not support a racial attitude to the program. It is now time to unite the community on the race issue before it flares into an ugly reproach for us all. History shows us that we can differ on many things in principle and about administration. We should now put aside those publicly aired views that divide us on race. It has not been satisfactory to me that I have had to do that personally by supporting a Government initiative. Neither is there satisfaction in knowing that the division arises from our side of politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) tabled the Government response to a House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report entitled Poles Apart. The Committee inquired into Telecom's zonal and charging policies in rural and remote areas of Australia. It was tabled in the Parliament on 20 November 1986. There was a very significant difference from the time the report was presented until the Government response, although the time delay was due in part to the diverse and complex issues that needed to be addressed by Telecom in responding to this report and an earlier report, Ringing in the Changes. When Poles Apart was presented I noted in my comments that, as with Ringing in the Changes, Telecom's technical performance had been generally good but the Australian Telecommunications Commission had been insufficiently responsive to the needs of the Australian community in the 1980s. Telecommunications are particularly important to Australians who live outside the capital cities and a reliable telephone service is more than a convenience in many rural remote areas: it is a necessity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was particularly concerned with the communications needs of country people and put together a package of improvements reflected by 33 recommendations. I was pleased to note that Telecom has already undertaken action to address the concerns presented to the inquiry and, further, that relevant procedures have been strengthened and plans have been developed to ensure that Telecom is responsive to the interests of the rural community.

Although not all of the 33 recommendations have been adopted by Telecom, it is pleasing to note that alternative actions are proposed which will address the concerns underlying those recommendations which cannot be fully implemented. The Committee identified five major issues in the course of its inquiry. These were: the designation of service centres; the problems relating to countrywide calling; the rural and remote areas program; Telecom's pricing policy; and Telecom's relations with its customers. Overall, I think it would be fair to say that Telecom's response has been positive. Telecom believes that the rural and remote areas package offers worthwhile call charge reductions and greater response to customers-both of which can only benefit Australian telephone users, not only in country areas but indeed throughout Australia.

During the inquiry, the Committee heard a number of criticisms of the operation of the service centre concept and it also received many representations seeking its extension. Critics of the service centre arrangements argued either that the selection of some specific service centres had been inappropriate or that the list of minimum services considered necessary by Telecom was too restricted. Other witnesses, who supported the basic concept, sought extensions to the scheme such as untimed access to the service centre in lieu of the charge per three minutes or access to more than one service centre. The Committee was of the opinion that the designated list of basic minimum services required in a service centre was generally relevant and suitable to the needs of rural and remote residents. However, the Committee went on to say that it believed the list should be expanded and redefined to include certain other facilities. I am pleased to note that in the Minister's response today the Government indicated that Telecom has been sympathetic to the Committee's views on this subject and has indicated that it will adopt a more flexible approach to the criteria for determining service centres.

I could comment on a number of other matters but, in summary, I think it would be fair to say that most members of the Committee would be pleased to note that Telecom has already undertaken action to address some of the concerns presented to the inquiry. It has strengthened some of its procedures and developed plans to ensure that it is responsive to the rural community. Telecom's continuing attention to its customers' needs will ensure that it satisfies its statutory obligations to telephone users throughout Australia. I am particularly pleased to note the reaffirmation of the principle of the cross-subsidy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to talk about the response of the Government to the inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure into Telecom that was entitled Poles Apart. I sat on that inquiry along with the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons). I point out to honourable members that the report was tabled in November 1986 and it has taken until now for the Government to respond to the report. I think that would be a disappointment to everyone. When the former member for Port Adelaide, Mr Mick Young, who was a Minister for various things, was in charge of the business of the House he proposed a motion that the Government should respond to such reports within three months. It seems that with his demise that requirement has disappeared.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take up where the honourable member for Calare left off and talk about cross-subsidies. Telecom has come up with some extraordinary figures on cross-subsidies. Much has been made about the fact that Telecom is so generous to people in the country and people have worked on different figures. When the inquiry was first under way back in 1986 the then Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, came into the chamber quoting the figure of the cross-subsidy. He gave a figure of $531 a year for constituents in one Opposition member's electorate and he went on to talk about the various figures as they broke down for each member's constituency. But once the inquiry started Telecom told us that the value of the cross-subsidy was $492m. The Minister then reduced it to $459m in replying to a question. Then, during the inquiry, the Expenditure Committee was told by the Financial Studies and Development Manager of Telecom:
Our best estimate of the cross-subsidy metropolitan to country in 1984-85 was of the order of $400m to $500m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give or take.

—We can give or take a fair bit. The country people have been belted over the ears about this a few times too often. Earlier this year, on 25 May, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate tabled a paper entitled The Australian Telecommunications Services: a New Framework. That paper contains some very interesting comments about the value of the cross-subsidy. When we look at it, we find that the Minister has moved a long way from his predecessor, the present Minister for Trade Negotiations, who was talking about precise figures. We find that the Minister tabled a paper this year in which the following comment is made at page 40:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not clear how much economic loss actually arises from the current pattern of cross-subsidisation. Telecom's internal management accounts have indicated that cross-subsidy levels from the profitable trunk network are up to $670 million in 1987-88 . . . In seeking to measure only the direct losses that would be incurred in operating the cross-subsidised services, one alternative estimate of $250 million-
that is considerably less than half-

has been made by officials during this policy review process. However, it is not possible to sufficiently disentangle separate service costs within Telecom's present management information and accounting system to enable a reliable calculation of the costs or levels of these cross-subsidies or to enable proper consideration of possible alternative service-delivery arrangements.

I think this shows very clearly that Telecom was trying to tell us that there was a precise figure of cross-subsidy. We have now found, as I mentioned two years ago when this report was tabled, that in fact the level of cross-subsidy is a rather unknown and vague quantity. As a result of this, the Minister has pointed out that the Bureau of Transport and Communication Economics, with assistance from consultants, is going to carry out a special inquiry to report on the actual costs of the cross-subsidies.

I consider that the inquiry that the Expenditure Committee undertook has achieved something, but it has taken an awful long time to do so. I hope that when the results of this inquiry are published we will in fact be properly informed about whether there is in fact a cross-subsidy of the order that has been announced or whether in fact the figure is considerably less, in which case Telecom has been loading the cost up as an excuse to charge people in the country more than necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer briefly to the debate that took place earlier today on the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to a non-discriminatory approach to immigration. I am enormously proud of Australia's record in successfully integrating into the community people from literally over 100 different nations. I do not agree for one moment that Australia is any more racist than any other country. In fact, I think we are considerably less racist. The success of that integration of so many people from so many different cultures is unquestioned. I must say that I get annoyed when countries which do not have that same record of racial tolerance take us to task.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition policy that has been put forward has been accused of having some racist overtones. I reject that criticism. In fact, I voted for the amendment put by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) during the debate here today. But it would be unfortunate in the extreme if some people misinterpreted that policy by thinking that it is being overridden in a racist way. The result of that would be to give some respectability to those elements within the Australian community-and they exist within any community-who are bigoted and racist in their approach. In a country particularly like Australia, where so many people from so many different countries are settling and making a magnificent contribution to our development, that racist, bigoted tendency must be opposed and put down at every step. It cannot be allowed to start, it cannot be allowed to flourish and it cannot be allowed to continue. There is no place in a modern Australian society for discrimination based on race. Any suggestion that the policy of any political party may allow that must be put aside.

Obviously it is the right of any country to decide who shall or shall not enter that country. In my mind, that right is not disputed. In fact, that was the first principle of the nine principles that I helped draw up in 1978. Obviously that is the right of any country. But that principle is not set aside by a non-discriminatory policy in terms of race because one is not deciding on the basis of race. One must not decide on the basis of race, and the Opposition policy does not do this.

This afternoon I abstained from voting on the Prime Minister's motion because I do not think he came in with utterly clean hands in promoting his motion. He made the statement that the motion was not devised on a political basis, that it was not devised to drive a wedge into the Opposition. That is nonsense. Of course it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was cynical.

—As my colleague says, it was a cynical exercise in that respect. Having said that, looking at the words of the motion, in no way could I vote against it. I voted for the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition because it supported the Opposition policy. I support that policy because I believe that it is non-discriminatory in terms of race, colour, creed and religion. But having said that, I do not agree with the principle which was enunciated-that national sovereignty must in some way be prejudiced by a commitment to a non-racially based policy. I think one can be both non-racial in one's approach to this question and also maintain absolutely the right of the government of the day to decide who shall and who shall not enter. Therefore, I was not going to give any encouragement to the Government's attempts to drive wedges into the Opposition by crossing the floor. Neither was I going to compromise my oft stated principle of a non-discriminatory approach to this question by voting against my Party. I therefore abstained.
— Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear appropriate to place on record the contribution that my extended family has made to the Federal parliamentary process since the Federation of the Commonwealth. The second last item of business that was discussed in the provisional Parliament House on 3 June this year was a vote of thanks to former and present members and staff. Time restrictions precluded me from speaking to that motion. But in this, my first speech in the House of Representatives chamber of the permanent Parliament House, I am delighted to pay those tributes.

SPEECH.PARA: My maternal grandmother's sister was married to Littleton Ernest Groom. He was the son of William Henry Groom, who was elected to the first Commonwealth House of Representatives in 1901 as the member for Darling Downs. When he died in August that year his son Littleton Groom succeeded him and, apart from a period between 1929 and 1931, he held the seat until he died in November 1936. During his long and distinguished parliamentary career, Sir Littleton Groom was Minister for Home Affairs, Attorney-General, Minister for External Affairs, Minister for Trade and Customs, Minister for Works and Railways, and Minister for Health. He was Speaker from 1926 to 1929 and was, therefore, the first Speaker in the provisional Parliament House. In 1984 the newly created Federal seat of Groom was named in his honour.

Another of my maternal grandmother's sisters was married to Charles William Grant, who was a senator from Tasmania in 1925 and from 1932 to 1941, when he retired. He was Temporary Chairman of Committees during a portion of his term in the Senate.

My father, Oliver Howard Beale, was the member for Parramatta between 1946 and 1958, when he retired to serve as a highly successful ambassador to the United States of America. Sir Howard Beale during his distinguished parliamentary career served as Minister for Transport, Minister for Information, Minister for Supply and Minister for Defence Production, and was acting Minister in a number of other portfolios over that period. He did not, I deeply regret, live to see me elected as the member for Deakin in December 1984. Accordingly, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will see that my extended family has a remarkable record of service to the Australian people through three Parliament buildings-in Melbourne, in the provisional House and in the permanent building in Canberra; across four States-Queensland, Tasmania, New South Wales and Victoria; and in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, as well as in a variety of ministerial duties. I am proud to be a small part of this family which has given such outstanding service to the development of this great nation of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to raise a very different aspect relating to the referendums. I refer to the category of voter known as a registered postal voter. Before proceeding, perhaps I could point out to the House that during the winter recess I had the privilege of visiting Burma. It is food for thought that the right to vote in a referendum is not easily gained in many countries around the world. Sadly, an estimated 3,000 people have lost their lives in recent weeks in Burma as the Burmese people have fought for the right to have a referendum over the reintroduction of a form of democracy and a two or more party state in that interesting and exciting country, which is also the site of many Australian war graves that are kept in excellent condition.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to those people who are at postings such as Rangoon in Burma. The Australian Embassy staff there carry out work in very difficult circumstances. That situation would apply also at many other missions around the world, such as those in Iraq and Iran until recent times, in Afghanistan and elsewhere, where the staff face real danger as they go about their work in the interests of Australia. It is not easy. Sometimes there is a military danger and at other times there is danger caused by natural phenomena, such as the recent very bad earthquakes along the border of Nepal and India. I hope that the Burmese people have now won the right to a referendum or referenda in their country. They have paid a very bloody price indeed. Here in Australia we will go to the polls on Saturday, 3 September, hopefully without the loss of any life whatsoever, either in the lead up or on polling day, and that reflects the strength of our parliamentary democracy.

So far as registered postal voters are concerned, let the House be advised that the Australian Electoral Commission sent ballot papers to those registered postal voters up to three, four and five weeks ago and some of them are yet to receive the official Yes or No brochure. Indeed, Dr Colin Hughes has formally advised that in the case of New South Wales many of those brochures are still going out to those electors, who have now had to vote without access, because of the isolated nature of the location in which they live, to the official Yes or No brochure. This very specific category applies to hundreds of registered postal voters in western Queensland, western New South Wales, parts of Victoria, northern South Australia, much of Western Australia and indeed, much of the Northern Territory. It is a category which, clearly, the Electoral Commission has not been geared up to.

Permanently registered postal voters already on separate computer lists should have been forwarded the Yes or No brochures as soon as they were off the press so that they would have some chance of getting them before they were required to vote under the registered postal vote format. Quite possibly that could be a breach of section 128 of the Constitution; it is certainly a breach of the spirit of section 128. I do not take kindly to Dr Colin Hughes issuing a Press release naming me, misquoting my Press release, and not really dealing with the fundamental question of registered postal voters. I hope that in future referendums a special effort will be made to mail out the Yes or No brochure to registered postal voters who live in isolated circumstances so that the various procedures associated with democracy and a fair go for people in isolated areas can be seen to be adhered to.

Finally, I point out that many thousands of voters also voted under pre-poll arrangements without having previously received the Yes or No brochure. They did not take the opportunity to look at the one or two copies that might have been available at counters of divisional offices at Albury, Mildura and elsewhere. That is to be regretted. Clearly, the distribution of the official Yes or No brochure has left a lot to be desired. I hope that in future exercises it will be done more efficiently so that there can be an informed vote on referendum questions. In this case if there is a truly informed vote we will surely see the defeat of all four referendum questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday this week there took place in the capitals of the three Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia very large demonstrations. These demonstrations were to protest against the treaty entered into in 1939 between nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. People who came out into the streets of those three capitals earlier this week were protesting against that initial act which had led to the subsequent enslavement of their own countries. It is appropriate that this House should acknowledge in some way that those demonstrations took place and appropriate also to acknowledge that many of us in Australia recognise the continued struggle of the people who live in the Baltic states and who live, quite against their own free will, subject to rule of the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, this demonstration was significant because the Soviet Union has always maintained that it has hegemony over the three Baltic states since the people of those three states wanted the Soviet Union to be there; in other words, that the Soviet Union entered those three countries in response to a request from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. There are two things to be said about that proposition. The first is that it is utterly and completely false. The second is that we now know that there was a secret protocol to that 1939 treaty which in effect made a gift, so far as the two principals to that treaty were concerned, of the three Baltic states to the Soviet Union. Indeed, the secret protocol that we now know existed gave Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to the Soviet sphere of interest, as it was called. The people of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were never consulted, of course. They have never been asked whether they want to live under the rule of the Soviet Union and, of course, if they were asked they would say no. It is therefore significant that this week there has been this series of three demonstrations in what is now a long series of demonstrations protesting against the continued Soviet occupation of these three States.

What the people of the three Baltic states want in terms of what was expressed in those demonstrations is, I am sure you would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, very moderate and reasonable. They are asking for some form of home rule. They do not want every act to be determined in Moscow. They do not want to be ruled from Moscow, they want to be ruled as the continuing free, independent countries that they were until they were invaded on the eve of the Second World War. The second thing they want is some greater freedom to develop their economies. I mention that on this occasion because I believe it is appropriate, first, that the Australian Parliament recognise an incident of this type whenever it occurs and, secondly, because it is important that the people in those countries-Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia-know that there are people in the free world who recognise their continuing struggle and support them. I am sure that I speak for many members of this House when I say-I hope this message is conveyed to them by some means or other-that we recognise their continued struggle and we support it. We believe that they should be given freedom from this continued tyranny of the Soviet Union. We hope that one day, in our lifetime, we will see those three countries once again become the free, independent countries that they once were.
House adjourned at 11.41 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Aboriginal Affairs: Mailing List

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 21 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Who is included on the departmental mailing list and how many of the inclusions are:
(a) organisations;
(b) communities; and
(c) individuals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The departmental mailing list comprises 5,800 names with identifiable sub-components of:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Clothing, Textiles and Motor Vehicle Industries: Assistance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 21 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current level of Government assistance provided to the clothing, textile and motor industries.
(2) What is the estimated level of assistance to be provided in (a) 1993 and (b) 1998.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The latest estimates of current assistance available for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) and passenger motor vehicle (PMV) industries are the preliminary figures for 1986-87 which were published by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in its 1986-87 Annual Report.

For textiles the nominal rate of assistance was 25% and the effective rate 68%. Clothing had a 64% nominal rate and 167% effective rate of assistance and motor vehicles and parts 27% nominal and 87% effective.

(2) In estimating future levels of assistance for these industries, account must be taken of the recent changes announced for TCF assistance in the May Economic Statement and those changes made to the PMV Plan in April 1988.

It is not possible to predict accurately what the levels of assistance will be for the TCF industries in 1993. This is largely because the assistance provided by tariff quotas will vary over time due to, among other factors, movements in the exchange rate between the Australian dollar and the currencies of major TCF exporting countries.

In these circumstances, all that can be provided is a conditional projection for 1993. Such a conditional projection has been made by the Treasury and was included in the May Economic Statement. Assistance was projected to be 19% nominal and 63% effective for textiles and 54% and 147% respectively for the combined clothing and footwear industries.

In relation to assistance afforded the TCF sector in 1998, if no further changes occur following the Post 1988 Plan, then the estimated average nominal and effective rates of assistance would be 19% and 63% for textiles, 44% and 118% for clothing and 41% and 123% for footwear.

The assistance afforded PMV in 1993 and 1998 will depend upon the assistance arrangements implemented following completion of the current PMV Plan at the end of 1992. At the end of the current Plan the average nominal and effective rates of assistance for this group is estimated to be 18% and 54% respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 26 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the apparent theft in 1968 of a quantity of yellowcake in transit (the so called Plumbat affair); if so, what amount was involved and has it ever been recovered.
(2) Is Australian yellowcake in transit not subject to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards provisions.
(3) Does Australia merely notify the IAEA of the quantities and destination of yellowcake in transit.

(4) What safeguards or security arrangements are in place to look after Australian uranium (a) from the mine site to the yellowcake processing facility, (b) to the port of embarkation, (c) in transit by sea and (d) on land overseas.
(5) Can the Minister give assurances that no Australian uranium or yellowcake in transit has been lost or stolen; if so, on what does he base such assurances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The incident referred to is the alleged disappearance without trace in 1968 of a European shipment of 200 tonnes of yellowcake. As my colleague Senator Walsh said in a statement to the Senate in 1984 (Hansard p 1616 of 4 May 1984) this issue is of limited relevance to the question of the adequacy of safeguards now, as that incident predated the present international safeguards regime, including bilateral requirements for physical protection.

(2) and (3). All Australian yellowcake in transit is covered by both the IAEA safeguards system and Australia's bilateral safeguards arrangements including physical protection measures. The Australian Safeguards Office notifies both the IAEA and the bilateral partner country to which the yellowcake is being shipped of quantity, shipper, batch number, owner, receiver, date of shipment and arrival details for each separately identifiable yellowcake export. This information is provided pursuant to Article 35 (a) of Australia's agreement with the IAEA (INFCIRC/217) and the relevant articles of Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements. The IAEA acknowledges receipt of this advice which it then compares with the receipt data provided by the recipient state. Recipient states also notify the Australian Safeguards Office of the receipt of shipments. The physical protection measures which are applied to yellowcake in transit are such that any diversion or loss would promptly be detected.

(4) As physical protection arrangements are primarily directed against theft or terrorist acts, the specific arrangements which apply to Australian uranium are of course confidential. However these measures, which are applied domestically in close co-operation with the relevant State and Territory police forces, are consistent with, and in practice go well beyond, the recommendations set down in the IAEA document INFCIRC/225/Rev 1 and the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, to which Australia is a party.

(5). The Australian Safeguards Office confirms that as at 31 December 1987 no Australian uranium or yellowcake in transit has been lost or stolen. This assurance is based on information supplied to the Australian Safeguards Office by Australia's bilateral treaty partners and the IAEA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is meant by uranium enrichment and what are the degrees of enrichment.
(2) Is there any agreement as to the degree to which Australian uranium can be enriched; if so, when and with what Governments or agencies were such agreements entered into.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the Australian Science and Technology Council report into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle which was completed in 1984 enrichment and enriched uranium were defined as follows:
Enrichment: The process in the nuclear fuel cycle by which enriched uranium is produced.

Enriched Uranium: Uranium in which the content of the fissile isotope uranium 235 is higher than the 0.7 per cent normally found in nature. Low enriched uranium, containing 2 to 4 per cent of uranium 235, is used as fuel in many types of reactor. High enriched uranium, which may contain more than 90 percent uranium 235, is used as fuel in some types of reactor and also to make nuclear weapons.

(2) All Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements prescribe that Australian obligated nuclear material may only be enriched up to 20% in the isotope U-235. Enrichment beyond 20% may only take place with the prior consent of the Australian Government. The list of Australian bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements and the dates which these agreements entered into force are contained in the attachment to my statement to the House on 20 April 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the definition of uranium equivalence as it applies to Australian uranium supplied to France and other countries.
(2) Could uranium in ore that is still in the ground be regarded as equivalent to uranium in yellowcake or processed uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The equivalence principle is based on the understanding that all atoms or molecules of any substance are indistinguishable from one another and are therefore interchangeable. It is used in accounting for quantities of nuclear material when, for operational reasons associated with any nuclear process, the quantities lose their separate identity. Equivalent quantities of uranium must possess the same amount of the uranium isotope U-235. While the equivalence principle is integral to the operation of Australia's safeguards agreements, it cannot be used to replace one quantity of nuclear material by another of lower quality, eg enriched uranium could not be replaced by an equivalent quantity of natural or depleted uranium. Any such replacement would require the prior special approval of the Australian Safeguards Office. No such approval has ever been either sought or given.
The conditions which apply to the operation of the equivalence principle in Australia's safeguards agreements were set out in my Parliamentary statement of 20 April 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able say whether South Africa has a uranium enrichment plant; if so, what is its capacity and when was it established.
(2) Is he able to say whether France has supplied enriched uranium to South Africa.
(3) Is he able to give an unequivocal guarantee that Australian uranium has not been enriched and subsequently supplied to South Africa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) South Africa is reported to have both a pilot plant and a commercial enrichment plant. The pilot plant was completed in 1977 and is reported to have the capacity to produce 50 kilograms of 45 percent U-235 enriched uranium per year. The capacity of the commercial plant, now at an advanced stage of construction, is understood to be 50 tonnes of low enriched uranium per year.

(2) Pursuant to the safeguards agreement between France, South Africa and the IAEA (IAEA document INFCIRC 244 refers), France has supplied enriched uranium in the form of light water reactor fuel assemblies to South Africa for use in the Koeberg nuclear power station.

(3) The retransfer of Australian obligated nuclear material requires the prior consent of the Australian Government. No Australian obligated nuclear material has ever been supplied to South Africa, a country with which Australia has no safeguards agreement in force. Furthermore, the Australian Government has received no requests-nor would any be expected-for approval to retransfer Australian obligated nuclear material to South Africa. Such a transfer would not only be inconsistent with Australian Government policy but also with United Nations resolutions and Commonwealth sanctions concerning nuclear cooperation with South Africa.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 23 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the judgment of Mr Justice Ryan in Chenoa Pty Ltd v. The Shell Company of Australia Limited delivered in the Federal Court on 10 March 1988.

(2) As a result of this judgment, will a significant number of retail sites in the petroleum industry revert from franchisee operation to oil company operation and will the operators of those sites be deprived of their rights as franchisees.

(3) Will the Government provide compensation for those franchisees who lose their businesses as a result of the effect of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act as interpreted in Chenoa Pty Ltd v. The Shell Company of Australia Limited; if not, why not.
(4) Is it a fact that there is now no enforceable obligation on oil companies arising from their inheritance of businesses previously owned by franchisees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2), (3) and (4) No. The decision of Chenoa Pty Ltd v. The Shell Company of Australia Limited was subject to an appeal. That appeal, heard before a full bench of the Federal Court of Australia was upheld, with the result that the provisions of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 were found to apply to the agreement between Chenoa Pty Ltd and The Shell Company of Australia Limited. Consequently, retail sites in the petroleum industry operated under franchise arrangements will not revert to oil company operation nor will franchisees be deprived of their rights as franchisees. It is my understanding however, that The Shell Company of Australia Limited intends to lodge a further appeal in this matter to the High Court of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement made by the New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority that substandard fruit unsuitable for other export markets would be exported to Australia and sold as choicest grade fruit.
(2) What quantity of kiwifruit of choicest grade has been imported from New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The statement to which the honourable member refers in the first part of his question appeared in the New Zealand Herald in March 1988. Despite the fact that it was attributed to the Authority in that paper, I understand that the statement was not made by the New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority and that the Authority sought and received a retraction from the Editor of the Herald.
The New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority has provided the following explanation.

Early this year the Authority decided to send to Australia some trial shipments of kiwifruit of good quality in itself, but which had some blemishes on the skin such as water stain. The purpose of the trial was to test Australian consumer reaction to the blemished fruit. This fruit is being labelled as ``Choice Kiwifruit'' and not ``Choice Grade'' or ``Choicest Grade''. The unblemished fruit for export from New Zealand is labelled ``NZ Kiwifruit''. The volume of ``Choice Kiwifruit'' being shipped to Australia this season as part of the trial exercise is 600 tonnes. Some shipments have already been made and the remainder should be shipped in August. ``NZ Kiwifruit'' is sold in Australia in the September-December period when there is apparently a gap in the availability of Australian kiwifruit. The Authority advises that the cartons are clearly labelled ``Choice Kiwifruit'' and that this fruit sells in Australia at approximately the same price as Australian kiwifruit, much less than ``NZ Kiwifruit''. It advises that the importers in Australia are fully aware of the condition of the fruit and notes that the consumer can clearly see any blemishes on the skin when it is displayed in the shops.

In answer to the second part of the honourable member's question, it appears that no imports labelled ``Choicest Grade'' kiwifruit will be imported from New Zealand this year. However, the New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority reports that total exports of ``NZ Kiwifruit'' to Australia last year were 3,850 tonnes and that this year the figure is expected to be 1,750 tonnes. As 600 tonnes of ``Choice Kiwifruit'' will also be shipped to Australia on a trial basis this year, a total of 2,350 tonnes in 1988 is expected. The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not publish details of kiwifruit imports.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 25 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) know of News Corporation's apparent breach of foreign ownership provisions as at 23 November 1987 when the Minister's Department prepared a report on prescribed interests; of not, why not.
(2) What action did the ABT take concerning this matter and when did it take the action.
(3) Did the ABT contact News Corporation to inform it of its apparent breach of the foreign ownership provisions in November or December 1987; if not, why not.
(4) Did the ABT reassure the Minister before May 1988 that it was taking steps to rectify the problem or inform the Minister of any action; if so, when did it do so.
(5) If the ABT did not reassure the Minister, why not.
(6) How many television ownership transactions which have occurred since January 1987 are still awaiting approval by the ABT.
(7) How many media companies hold shareholdings in a broadcast licence above the 5 per cent prescribed interest limit and what are the names of those companies.
(8) What was the chronological order for licence approval hearings before the ABT as at 18 May 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to the information available to the ABT on 23 November 1987, there was no apparent breach of the foreign ownership provisions on the part of the News Corporation Limited (TNCL).

In May 1987, the ABT received applications from TNCL for the purchase of shares in Northern Star Holdings (NSH) Ltd indicating that once the proposed acquisitions had occurred its traced shareholding interests in NSH would exceed 15 per cent. However, the aggregate of `controlling' interests (ie greater than 15 per cent at each link in the corporate investment chain) held by TNCL subsidiaries in NHS would not exceed 15 per cent. Therefore TNCL would not have satisfied the criteria in s.89k of the Broadcasting Act 1942 (former s.91aac) for deemed control of a company.
Since TNCL would not be deemed to control NSH the ABT would only be able to establish if control existed indirectly within the inquiry process.

At 25 June 1987 NSH advised the ABT that a subsidiary of TNCL held only 10.7 per cent of NSH instead of its intended holding of 14.37 per cent. This would result in the total shareholding interests of TNCL amounting to less than 15 per cent of NSH.

(2) In June 1987 the ABT commenced an inquiry into the acquisition by NSH of the electronic media assets of TNCL. The inquiry is also related to the acquisition of a major interest in NSH by subsidiaries of Westfield Capital Corporation and lesser interests by Daily Mail and General Trust, Associated Newspaper Holdings Pty Ltd and by News Investment (Australia) Pty Ltd.
This inquiry was advertised in the press on 29 July 1987, inviting public submissions. The closing date for submissions was 4 September 1987.

On 7 August 1987, NSH announced the acquisition of further significant radio and television interests. As the ABT could not form any views on possible contraventions in advance of receiving all the applications, the inquiry was deferred on 12 August 1987. Ultimately over 200 applications were lodged with the ABT with 121 of those being lodged between 12 August 1987 and 22 April 1988.
On 1 June 1988 advertisements appeared in the press, again inviting the public to lodge submissions.

(3) The ABT did not contact TNCL in November or December 1987, since according to the information available at the time there was no apparent breach of the foreign ownership provisions. [see answer no (1)].
(4) A Ministerial Briefing Paper on this matter was prepared on 8 April 1988. This paper advised the Minister that the public would shortly be again invited to lodge submissions.
(6) A total of 94 television ownership transactions, which have occurred since January 1987, are still awaiting ABT approval.
(7) As at 9 June 1988, a total of 238 entities held a prescribed interest in a commercial television licence. A copy of this list has been forwarded to the honourable member for his information.
(8) As at 18 May 1988, ABT public hearings into radio and television ownership changes, were scheduled for:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 26 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to part (5) of my question No. 4962 (Hansard, 27 November 1986, page 101), is he able to say whether results have now been obtained from experiments in Britain and Japan involving the incorporation of High Level Waste (HLW) from spent radioactive fuel elements into small samples of Synroc; if so, what are the details of the results.

(2) Is he able to say whether any other countries are conducting or planning to conduct experiments on the incorporation of HLW into Synroc; if so, which countries and what are the details of those experiments.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Synroc involved in these experiments contains aluminium; if so, in what form is the aluminium present.

(4) Have tests been carried out to improve the leach rate of Synroc containing aluminium under acidic conditions; if so, what are the results of those tests and how does the performance of Synroc in those circumstances compare with borosilicate glass.
(5) To what temperature must HLW be cooled before it can be incorporated into Synroc and what length of time is involved in this cooling process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Preliminary results only have been obtained from experiments in the United Kingdom on Synroc containing high level radioactive waste. I am advised that the results support the view that Synroc has advantages over borosilicate glass. The Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI) has commenced tests on small samples of Synroc incorporating highly active curium and plans to add HLW to Synroc samples later this year. Results are not yet available from this program.

(2) A co-operative agreement has been concluded between the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the National Committee for Research and Development of Nuclear and Alternative Energy (ENEA), Italy on research involving Synroc. These experiments will evaluate the sol-gel technology developed in Italy as a route for precursor powders for Synroc production.
(3) Aluminium is deliberately introduced into Synroc to form the hollandite phase, where it is a necessary component of the crystal lattice.

(4) The leach rate of Synroc is relatively insensitive to the acidity of water over ranges larger than expected to arise in groundwater. Advice from ANSTO is to the effect that the leach resistance of Synroc (incorporating aluminium) is superior to that of borosilicate glass, including in acid waters.
(5) Liquid high level waste can be incorporated into Synroc at any time; there is no technical need for intermediate cooling.
